146631300.review:
[h1]A tough but important topic[/h1]
[h2]a must-have experience[/h2]
Depression Quest is imo not a game by definition, but it's an interactive short story about the struggles of daily life from the perspective of a depressed person with motivation, energy, and sleep issues. At the end of each segment you get multiple choices for how to react and proceed.
The most interesting thing is that if you lean too much into your depression and always take the easy route, some of those options are crossed out, so you can't choose them even although you know they would be good options. You still see them and know they're there, but you can't choose them. Instead you're forced to choose an option that you know is bad for you and your health, but you can't help it or do anything against it - just like with a real depression.

As a person who struggled with severe depression since childhood, still suffers regularly, and later with suicidal tendencies as well I can say that [u]this representation of how life feels for a deeply depressed person is the most accurate and most relatable depiction I've ever seen.[/u]
100% of what the protagonist feels and describes could've been copied from my diary and dozens of times I felt as if the game had quoted me, like literally word by word, the withdrawn and auto-destructive stuff as well as the hopeful trying-to-survive stuff.

[h3]I totally recommend this game for people who struggle to understand why depressed people have so many problems with stuff that works easily for healthy people.[/h3]
Retarded statements like "pull yourself together", "think positive", or "Why are you depressed? Life is so beautiful" do not work against real depressions and by saying something as ignorant and inconsiderate as this you only make it worse for the depressed person. Depressed people need security instead of guilt trips and assurance instead of being called abnormal.

I also recommend this game for people who already suffer from depression which may sound counter-intuitive and discouraging, but I promise you it's not. Depressed people should try this at least once not because they need to be taught something (although the game does a quite good job with that) or because they need to see how much worse it can get... but to learn one simple but very important thing:
[b]There are people out there who understand what you're going through,[/b] even if it seems that no one does. And I'm not talking about therapists only. [u]You are not alone.[/u]

There are more important things to learn from this game:
[list]
[*]A strong social support network is essential for coping with depression.
[*]It's important to be able to tell from case to case whether socializing could help you no matter how difficult it feels to agree to it, or if it's too much right now and you need rest.
[*]Don't be afraid to admit that you have problems. Accepting them is the first, HUGE, and very hard step on the road to recovery. Everything after that usually becomes easier.
[*]Taking medication does not brand you a lunatic or make you sick, quite contrary: Medication can really help with depression. The game uses bronchitis as an example, I always use diabetes: Just because the dysfunctional part of your body is [not the lung, but] a gland or a part of the brain, you're not alien or abnormal. You wouldn't be ashamed to replenish your insulin household, then why should serotonin (or anything similar) be a problem? Depression is an illness like any other and there are ways to treat them.
[*]A person that doesn't understand what you're going through has no grounds to judge in any way and shouldn't be taken seriously at all. There's no shame in seeking help from those who do understand you.
[*]And last but not least: Seriously consider getting a pet (or two or a dozen), if you don't already have one. Animals, unlike certain humans, accept you the way you are. [u]If they start to love you, they do it unconditionally.[/u] They don't shame you for a lack of energy, instead they're there for you and interacting with them can be extremely soothing. If you feel lonely, but also think that you're unable to spend time with people, a pet is a surefire way to combat loneliness.
I have 7 cats (and wish for dogs and donkeys, if I could just afford them...), so you can believe me. Anywhere they are is the safest place on Earth for me and I have no idea whether I love them more than they love me or the other way around. They're the second-most enriching part of my crappy life... the best part is my wonderful wife.
[/list]
Yes, I have a wonderful and understanding wife that I would die for to protect her and that I would do anything for to make her happy... [u]because she's willing to do the exact same thing for me.[/u] She's my personal guardian angel and thanks to her and our pets I can finally somewhat enjoy life.
[b]I didn't know that that was even possible, but after playing this game I appreciate her and everything she does for me even more.[/b]

[h3]Dear fellow depressed person: I wholeheartedly wish you that you find that kind of support in your life as well.[/h3]
[u]And I recommend Depression Quest from the bottom of my heart.[/u] The amazing people behind this are geniuses that managed to tackle a very serious and difficult topic in a truly helpful way with something as simple as a semi-interactive short story.
If I was wearing a hat, I would not only take it off for them, but also never put it on again.

I think it is at best an okay representation of depression. It was really relatable at specific moments, but I think it could have been much better.

141268734.review:
[b]EST Completion Time (1 Playthrough):[/b] 1.5 hours
[b]Achievements Available:[/b] 0 (N/A)
[b]Trading Cards Available:[/b] 0 (N/A)

[h1]Overview[/h1]
[i]Depression Quest[/i] is a text-based interactive fiction experience about living with depression. The protagonist, whom you are playing as, attempts to manage his illness (depression) while navigating struggles with his love life, social life, career, and family.

As someone who has lived with chronic PTSD, OCD, anxiety, and depression for over 20 years, I found that the decision-making structure for this game was perfectly fitting. Much like in real life, your choices in [i]Depression Quest[/i] matter. When encountering a variety of scenarios you will be presented with multiple decisions (which can either reduce or increase your depression and symptoms); however, the more depressed your character becomes, the more the depression “takes the wheel” in driving decisions and certain positive decisions become unavailable.

The stated goal of the developer is to help people (who live without depression) better understand depression and dismantle stigmas against those living with depression; for sufferers, they hope it provides them with some level of comfort by validating their experience with depression and its symptoms.

Admittedly, I played through this game for the first time over 5 years ago (when I was in my mid-20’s) and I absolutely abhorred it. I found myself feeling incredibly uncomfortable and insulted by the way the experience of depression was represented. However, I decided to revisit [i]Depression Quest[/i], now in my early 30’s, and felt a level of slight comfort that the developers had intended for us sufferers to feel. That said, because this is a “choices matter” game, I suspect whether or not you hate the game will depend greatly upon the choices you make throughout the game, whether or not you have depression, and where you are in managing your own depression (if you’re a sufferer). As the old adage goes, “what we often hate in others are the reflections of things we hate about ourselves.”

[h1]Pros[/h1]
• Trigger warning (RE: depression & suicide) prior to beginning the game.
• Choices matter and effect the outcome and which “ending” you unlock.
• Background audio/music is soothing, but becomes staticky/glitchy the more depressed you become (alluding to how disruptive depression is to inner peace).

[h1]Cons[/h1]
• Multiple grammatical/spelling errors, weird/unfitting word choices, and occasionally missing words which can be disruptive to the flow of reading and feeling.
• Emotional impact on the player can be positive or negative, potentially increasing depression symptoms for sufferers if triggered.
• Visuals are subpar, and don’t add anything to the experience.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
[i]Depression Quest[/i] is an interesting text-based experience for those without depression that are interested in learning more about living with the illness, but may be either triggering or comforting for sufferers of depression. While it certainly isn’t “Game of the Year,” [i]Depression Quest[/i] may be worth trying if you have 1-2 hours to spare for something serious and emotional (rather than fun, lighthearted, or mindless).

135403555.review: I maximise the window, this is going to be a text heavy session, so I want big text. Then it hits, the room tone shifts as I dial the volume back and check that I understand the keyboard controls. Turns out I won't need them at all, just scroll and choose your dialog line. The busy world fades into a muted background of light gray.[h3]A Brutally Honest Text Based Game[/h3]Depression quest is a simple choices game. You might think your choices can motivate your character, but you quickly discover depression is complex. Very. Everyone goes through depression, it's not all about suicide, but this is a pretty severe story. It's more about the crushing weight of expectations you build up for yourself when you don't think you are fighting hard enough. When you feel you are letting people down, a cycle where you let yourself down starts, often with bad sleep patterns. I found myself slipping into character and out again, I've been in similar situations. Situations all described with brutal honesty in these pages. Perhaps sometimes the dialog to read is just a bit too long, but each day has a unique challenge for you, and so you read and process. After a while you notice that the sound effect "colour" or tone is continuously changing, and that the little chapter point photograph is picking out a detail for your character. Just as you start getting invested in your character and can see some light at the end of the tunnel, the story closes.[h3]No Conclusions[/h3]Depression , like this game, has no happy endings, it's really a set of many journeys. And this little story/game may just drop some hints on how to survive to fight the next one. Hints, on how to spot depression in someone, or maybe what you can should try say when you or someone near you is depressed. There is no magic bullet, not today.

133728138.review:
I have played the web version many times now, so decided to add this version to my library - the music does make it a more immersive experience. As someone who has suffered from depression and is currently going through a rather bad episode, I have to say that this game is brilliant.


Yes, there could be better ways to make this game, like adding videos for example, but the bare-bones text-based gameplay is used perfectly. It presents a stripped-down narrative that makes it easy to identify with the protagonist. Nothing can truly simulate depression except depression itself, but this game does a good job at translating one aspect of depression - the erasure of your agency that prevents you from getting better even when you know what would make things better.


[spoiler] People talk about how the gameplay mechanic of how certain options are crossed out and simply can't make some choices. But there are some other interesting aspects of the narrative. Sometimes your condition will change for the worse no matter what option you choose - which is honestly great at capturing the ocassional futility of your difficult choices even when you find the strength to make them. Additionally, when things get bad enough, you will be forced to pick only the worst option and you will have to proceed through the game while your condition keeps getting worse. It's subtle, and frustrating, but that's the point. That's what depression can feel like.[/spoiler]


I wish the game was longer, and a bit more complex with more storylines. I would be ok playing that game even in this basic format. However, considering how much of this was created by one person, while she carefully crafted an honest experience, I am impressed by the story.

127750553.review:
It is hard to recommend this as a yes. It is a game in its barest form. An interactive text story with no visuals. I played it through once and for me that is enough. There is definitely some reliability here personally. I write that as someone who suffers from Depression and is suffering from a fairly bad bout at the moment. Not all of my experience syncs and for some, it probably does not relate at all. Looking at a few reviews people mention that it is insulting to people with depression. I do not feel that. But, it could come off that way depending on your experience. As the intro says it is made by people who have experienced depression and are trying to show how this feels to others. It is not a game really. But as a form of expression, it is interesting what the medium can do. It's worth a try with the caveats listed above. 
1) don't go in expecting a game. Even along the lines of a visual novel experience (which I love and was how I came across this)
2) It's not everyone's experience. it may not relate to you and this is fine. But take it as the creator's experiences with it and trying to relate that in this interactive fiction. 
--
I feel the negative reviews do not really take these points into account. 
I agree that the medium is not the best for conveying depression. In the sense of picking options. I agree with others that it is not that simple. I did like the way that some were greyed out. sp you did not have a choice for some answers. Depression makes these impossible which can be the way these things feel sometimes. You do know the right answer but picking it is hard. Of course, you know the right one. But for the way the game is played I am not sure how else it could have been conveyed, To be true to myself I went for how I felt I would answer right now if it were me. Which were not all the right answers. I agree it is an oversimplification of how it feels but again It is an interactive story so I think it was conveyed reasonably well in this sense. But personally, it did not come off as insulting.

125274489.review:
Is DQ very deep? Nah, not really - the mechanics are relatively straightforward, even as a twine game, and it's not hard to see what the best answer is in a lot of circumstances. I did like that the character's mental situation blocked off a lot of options at the start, and as I got things under control more healthy responses and coping strategies became available, but it's hardly a gameplay revelation.

Is DQ well presented? It's...fine? The static thing is well executed but a bit cliché, and the difference in sounds didn't really stand out to me. It's above what a lot of twine games do but it's hardly going to blow a skeptic away.

Is DQ a good depiction of depression? In my view, yes. Absolutely. I've had a lot of these experiences, and some of the little touches really rang home; it might not match in every respect, but i do believe in it as an authentic depiction. It's good, it's worth playing, and it's short - it doesn't outstay its welcome.  

It's very hard to assess something as controversial as this on its own merits, especially when the game is so slight, but taken on its own face, with the intention to focus on what it offers in and of itself, as a depiction of what some people's depression can do and how they can face it, it's a decent little statement.

123549400.review:
I am definitely not a therapist to assess whether this could actually be helpful for someone that deals with depression, or for someone that does not know how depression feels like. I am also not an expert on depression to assess whether this accurately depicts depression, or at least approximates it in an adequate manner. As such, take the rest with a grain of salt. 

I guess I can say my opinion on the writing, which I found to be terrible, and akin to a self-help book. Literally every paragraph in the game starts with "You", everything is all about "you", and, again, I do not think that this is not how depression feels like. This augmented egotism of "the character" can also be seen in other, key places in text. I remember I chose to help an online friend with something in-game, and after I made that choice, I was greeted with a text that read like: "Sure, you can't really work on your project right now, you're tired, so why not help a friend?", which is clearly egotistical, and not something that a person with depression would necessary feel like. 

I checked one of the authors/developers of the game, and a list of books that they wrote came up:
A) Be Happy, 170 Ways to Transform Your Day
B) Now Is The Time: 170 Ways to Seize the Moment
C) It's Never Too Late: 172 Simple Acts to Change Your Life
which all sound like self-help books. It's all good if someone wants to write a self-help book, however, this does not mean that this person is actually qualified to depict an image of depression. There are actual scientists/qualified psychology practitioners that can do this, and I would be great if those could collaborate in this project, but all I see is 2 names + the musician. 

With my very, very limited knowledge of what is depression, all I have to say is, do not take this game for granted, but search more on the topic. This is barely scratching the surface, and in the wrong way.

119471905.review:
I have skimmed through a couple of the reviews of this game and despite seeing several that were pretty negative I was curious enough to try it myself. I have completed one playthrough and feel like I have an understanding of the story the game wants to portray, but I haven't explored every single outcome.
As a reference I have battled with severe depression and anxiety myself and have been going to therapy for 15 years. This doesn't necessarily make me any more qualified to review this game than anyone else, but that's the experience I have going into the game.
I have also seen another person comment about some kind of controversy surrounding the game and I want to be fully transparent and say I have no idea what that is in reference to, and wanted to do an unbiased playthrough before I looked into what this might be. If I discover that this controversy drastically changes the way I view the game I'll change or delete my review.


First of all I appreciate the very clear content warning you get before you start the game. The disclaimer explains that this game couldn't possibly describe a universal experience with depression, as there simply is none, and I like that they took the time to make sure everyone knows this going in. 

My impression is that this is a fairly simplistic depiction of what depression can look like for a "generic" person. This doesn't have to be something negative as most people will be able to relate to some aspects of the story. The downside is, of course, that it simplifies a very complicated mental illness, possibly giving players a false idea of what depression is like, or alienating people's own experiences. I do feel like they gave a good enough disclaimer at the start, and as such I don't have too much of a problem with it.
What I personally found most realistic was that you were incapable of choosing certain "good" options, depicting how you can be physically incapable of doing something, even though you know it will make you feel better. These crossed off options were sometimes in the theme of "shake it off and feel better", showing how that common advice is impossible for a lot of people. Simple, but effective.

My biggest issue with the game is that it's very easy to make the "best" decision in most situation, easy to realise reaching out to a therapist is the correct action, that being open with your significant other will make you feel better. These "good" options always pay off in some way, which I feel is a big mistake. Pushing yourself to be social, or to do something you don't feel like because it is the "healthy" option, will not always make you feel better, and will unfortunately sometimes make you feel even worse as you are pushing yourself past your limit. Again, this will not be true for everyone, but I feel like the game gives a potentially harmful view that not only is it easy to make the decisions that will make you feel better, but that these decisions will always work. 
Ironically there is a parental figure constantly pushing you to do just this, to think and do what she deems healthy, and the main character thinks about how it is not that simple, only for the game to then make it just that simple. 


I feel like this game was made to act as a bit of an introduction to what depression can look like, how someone seemingly "normal" can feel that bad. It is simplistic and almost a bit naive at times, but if you don't expect it to depict your own exact experiences it does an okay job. It felt like the creators wanted to give people a bit of hope as well, showing that someone can improve under the right circumstances, and give a simple view of what those might be. 

This game wasn't a revelation to me, nor did it depict my own personal experiences. But that was never it's intention, and it would be wrong of me to expect more than this somewhat basic introduction. It's okay enough, and considering it's free I'd say I recommend it to people wanting a brief summary of what depression CAN feel like. I don't find it bad or harmful, merely one side of a very complex issue.

115680871.review:
Oh boy, it's Depression Quest, the game that caused so much controversy.  I won't go deeply into that because that's a toxic minefield, except to be forthcoming and advise that I received no money or "compensation" for this review. 

And despite all the controversy, when I sat down to actually play Depression Quest, I was disappointed to see it's not even a game, it's just a Choose Your Own Adventure/E-book that got self-published on Steam (presumably because no actual book publishers would touch it with 10' pole, the writing is atrocious).  The e-book has a theme about depression and mental illness.  The e-book explores basic slice-of-life daily confrontations that people with mental illness/depression face. 

So we have a couple of problems here already that make this unsuitable to be a game on Steam, which is for PC gamers, not e-book readers.  My gaming rig isn't a Kindle.  Because this isn't really a game, it can't be recommended to PC gamers as if it is one.  I'm certainly not going to tell people to stop playing DOTA2 or CS:GO so they can read this e-book instead.  Secondly, this wasn't written as a game for gamers at all.  This is more an attempt at "art", hamfistedly dumped on Steam in the guise of a video game.  As is always the case when non-games are dumped on Steam for the sake of "art", this doesn't make art better, it's just making video games worse.  Which is not to say video games can't be "art"... games like Death Stranding, Life is Strange, even Red Dead Redemption 2 feature amazing and deep storytelling as well as brilliant technical implementation that immerses the gamer so completely there's no other way to describe their emotional impact than to call them works of art.  But you can't just take a crappy ebook and publish it on Steam and call that "art".

Trying to address social issues through the medium of video games is misguided and can be harmful.  While it's plausible to suggest the intention was noble, this can do more harm than good.  It's my opinion that it's improper to use video games to push political or social agendas.  Especially things that aren't even video games.  This offers nothing to the benefit of PC gamers.

On matters of technical execution, Depression Quest is a hard fail.  The game engine and technical implementation are considerably worse than your average Ren'Py high school anime fan fiction (and boy, Steam has hundreds of those), although there is a working full screen mode.  At least Ren'Py asset flip fan fictions have asset flipped anime characters and artwork to try pretend that they're actually video games and not crap E-books.  The developers of Depression Quest didn't bother even pretending this was a video game, and the whole thing could easily have been done as a web page.  So why is it on Steam?  I already have Chrome installed. 

Because this arguably doesn't qualify as a game, and offers nothing of value to PC gamers, I can't recommend it.  If you are looking for a decent e-book to read, Project Gutenberg has literally thousands of free e-books, all much better written than this one.

114309533.review:
Based. Cathartic. Intense.
It's "choose your own adventure", and as such it requires a player who is prepared to sit down and READ. Today, that player is me.

It's good to look through these gestalt eyes of the authors. I think that a lot of the challenges the player encounters in this game are on the menu sometimes whether you are depressed or not (stink job, insecurity, social isolation). For example, many of us have probably thought "If I died today, nobody would notice for a bit", if we have been impacted by "COVID lockdowns".

The takeaway from the epilogue is very good; though not entirely unique, it's a good way to view things. I won't spoil it, but... You probably won't be at your shitty job, or confined to your house, or completely isolated forever.

But I'm reviewing the game, not life, and so I will refrain from trying to give life advice. I will just say in closing that if you're curious enough to reach the bottom of my review then you SHOULD try this game, absolutely. It may surprise you.

Ok, I don't like this game. I was reluctant to write a negative review of this given it describes itself as "(non)fiction", indicating that one of the three developers based this off of their personal experience. I don't have a problem with the protagonist because they are relatable as having depression, my problem is how this "game" was made. For a project with three developers, it only ever needed one who knew HTML and CSS. This is not a video game, but a text adventure much like the ones you would find on WattPad or Writing.com. Most Steam users don't want to read a wall of text against a white background, they would rather experience it through a truly interactive medium.

TL;DR I'm glad people can related, but its execution was all wrong.

112999724.review:
There are many mixed opinions about this game but I think most people don't really understand why this game is the way it is. First, we have to understand that this is NOT a choose-your-own-adventure game, but an experience. Yes, the game doesn't let you really decide anything and even when you took the less worse decisions, you probably will end up unsatisfied. But that's how the game works. There are no good or bad endings. There are just endings. That's how life works and that's what the game tries to show us.

Now, about the choices. A lot of people get frustrated about not being able to choose the right choices, but that would just make it a plain and pointless experience. The game works the way it works because it wanna show us that sense of knowing what's best for you, but just don't be able to do it.

Anyway, there are things that I don't really liked about this game like the way it represents many things about living with depression, mostly shortening depression to "Be sad all the time". But I would definitely recommend to test this one for yourself and get your own conclusions.

110075395.review:
As someone who had their fair share of experience with mental illness and depression, this game did not speak to me. The game seems to insist that there are no options but to be depressed, but it feels like it leaves out a lot of options for the sake of making a statement. I even think it risks romanticizing real issues such as depression, by making it a beautiful tragedy with emotional music and no agency of your own to get out. In real life, people have far more agency over their own life, even when facing depression.

It's not interactive enough to be considered a game, and I'm stating that as someone who can deeply enjoy visual novel style games. I don't think the "story" told here is enticing enough to hold its weight in that medium. It feels a bit the way I feel teens depict their issues and struggles online, at least that is the impression I am left with here.

There is zero nuance here, so unless you have exactly the same approach to life as the author of the game, this is not going to be remotely relatable.

And I know it sounds cruel, but at least leave me the very realistic option of ending it all? I know people like to say "it's not an option", but it literally is. And one far too many people feel forced to choose. I can't make it better or even try to, I can't end it all. Then it's not much of a game? Maybe this would have done better as a published short story.

109444119.review:
The game acknowledges that everyone's experiences are different, and I quite like that. Everyone's insecurities and condition are different. Some people's insecurities are that a simple video game that simulate some part of clinical depression exists. This game is quite simple and effective at letting you think and ruminate on your experiences, along with empathizing with the protagonist of the game.   

The music is fantastic, it is forlorn and calming. Though I wish there's more sound effects to represent the scenario. Like distant alarm clock sounds, cat meowing, and door bells. The game utilize this to some extent by putting background noise when you are in a cafe, keyboard sounds when you are on your computer...etc.

I got the first ending where the player build a support network, while still struggling with depression. I'm a sucker for good endings. The conditions of which you are depressed slowly taking more and more options away from you is a great touch. You are on a leaking boat that are sinking, and each action you take only repairs the boat little while water rushes in.

I enjoy the usage of the blue highlighted key terms giving more background. It's an old trick text adventures do, but the writing keeps topics relevant and homey. I think key terms like Cognitive Behavioral Therapy should be able to be clicked on to give players more context. 

The 3 bottom message is arguably the game's most effective and striking visuals. The black words highlighted in static. 
- You are Depressed, even activities you used to enjoy hold little or no interest for you, and you exist in a near-constant state of lethargy.
- You are not currently seeing a Therapist.
- You are not currently taking medication for depression.

Going through the process of getting help made me more mindful of my own condition. Like why am I not doing things as effectively as I like to. What's the second best thing I do, when my brain doesn't let me do the first best option? (Sometimes, there is no best option as well.)

99130973.review:
Trigger warning: Depression & Suicide (duh)

Depression quest isn't supposed to teach you how to deal with depression, it isn't supposed to teach you what is depression, Depression quest gives to you an experience that you (hopefully) doesn't goes through in your daily life, that's what makes the game beautiful on it's own way, it's a game about acceptance, about superation, and about experiences.

for all those who negatively reviewed the game, i understand them.
BUT what we truly need to understand is that this should NOT have a "Kill yourself" button, it shouldn't have a "Take Meds" button.
the game is about decisions, and those decisions are impactful as to how your experience with it will be, if you for any reason hate this game, and when i mean hate i mean HATE, in the sense of totally despising it and seeing it as nothing but an aesthetic game for Emo kids, then all i'd have to say to you is "you simply didn't understand it"

the same way people don't understand games such as Pathologic, Omori or even Grimm's Hollow, and just think of them as "edgy games"

Depression Quest is an Abstract Masterpiece and it deserves every single good thing said about it, you don't "need" to understand it, it's just an experience, and i hope you reading this never has to go through a similar experience in real life.



Side note: the fanbase is edgy, this doesn't means the game itself also has to be, STOP TURNING DEPRESSION INTO AN AESTHETIC ON ITSELF.
However, this game isn't making aesthetics out of depressed people, it is making art out of depression, both are different things, and should not be taken the same way.
similar to how the Caretaker made a full 6 hour album out of Alzheimer's Disease, and he didn't make it into an aesthetic, he made it a style of expression through art, and so did Depression Quest.


thanks for reading                                                                                        -J

I've decided I'd go back in time and write something up for some of the games I never got around to reviewing. Steam says I last played this one in 2017.

Although I've decided to lean on the side of recommending this game, I have caveats.

Beware Depression Quest is not exactly a "feel good" experience. Also, it seems it might be accurate to a lot of people's experience with depression, but probably not [i]most[/i] people's experience since there's no uniform experience of Depression that everyone has, despite the standard list of symptoms.

I like a well-written text based game, but I remember finding the writing tedious and generic for this one, unfortunately. The characters seemed shallow and the writing was dense. The concept of the options increasingly greying out is a really great idea and I appreciated how it was applied.

If you decide to play, it does simulate what Depression might be like to some extent just by virtue of how the choices get limited over time. This is why I (lightly) recommend it.

88904200.review:
Realized I hadn't played this in awhile so I went back and clicked through it again. There's obviously a lot of history behind this game and the backlash faced because of it, though it's such a non-threatening game. My reasons for not recommending it are more about technicalities and how it could have been a stronger game if it was more interactive. A lot of negative reviewers questioned the validity of how depression is portrayed, and that's not only missing the point but also playing up the notion that someone can feel they are knowledgeable enough to criticize others' personal experiences with depression. 

Depression can be experienced in all sorts of ways and this is literally stated in the game, that it doesn't speak for everyone. Depression is not always staying in bed all day; there's high-functioning depression and so many other degrees and variants of it. I think that comparing and feeling the need to prove that one's mental illness may be more debilitating is the least helpful thing to include in a review. Everyone's battle with depression should be valid. 

I think the devs highlight the train of thought and false perceptions of depression pretty decently, especially with the guilt and feeling worthless based on other's ability to succeed in life, not to mention wanting things to get better but knowing it's more complicated than simply "being more positive". Depression often defies logic and it can seem impossible to make choices that would benefit us. It's a lot more complex than just taking the first step and "being strong", and it's easier said than done.

My main issue with the game isn't the commentary on relationships and how depression can affect romantic interests, family, friends and work, but on HOW the devs brought this to the attention of the viewer. The long-winded paragraphs felt so heavy-handed and dragged the narrative, which could be an adequate way to describe depression, but it became too wordy for me. At times, it felt forced with the second person view, and maybe if the devs would have given us a character to play as, using first or third person, and showing us actual scenes instead of the paragraphs of text, it could have been more impactful. I thought the crossed out choices were interesting though, as it plays on the doubt in our minds and how we feel we have no other options, or how our mental illness convinces us we're trapped.

While this is a free game, I feel like there are far more engaging and thought-provoking games out there (that are also free) that portray mental health in a more interactive way, one that is also innovative in storytelling. Obviously this game is not focused on entertainment but more on experience and insight. Perhaps if this would have been a format of opening a phone or computer screen, having apps and answering texts with the choices, that could have worked better. Maybe our character could be receiving countless emails and messages, and we are unable to respond and put our feelings into words, because it can be hard to describe depression. So while I appreciate that the devs opened up conversation and a look into how depression can affect daily life, and how it's not synonymous with laziness or self-pity, I wish it could have been presented in a different way rather than spoon-feeding the reader with almost textbook-like definitions. I don't find it helpful to criticize the content's authenticity or accuracy, but I feel the construction of the game could have used much more work, as there are other ways to present and explore mental health than through paragraphs of text. I am grateful for the epilogue though, and the devs pointing out that there is not an neat resolution to depression and it's more about providing more outlooks on how to deal and cope with it. I'm sure this was helpful to some people.

87871494.review: This game is wonderful, I'd recommend you play whether you have depression or not. It gives you a look into a depressed person's thoughts and feelings and helps you understand their behaviours. And even if you do have depression this game can help you understand your own thoughts and feelings, picking the more open/healthy choices in this game can give you a sort of good ending in a way. You are doing CBT and taking meds, you have a healthy support system and even when you have low days you have ways to manage them. This game can really make you feel hopeful and show you some of the small actions you can take to start better managing your own depression.  And your partner Alex is lovely, when you choose to be open with them they're understanding and supportive. This game truly does really gives people with this mental illness hope that one day we will get better and that the people we love don't see us as burdens despite what we might think, and that they will support us through our struggles.

At first walkthrough I was trying to pick choices I made everyday and get moderate bad ending. Well, yeah, this is a way I actually live. There's no exaggeration to good or bad side, it is as it is. There's a little chance that a person who constantly making bad choices will start making good ones. But sometimes it happens, and the game does not allow you to make them. I don't think it's a good decision.
Overall, this game would be a good start for people who wants to understand depressed people better, support them. We really need it.

Although not much "playing" goes on and it is more of a 'reading/choosing options/pathways ' type of game, it was still a good read and worth the short experience. It does suck that it cuts out options for you as you carry on through the game, also that the options seem very limited sometimes, but then again, this game is only trying to show the player a basic viewpoint of one of the MANY differentiating lifestyles/experiences an individual suffering with depression may go through. 

I think it's rather shitty that some reviewers are trying to trivialise the experience/s the principle character goes through though. Whether you understand depression from personal experience or not, I still think it's good to be open-minded about this game and what the game creators are trying to show you and make you understand at the end of the day. I would absolutely recommend this game for someone who needs a general understanding on how depression can work on individuals at times. It's obvious that this game isn't going to represent everyone who has ever been depressed, but I think the creators have done a good job overall portraying a few of the ways in which a person can be affected by depression (and anxiety too of course, as they delved into that at certain points of the game).

84599458.review:
While there are many negative reviews, I think most of them are judging the game too critically. The game is nothing more than it claims to be or tries to be, a simple text based game trying to educate people on what it is like to be depressed, and potentially help depressed people understand their illness or understand they aren't alone. While this more than likely isn't going to cure anyone's depression, it could benefit some, and it is a great educational tool for those without depression. As you go through the game, many of the choices are pretty easy to figure out correctly, but many may actually be the other way around, and show the adverse ways depression can impact someone.   
  
Many of the negative reviews are simply depressed people saying it's a terrible depiction of depression, which again, I think is being to critical, because their isn't as much of a need to teach depressed people about depression, it's more about teaching non depressed people about depression, or someone who is depressed but doesn't know/understand it yet. if you are a depressed person of course you will have a better understand of depression than what this game can teach you. But to someone without depression, it can help them understand that depressed people literally can't make certain choices, and that it's hard for them to do these things, and it is a disorder that builds on itself. While I can see why some didn't love it and why it is controversial, I think it does it's job well and can definitely help people understand depression better.  
  
If you are depressed, please do your best to keep fighting, keep trying, keep seeking help when you can, and understand you are not alone. If you know someone who is depressed, please try and show them you care, that they are not a burden, and you are their and want to help them however you can.

81096053.review: There are a lot of negative reviews on this game, and many of them talk about the differences between this game and the experience that person has had with depression. The one thing I will say about these reviews, however, is that they aren't looking at the fact that depression takes on many many different personalities in many different people. The depression that plagues the character is this story was, in fact, a lot similar to my own experiences. I was diagnose with PTSD, Anxiety, gender Dysphoria, and Depression when I was 13. Before that point, I was suffering daily. I was on depression medications, but they weren't helping me. I had severe suicidal ideation daily, and made two attempts in the span of two weeks. I felt a lot like what the character in the story was describing. Constantly feed into negative feedback, staring at walls for hours and hours, constant anxiety, etc. I never fully acknowledged my depression, though. I never thought it was enough to get therapy for, and with the route I took in the game, that reflected that very clearly. Another thing I noted was the fact that the character you play as in the story never fully pays attention to their own needs or wants. They only ever notice whether they mentally can of cannot do something. This is exteremely accurate part in depression, from my experience, at least, I never thought to think of what I wanted or needed, I only thought of whether I could or couldn't that day. However, once I started intense therapy and medication, I finally realized my own value. I finally realized the fact the my problems don't burden other's if I don't put it all on their shoulders. I believe I got an incredible ending for this game. I took the route of medication, pushing the character to do things outside of their comfort zone, pushing them to talk to others, to go to therapy. I pushed them to talk to family, even when it seemed hopeless. These things are what helps someone get through mental illnesses, and I learned that the long way. Another accuracy in the game was the fact that the character's depression got much worse before it got better. That is the case always. It's going to be mentally, physically, and emotionally draining, and you will get worse. But, in the end, it's worth it. I loved the slow acknowledgement of one's worth and accepting one's limits. I loved the slow and detailed progress, barely noticeable, but when you look at where you were from where you are now, you can see the change. You begin to acknowledge your growth and improvement, and how far you've come. You move on to have yourself in you best interest, and to put yourself first. You realise the boundary between need, want, and have to. This character hated their job, but they needed the money. After a long while, though, they began to have to make a change. Need is important, yes, but when you mental health is steeply declining because of the source of money, you have to leave that job before it gets worse. Anyway, I went on a bit of a rant. Please, play this game. It is incredible and very accurate.

79789908.review:
This reminds me of one of those Choose Your Own Adventure books, except with music. In the five minutes of playing the game to clear out my backlog, the lack of choices felt me robbed of my freedom. Sometimes, in a game as solemn and serious as this, I wanted the option to take my pants off and scream at the top of my lungs "L is Real 2401" at the party section of the gamebook. A logical consequence might have been that I would be committed to some psychiatric ward, sure, but it [i]could[/i] be a non-sequitur scenario. The title intentionally limits positive scenario choices to reflect the crippling effects of depression - even though someone suffering from depression [i]could[/i] take these positive scenarios willingly, while still striking out others later on. The game robs you of your autonomy in the name of guiding your character's life "invisible hand" style. Inhibitions have never felt more real.

I've been aware of the controversy surrounding this "game", and it took a long time for me to come around and play it because I prefer games that make me feel good rather than like garbage. However, the reason I rate against it is because Depression Quest isn't that unique or groundbreaking. I'm fairly certain someone out there has made a virtual gamebook long before the developers got around to doing it. It's free though, so the only thing you have to lose by playing this is a little bit of your time.

78262110.review:
I can understand why the reviews for Depression Quest are so mixed. It's not fun; the word 'game' is more than a bit of a stretch. But it does accurately capture depression, at least for me. I like how the crossed-out options capture the feeling of not being able to do the things you should do. The biggest negative is that it's impossible for a game of this style to capture how hard it is to do the things you can; it's easy to just choose the things you 'should' do and wonder what the point is. Instead, I picked the options I felt like picking.
It's good that the game offers choices that can help you feel better. And it did what it could in a short game. But since it's a representation of life, I feel the need to point out solutions that are missing. A big one is the binary between 'therapy' and 'not therapy'. I've had a pattern of starting therapy, then quitting and not seeing anyone for years. I didn't realize how important it is to get a therapist that's a good fit, and that trying again would make a difference.
Anyway. It's a well-written story, and worth playing. But don't expect it to be what it's not.

One of my aquantices said "what is worse - lavcraftian horor or tiresome job 5/2? answer is not clear". I have the answer - it doesn't matter. In the end you will never see cosmic horrors in real life, but if you do see them, it means your life is about to end anyway. Meanwhile your 5/2 is soulcrushingly real. Everyday tasks are hard. And I, personaly, don't understand concept of "friendship" anymore. Still, despite all that, I do consider myself unmotivated, rather than depressed.
This... novel depicts a rather dual situation, where random (coz it feels like it) people notice that you are not well and give you positive feedback, but close family and your partner don't. Sometimes compliments and nice words feel out of blue. It happens because you - as a player - are not attached to any of characters. Not your mother, not your girlfriend, not your friends. You spend little to no time with them and, honestly, some of reactions (especially "you don't know me at all" when you try to communicate and express your concerns/deelings) took me by surprise (in a bad way). To summarise all above - it's too short and doesn't build a mood at all.
Why am I saying all this? There is a game, as you probably know, that's called "Nights in the woods". You know where this is going. Worldbuilding of this game is fantastic. Despite it looks, It touches various complex subjects, including depression, mental illness. I always wondered how they depicted last one so... accurate and real? Well it's no question for me now. 
The point is you can feel how it's like to live day by day in a small town, reconect with your friends, discover yourself once more. It feels real. It's funny how game about cartoon cat makes you truly feel like you are not alone and nudge you to reconnect with your family, when actual "game" about depression fails miserably.
When I played "Nights in the woods" I prayed that there would be continuation. Guess that's my proof that god does not exist. You can fix your depression, despite this game message. You can't fix a dead person. Thank you for your contribution.

74820784.review:
I like this "game", and depending on your very specific flavor of depression you either will too or you won't. I think it does a good job of capturing the internal monologue that people go through when in the midst of a depressive episode. As someone who's been dealing with major depression (along with an emotional flatline) for most of his adult life, a lot of the scenarios presented here resonated with me. Like, too well, in fact. 

The whole reason I even played this game recently was because I was sifting through my library to find something to play that would help me get through the night. That's something that only happens in the midst of an episode: You want to do something you enjoy to numb away the night but you're either too disengaged and/or emotionally exhausted to enjoy anything or the thought of trying to play anything that requires even a modicum of concentration just makes you want to give up and go to bed, only you can't. It can be a vicious cycle, but I digress.

Overall, I would recommend this game if you're either living with depression or know someone who's living with depression. This game may or may not provide some answers for you as to what living with depression is like, and at the very least it'll help, just a bit, to know that someone, somewhere out there knows how hard it can be. And that might just be enough to help you get through the night.

72898245.review:
As someone who has suffered from depression, there were some relatable moments in this game for me. It often does a good job of describing how depression feels, and how it's easy to get stuck in certain negative thought patterns. That said, it doesn't go into much detail about why people become depressed, and I think the game oversimplifies the process of dealing with depression. 

If you make all of the obviously "right" choices like taking medication, seeing a therapist, reaching out to people, and going out and doing stuff, your life will pull itself together and you'll get the good ending. These things tend to help, but they require a lot of trial and error, and it's not as simple as picking a dialog choice and saying "I'm going to do this today!" The game kind of acknowledges this by crossing out certain options if you're "too depressed", but that can lock you into bad endings and ultimately leads to a deterministic view of depression I don't agree with.

The protagonist is an educated middle class person with a steady job. His depression doesn't come about because of any intractable or historic problems in his life, and he already has an established support network that he can trust (friends, family, girlfriend, drugs/therapist he can afford). Although it's a good thing that we have a game that can talk about depression, this is basically depression on easy mode, and I think a lot of people will have a hard time relating.

As to whether Depression Quest is technically a video game or not, I'm not sure. The game is basically a Choose Your Own Adventure story presented as a series of webpages with a crappy 90s style music loop that I turned off. I got it for free, so I'm not complaining. The "Is this a video game?" question has been asked many times about many things over the years, and I'm okay with leaving this to the academics. What really matters is whether you get something out of it.

A lot of people really don't like Zoe Quinn, but I think it's important to be able to separate an artist from their work. You can like Depression Quest and appreciate its contribution to our culture while completely despising the person who made it.

The game was free, it didn't take long to play, and I got a few things out of it (though not a lot). There still aren't many games about what it's like to live with mental illness, so Depression Quest still has some value in my opinion. I tentatively recommend it to anyone who has experienced depression or who's curious about it, and has a little time to kill.

72385394.review:
I kind of wanted to give this game a bad review because there's no way to save your game. I accidentally closed it at one point, and I had to start it over again! That was frustrating. I wondered if the maker did it that way on purpose to frustrate the player into depression, making the game a more immersive experience.

But despite this flaw, I enjoyed (!) the game. By making better decisions, I was able to get the character to a better place. Their problems are not over--they still hate their job--but they're making progress. I was particularly pleased that I was able to do that just with some therapy and no medication. Not to say that nobody should take medication, but that was the choice I made, and it was nice to see it validated. This game is not a plug on behalf of the pharmaceutical industry.

It took about an hour and a quarter of  play for me to get to an endgame.

72105953.review:
The people saying that the main character is privileged and lazy and has no reason to be depressed are VASTLY MISSING THE POINT AND CLEARLY DO NOT UNDERSTAND HOW DEPRESSION WORKS. Depression can be caused by traumatic events. It can also be caused by a chemical imbalance, diet, or the environment in which a person grew up. Of course the protagonist has no reason to be depressed. YOU DO NOT NEED A REASON TO BE DEPRESSED. It just happens. I'm relatively privileged and successful, and surprise surprise, I still think about killing myself at least once a week. 

It's clear that the protagonist also has anxiety, and that constant overthinking is definitely something that contributes to feeling depressed. You'd be depressed too if your brain constantly told you that all of the people you love and care about actually think you're a burden. 

People are also complaining about how all the PoSiTiVe DeCiSiOnS aRe CrOsSeD OuT, ThAtS sO NoT HeLpFuL. No shit. Everyone who's depressed KNOWS the right thing to do. We're just too depressed to do it. A very prevalent side effect of depression is a lack of motivation and desire. That's why the protagonist struggles to do anything. That's how depression works. Of course some people with depression can function perfectly fine- but everyone's different, and there are different levels of depression. 

Lastly, people are saying that this game doesn't help depressed people. Uh, okay? It's a game, not a therapist. This is supposed to be a simulation of the mind of someone with depression and anxiety. 

Also, the people who are complaining about not being able to get the "good" ending are wild af. I got the good ending on my first try. I guess y'all just suck at having depression.

Anyway, the game was an interesting experience and I could relate to a lot of what the protagonist was feeling. I've been struggling with depression for ~8 years and have more recently been going through mental hospitals. I think this is a very accurate depiction of what depression is like. Epic.

70858179.review:
Depression Quest is a text based history about a human being in their twenties struggling with depression. It has a very well written text, which can make a moving, powerful and compelling narrative, which is in my opinion a monumental task, since it talks about a person suffering from a condition that is difficult to portray at the degree and severity it is shown here, by a narrative standpoint. It’s hard to write a story that happens mostly in someone’s mind. There is no adventure, no quest. It’s a text game about choices, that sometimes you are unable to muster yourself to make. It’s a narrative designed to portray frustration, impotence, exhaustion, insecurities and fears, which are backed up by the game’s own mechanics. What you can’t do are as meaningful to the story as what you can, and it’s always interesting to see a game that uses its mechanic as a story-telling device.
      But one of its more captivating traits is, without a doubt, how real it feels and why. One of the things that made me fall in love with a lot of independent games is that many times the histories told in them feel real because they ARE real. The feelings the character experiences feel real because they were felt by the team who wrote them. I saw and sympathized for the protagonist’s suffering, and cried in joy because of the battles they won against depression, because you can see the suffering and you can see the battles in each of those lines. And the game is made not to entertain, but to share stories and raise awareness about an illness that haunts many across the globe. It just… Hits Differently.
          I will not lie, it’s not an easy and joyful ride. Sometimes we find in games a way to escape real life and its horrors, and it is not easy to play through a game that makes you remember feelings you wish to forget and feel pains you’ve never felt before. But it’s of the utmost importance that games like this get made in my opinion, so we know what we run from when we’re trying to escape reality, and to better understand pains that we might never feel, but that are very real.

So if any of what I said makes it sound like you'd hate this game, that's fair. Just don't play it.

Unless of course you only want to play this game to justify the judgments you've already made about it based off of internet conspiracy theories, in which case, what are you waiting for? The game succeeds at what it is meant to do, which is to provide an insight into what it's like to live with depression. I'd say it does this pretty well. Some may disagree; everyone experiences depression differently, so naturally this is not going to provide an experience that all depressed people can relate with.

I want more games like this. Not necessarily about depression, but games in general that push past the traditional ideas of  what games are for.

62625375.review:
Update: After some insistence from some commentators, I've decided to play some more. My updated thoughts will be at the bottom of the review.


Depression Quest expertly puts you in the shoes of a person suffering from depression; I've been playing for five minutes and I want to fucking die already.



This "game" is a joke. It doesn't go much further than "You have depression. You have no energy to do anything. Isn't that horrible?", oversimplifying depression to an extent not unlike the one commonly seen in more mainstream media, where depression is portrayed as "You're sad, everything sucks, boo boo". The saving grace in those cases is that the story typically isn't all about depression, and that it's usually somewhat enjoyable. Depression Quest has none of those saving graces. I'd say its only saving grace is being free, but even without having paid anything for it, I want a refund. A refund of my time, my precious five minutes that never will come back, that is.

If you're curious about it for the memes, feel free to try it out, but you probably won't get much from it. Like, at all. In fact, you'll probably end up losing.


Updated thoughts:

So, I kept being told that the game gets better, and I figured that even if my first five minutes playing this game were so awful that it made me never want to play again, five minutes probably isn't enough to offer a review. So I booted it up again. For context, I'm a writer, and I have depression, so I think I know what I'm talking about here, to some degree.

My first playthrough went something like this: I booted up the game, and being no stranger to visual novels, which this feels closest to, I tried to get in character. Wasn't hard, since the game pretty much forces you to. At the beginning, if you choose any other option other than the 'depressed' one, you're told no and sent back to choose, this time with the option you chose crossed out. I ended that playthrough in about five minutes, my character completely drained out and unable to do anything, all the options crossed out. And I felt the same, which is why I wrote that review.

This time, I decided to try to play in the "correct" way, trying to choose the options that would help my character whenever possible. The game gives you some context at the beginning, with highlighted words that you can click on for an explanation of who these people are, likely to help you get in character.

So I kept playing, choosing every option that seemed 'social' or like it would help MC. Often I wasn't given much of a choice, the amount of options that get crossed out can get to as many as five out of six, but even when it's not that bad, it often results in a 'right' and 'wrong' answer. 

"You're in X social situation, what do you do? 

A: [strike]Go out with your friends, be happy[/strike]

B: [strike] (Reluctant) Go out with your friends [/strike]

C: Explain to your friends why you're depressed

D: Do nothing, stay home, suffer"

I'm paraphrasing for the sake of the example, but this should give you a rough idea of how the game gets at times.

Personally, I believe this might have been done to make you feel cornered, like you feel when, y'know, you have depression, but the result still is that many options are there more as a formality than to actually provide anything.

There's a constant reminder in static-filled boxes at the bottom of every screen, of how you're feeling and whether you're taking medications or going to therapy. I guess so you don't forget that you're depressed? Though again, the whole atmosphere of the game contributes to making you feel like shit.

There are also some errors in the writing, off the top of my head I can think of [b]"You pass by a blue Camero and jump as it beeps at you, causing you to jump in surprise"[/b]. 
So I was so startled I jumped, and then my jump surprised me and I double-jumped? I jest, but it's something to take into consideration whenever you're writing.

For another example, at one point the option to say nothing in a conversation was labeled "Notice that your hands are shaking", which makes me wonder if this person was willingly ignoring their hands. I feel like simply labeling it "Say nothing" and [i]then[/i] in the resulting text screen describing MC's hands shaking would've worked better. The game is filled with these "show, don't tell" problems. 

Without any ill-intentions to the game's writer, most of it honestly reads like a teenager's fic where they try to present a depressed character, not so subtly trying to convey the message that they are the character and they're the one who's depressed. It's full of little issues you'd expect from a teenager writing their first short story for a school assignment.

...I mentioned before that the game excels at making you [i]feel[/i] depressed. It might've come off as sarcasm, and it mostly was, but the whole experience is very draining. It's true what the warning at the beginning says, so if the intention of the developer was to make you feel like shit while playing, they really accomplished that. 

But what I noticed in this second playthrough is that after a while, the game really manages to get you in character. You begin ignoring the top-most choices on your own, because you know they're the ones that are crossed out and thus inaccessible. But at one point, which I think is genius if it was intended, you're given the option to take medications. And that's what sparked me to come write all of the above, because all the options are available, but I didn't feel like taking it. I [i]know[/i] that's the right choice, but I still don't want to take it. I was basically conditioned throughout the whole playthrough to reject the top-most choice, so now I find myself rejecting it entirely on my own.

...Maybe I'm projecting myself too much, who knows. Everyone will have a different experience. Do I recommend this game? Ehh.... Still no. It has some really clever moments but it's still pretty dull. Fittingly for "an interactive (non) fiction about living with depression", everything in the game is made to wear you out and get you in character, which comes its detriment. It's an unpleasant experience. Think about it, to provide a comparison, as Darkest Dungeon. That game is not shy about wasting your time grinding for a character only to have them die and make you do the same with a new character. Thematically, it works wonders. As a game... it gets boring. It's the same with this one. Everything about it reinforces the depressing atmosphere, which is perfect for a story about depression, but unsurprisingly drives people away. I mentioned it briefly in the comments, but there really isn't any indication that the game will get better. It just happens as you play. You have to take a leap of faith and hope it will be worth it at the end. That's wonderful as an analogy for depression, but awful if you just want to play a visual novel.

I don't know who the person who made the game is, from browsing other reviews it's clear that there was [i]some[/i] drama, but I've avoided even acknowledging that until now, because I think the work deserves to be judged aside from the author. 

I don't know and I don't care if I'd respect this author as a person, but after giving this another shot, even if I still don't like it, I can say for certain that I respect the work just a little more.

59933032.review: I don't know exactly how I feel about this one. I saw myself way too much in the protagonist, and this really hurts. I don't think I have depression, I've been seeing a therapist for almost a year and she never said anything near it, but seeing that depression can work like this is hurtful as it can go unnoticed, but, at the same time it can bring awareness, I felt there isn't intensity enough to something as bad as depression can be. Also, despite the message at the end, I feel like the game gives the player a "right" or "wrong" path depending on what you choose[spoiler], like when you decide whether or not to start taking medication and choosing not to take it affects you negatively. Not all treatment is done nor should be done with medicine and sometimes people can totally make it without this step that can really affect you in a bad way if not thought carefully about[/spoiler]. It also makes it seem like an active social life is crucial in order to make someone happy. I mean, yeah, having a solid supply net is awfully needed and great, but that doesn't mean you have to be an active kind of person. I missed the game bringing the importance of knowing how to spend time with yourself [spoiler](yeah, I know the protag spends most of his time alone, but is mostly trying to deal with depression rather than getting to know himsef or learning how to properly appreciate his own company)[/spoiler], which not only is the most important thing, but for some people it can be key as they can really value their time alone. A game can't do everything, and despite it's flaws, it's still a nice and thoughtful enough attempt on portraying depression.

59813121.review:
I have been diagnosed with moderate to severe depression for 4-5 months now, but I do believe it was developing for about 2 years. I'm in therapy for it and have been on and off medication. From the standpoint of someone who has actually gone through the mental illness this game is depicting, I recommend it. 

While at times it did feel that it was showing depression to be something "easy" to overcome, I strongly feel that no game can accurately present a real life mental problem. This game stated multiple times that it is a very hard struggle, and had a lot of events that I could really relate to. I don't believe the game was depicting depression to be "just being lazy" at all.

The game said many, many times through the play through that it was due to a lack of motivation, the same way I usually describe it. It's the feeling of lacking any hope for the future or want to do...well, anything. That's not being lazy to me. I really believe that this game, while maybe not being the BEST interpretation of depression, did it's job well. Once again, no game can truly represent how depression really is, but this game did it well enough with the kind of game and short play time that it had. I fully recommend it.

I can see why this receives as many sarcastic reviews regarding the topic it covers. After all, sarcasm is too often used as a defense mechanism. Not to forget the plethora of flat out hateful reviews from gamergate bros who have an agenda against the developer and whoever else they may categorise as "feminazis." 

It wouldn't be surprising if some of the excessive hatred towards this game is a form denial of the deep suffering and (self-)hatred that leads groups (or mobs) like this to band together to harass people they don't know. It might also be hard to understand, relate or appreciate if you don't have depression, not to deny the fact that someone could dislike this game and have depression. Most importantly, everyone has a unique experience with depression despite similarities found in different experiences, and the game distinctly acknowledges this before it starts.

I'm not sure how much I'm looking forward to playing this again and trying out the endings that aren't optimistic, since the choices I made I myself would struggle with achieving in in real life, but I'm glad I experienced it.

There is a plague on this world that affects entire nations of people. It tears apart families and friends. It ruins lives and removes any form of hope from people afflicted by it. It turns life into a mud pit that is ever increasingly difficult to get out of. That's Depression.


Then there is the creator of Depression Quest. A person that has committed so many acts of horrible misdeeds that is incredible to think that she isn't classified as a terrorist. The creator has harassed a suicidal man with accusations of assault and rape until the man's own families believed her and he had nowhere to go and committed suicide. She has used and abused her employees for free labor with promises of future payments and then withheld those payments and fired the workers to pay for her vacations.
 Ruined organizations and their charity events that supported feminist movements and health focused charities because they didn't fit her agenda. Told innocent people to cover up her tracks or they would be targeted as well and took bribes from others for pushing people around.

I forgot all of this happened, because each time the creator has decided to hide her face in social media until it all blows over. I forgot until I saw a particular phrase the other day:

Five Guys Burgers And Fries.

58284508.review:
With a game as infamous as this one, going in with an objective and clear mindset was tough, especially with all the mixed reviews, but I tried my best. And while the game has some interesting ideas like crossing out options that someone with depression might not be able to force themselves to say/do, the game is kind of boring overall. Choices don't feel like they have much weight. the bland interface makes me feel more like I have ADHD than depression, since there was nothing to really hold my interest or attention besides forcing myself to finish the game.
Realistically, this game probably didn't take much time to make, or it doesn't seem like it. If you want a fun and interesting free to play visual novel, Doki Doki Literature Club surprised me with how great it was, so I'd say try that.

58184950.review:
I have mixed feelings about this "game", it's very upfront in it's way of conveying a story while at the same time being very uncomfortable with the truth.

• Uses old-school text adventure mechanics, with mouse input.
~ It has controller input surprisingly enough, however the games immersion I feel is better with mouse. It's a matter of preference really, both function well.
+ Has a very well told and strong story, relying on the players ability to relate to it.
+ Samples music from free sources in it's own unique way.
+ It's nice to know that the developer offers the option to pay-what-you-want, with the revenue going to charity (checked their website).

57602217.review: It's scary how relatable this game is sometimes. It shows depression so well yet is never too pessimistic. I cannot recommend this game enough to people; it's an excellent showcase of what depression looks like and hey it's free and you'll probably beat it in about 40 minutes

57523195.review: This is a good game that shows the problem of depression. There is a lot of text, periodically you can choose an action, the end of the game depends on it. The state of the protagonist realistically describes depression and possible solutions.

57328585.review: we waiting for dlc turkish subtitle....

57203113.review:
This game made me feel really good. Living vicariously through the protagonist to get to a healthier place made me feel some things. As someone at risk for depression, I really appreciate this game.

EDIT: Risk has become reality babeyyy! Anyway, I played the game again today and... damn. It really do be like that. This game is a useful tool for both people trying to understand what depression is like, and for people who have it and don't see any way out. It oversimplifies a little bit, like the ease of getting on medication (from the therapist you're already seeing as opposed to having to find a psychiatrist who's super overbooked and god it's been like 2 years since I started wanting meds and I still don't have anything). That oversimplification is okay, though, bc it makes it a reasonable option instead of just paralyzingly difficult. It is possible to get better, even if it never really goes away.

57158541.review:
Would I recommend this game to other players?  Yeah.  Sure.  Screw it.  Why not?  The "game" or narative, or choose your own adventure is about a guy who is depressed but sure seems to have a lot of support in the form of friends, family, and a lady friend.  I could not help but think that the character you "Play" has it a whole lot better than I.  He's got friends.  He's got a girlfriend.  He's got a mom and pop.  He doesn't seem to have a full blown drug addiction nor does he have people in his life that are not happy when he is unhappy, and are not happy when he is happy.  He doesn't seem to have people in his life that purposefully prey on his weaknesses and conspire to keep him in a sorry state, nor does he have soulless non-human but human looking drug dealers that do everything in their power to keep him strung out and lacking anything remotely resembling dignity or self esteem.  His Girlfriend in the game seems to be helpful enough..and he certainly doesn't have a female in his life that has marked him long ago as the weakest in the herd who does her level best to destroy any ideas of self worth or independence from her or his current situation, using a combination of sex, guilt, drugs, and gas lighting to slowly eat away at the remaining anchors that keep him grounded in sanity and on this planet in general.  He has a job and income and things that belong to him that he bought with is own money.  He has friends that seem to care about him, not simply a collection of people that wormed their way into his trust so that they could steal from him, feel better than him, talk shit behind his back, tell lies about him for fun, and make it more or less impossible to for him to get a fair chance at much of anything in the area where he "lives"....However, I suppose the point of this "game" is that he has every reason to feel well adjusted and loved, but he simply does not.  And this is an aspect of Depression.  You don't know why you are like this you just are.  It came into your life with such subtlety that you are not sure if there was ever a time you -didn't- feel this way.  Meanwhile the same tropes seem to follow you where ever you go, "Cheer up."  and "Suck it up" and "Quit being such a drama queen".  All you know for certain is that you annoy people.  They genuinely don't like you and you genuinely do not like you.  One more hit, one more shot, one more pill, it doesn't matter.  It's all going to be over soon....

Life has a way of kicking you in the balls or punching you in the tittys when you are at your worst and at your lowest.  We never really get over anything.  We just learn to live with whatever it is that is trying to break us apart.  To all those suffering from this Chronically Acute Disease, you do not suffer alone but sometimes reaching out to someone only serves to illustrate how far gone you are.    You deserve to feel better, however.  You deserve to have a genuine, heartfelt smile, not just something you put on for others so they wont feel upset in your presence.  It is not going to be easy...it takes great strength to get help.  It takes even greater strength to change aspects of yourself that are entrenched with age or comfort.  But you are capable of turning this around.  You are not alone in your feelings.  There may be somebody out there that suffers as you do that you can help, and in so doing you may find that you are helping yourself by helping someone else.
