55325846.review:
An awful lot of text for a game, but probably the best free thing I've found on Steam so far and often relatable personally. 
I think in my first attempt I ruined everything by interpreting one possible answer in a way that wasn't intended ([spoiler]notice that my hands are shaking - I thought that would send me in a panic and make things worse[/spoiler]). After that, I was left with only one possible answer per situation, i.e. there weren't any choices I could make and the outcome was pretty gloomy. When I replayed with the choice I first thought would be a bad idea, things worked out much better. 

This game might be for you if... [list]
[*]You'd like to gain some insight into how depression "works" for some (!) people
[*]You've struggled with depression yourself and would like to feel validated and less alone
[*]You're wondering if you might be depressed, maybe [/list]

This game might not be for you if... [list]
[*]Descriptions of depression or some other people's reactions to it could drag you down or trigger you [/list]

* * *

For more non-violent games, check out my/our new Curator, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35872486/]Peaceful Adventures and Stories[/url]!

54007364.review:
I really liked this game.  I suffer from depression and when I first started I instantly related to it.  Especially at the beginning it read exactly the same as I felt a year ago.  This raised my anxiety somewhat.  However once I started getting into it and making decisions I felt it was very affirming of the decisions I had made in the last year.  

So I recommend the game, but with caution, if you have just recently started suffering from depression I would not advise it.  Go to a therapist instead!  Best decision I ever made.  

If you don't have depression but know someone who does or are just interested in learning more about it, then please do play the game.  It is a fairly realistic story of what it feels like to be suffering from depression and the feelings and choices that go along with it.

[u] Gameplay [/u]
Depression Quest is a 2013 interactive fiction game dealing with the subject of depression.The game tells the story of a person suffering from depression and their attempts to deal with their affliction. It was created to foster greater understanding about depression. Depression Quest can be played for free, and has a pay-what-you-want pricing model.

Please don't play this game if you're suffering from depression or anxiety this could trigger your state, I wouldn't even recommend it if you're light hearted. I use the term "game" very lightly in this scenario due to it only being text driven and no save option (which lead to me not finishing this).

50748932.review:
Depression Quests is an interactive story about someone with depression. It was released on the 11th of August 2014. 

The concept is simple. The story unfolds and you have to make choices during the game. The choices affect the mental health of the player character. Certain choices are dependent on your mental health. This is done to simulate the effect of depression. 

The story is good, and the writing is good most of the time. There were a few instances of corny writing but they are few enough not to hinder the overall story.

The game is free, so I would say go for it. It will give you an idea of what it’s like to live with depression and how hard it is to make the right choices. It won’t be 100% accurate but it will give you a better idea. Just don’t play it when you are struggling with depression since it can be triggering.

50526169.review:
To start off with, this game made myself question a lot of things. It made me hesitate to preform certain actions, and put me in a position where I couldn't choose either outcome. 

Everything was crafted beautifully, from the dialogues, to the storytelling, to the music, and to the narrative. I appreciate all of the developers' effort and hard work, because it really paid off. 

This game's atmosphere is very dark. I do not suggest this game to people with a light heart, or anyone that faces Anxiety, Depression, or any related disorders. This game is meant for more mature audiences, so play at your own risk.

I thank the developer(s) and anyone else that helped craft this piece of art. I very much enjoyed the experience, and I'm glad I had the opportunity to review this game.

49568095.review: Well what do you know! Maybe Grust, the founder of Crappy Games Wiki and all other reception wikis, is right after all. Depression Quest is one of the worst games i have ever played in my life. There is very little "gameplay", just clicking on some choices that affect some storyline about an other who has depression and must do something for some reason. Even the game states that it is not meant to be fun. In fact, it is not a game, it is just a choose-your-own adventure quest. If the developer Zoe Quinn is going to make a game about depression, at least put something that can be remotely fun. Fun can lead to happiness, you know and happiness can be a cure for depression if done correctly. As for the story, well the whole story is just a boring young adult drama about an other who has depression as stated above, and is not at all happy. Also, there are multiple paths, but there is no ending because according to the game, there is no neat resolution to depression. Why? Who cares. What about the music? The music is just one somber piano loop that never stops with some occasional sound effects like the chattering at the party. Now there is one redeeming quality to this game and that is the fact that Depression Quest is completely free to play. You can play it free as charge so that you can suffer through this depressing game. In conclusion, this "game" is one of the worst and I can imagine people playing this game and getting even more depressed after they are done. If you want to play it, do it at your own risk.

48969977.review:
You may know of this interactive novel thanks to the enormous controversy surrounding its primary author. I'm going to pretend that controversy doesn't exist, and try to be as objective as possible in my assessment of it as a [i]game[/i]. But right off the bat, let's just get a quick subjective/cheeky review out of the way, if only to remove such temptations from my system...

   Depression Quest: Lives up to its title. Depressing as heck. (Though not entirely devoid of hope.)

   Okay, on with the more serious review.

   There's no denying there's some quality here. It's well-written - always a good thing for a game almost entirely reliant on [i]words[/i] - and the music and atmos sounds are very effective. I'm certainly going to "recommend" it: because of said quality, the fact that your choices really [i]do[/i] matter, and because it's FREE. That said...

   I would be very wary regarding [i]who[/i] I would recommend this game to. Me: I like melancholic art. Especially when it has some degree of catharsis, which this does; at least if you choose the slightly more proactive decisions offered to you throughout the game. Which is, granted, a potentially inherent flaw in the game's design from the word "go", as my understanding of "depression" is that it's something that doesn't exactly encourage proactive behaviour. That said...I played through once being proactive, and once being as negative as I could possibly manage, and both outcomes seemed sufficiently believable in and of themselves.

   Let me slap a bit of personal context on this. I myself was diagnosed with depression about a decade ago, and decided a couple of years later to wean myself off the medication. I've been largely fine ever since, so whether I was ever genuinely "depressed" or just going through a particularly bad patch - following a break-up and half-arsed suicide attempt - is anyone's guess. I'm a pretty resilient type on the whole, and have a tendency to actively seek out art that [i]confronts[/i] me. If you're not that kind of person: STAY. THE. HECK. AWAY. There's every chance this [i]won't[/i] be a cathartic experience for you; quite possibly the opposite. I see plenty of reviews joking that this product might push you towards suicide, but believe me...they're only [i]barely[/i] joking! This is not "fun" or lighthearted stuff, to say the least.

   But it [i]is[/i] genuinely artistic, and is genuinely well-done (aforementioned reservations about proactivity aside). Just know what you're getting yourself in for. If you're still on the fence, I'd happily recommend Tomorrow Don't Come as an alternative: it's shorter, closer to a regular "game", and more guaranteed to deliver a cathartic experience. I can't stress enough that I'm only recommending Depression Quest to those who don't demand to be "entertained" by each and every game that they play. 

   Don't say I didn't warn ya!

Verdict: 8/10.

(PS If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my two Curator pages: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9284586-ReviewsJustfortheHELLofit/​
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10868048-Truly-Horrible-Horror-Games/?appid=398210​
Cheers!)

48468350.review:
I know that different people experience depression differently, but as my personal opinion, I'd say this is a reasonably accurate portrayal of the atmosphere of feeling down about one's life as an unwanted aura weighing oneself down for an extended period of time.  This simulation is rather short, of course, and can be completed in one sitting, so it obviously won't have the full weight of an actual personal experience, but it does use interface elements in a few key ways to serve this purpose:

* It is entirely text-based.  If you were here for a video game, no, sorry, the most you get are some still photos of stuff.  The way you play this game is, thus, "boring" and dull, but that's actually fitting and evocative of such an experience.  (The repetitive, slow, dour music reinforces this slow-moving yet oppressive aura, Meanwhile, the writing is appropriately descriptive of this aura and of how a lot of seemingly mundane and sometimes even enjoyable activities feel like a chore to approach.)
* The visual style is just words on a grey background.  This style is similarly "boring".  (There are some colors, of course, but when life is glum it's still not consistently glum either anyway.)
* The most important interface element that I appreciated is that, when the game offers you choices at decision points, it often scratches out (and makes unchoosable) the ones that would "make the most sense".  They represent things you can think about doing, the kinds of things you "know you should" do, but just can't muster up the courage or will to make them happen.  This mechanic is an extremely apt portrayal of this phenomenon, in the form of an interface element.

The story in the game is only a snippet of life, and it's only a snippet of life of a person who isn't you and won't be entirely like you or anyone else.  However, it does have a variety of nuggets that make it relatable, in my opinion -- particularly the dour emotions and shackled outlook that come with such an experience in one's own life.

Note: The controversies related to the developer are a thing I don't care about, and my review has nothing to do with them, aside from the fact the hullabaloo surrounding the controversy actually caused me to discover this game.

Disclosure: I got this game for free on Steam, because, well, it's a free game on Steam.

48390667.review:
First of all, I didn't play this game with the idea that it will somehow help me, more out of curiosity tbh. At the age of 17 I've been diagnosed with chronic anxiety which later evolved into a full depression, so I am more than used to dealing with it. 
It came out quite surprising, to see how much I could relate to the protagonist, knowing that while it's a character, his thoughts were or are the thoughts of a real person. Of course, while I could identify myself with the protagonist, some people could not and it's okay, because even if depression has common points, not everyone is going through the same things. And this is a thing not many understand and criticize.
Because I could relate so much, I was able to get the good ending first. And it may come out as fake or whatever, but I was literally in the protagonist's shoes for most of the story. I too, saw therapists and took medication which both helped me in the end. And I made all the choices the way I did in real life. I'm not saying I got through with my depression, because as it was written in the end, you don't really "cure" depression. It's a thing you will probably live with your entire life but you have to manage its effects.
In the end, what I wanted to say is that, while it's not really a game, I think the meaning of it is to help you better understand depression, in one of its forms, both for people dealing with it personally and people who have friends or relatives going through it. For those dealing with it, it doesn't magically fix your depression, but it shows that you are not alone and there are ways of improving your life. For those who have someone close who is dealing with it, it raises awareness and helps you empathize so that you can be an effective help for them.
I think the developers did a really good job, I don't see why some people blame them and it saddens me when I read mean comments coming especially from people who claim they are depressed. Again, this game is not meant to fix your depression and I don't see how one would take it that way from the very begining. While I don't question whether or not you are trully suffering from depression, I think that keeping an open mind and not taking a defensive stance would help you better your condition and ultimately, your life. Anyway, that is what I did and it helped me a lot. However, I understand that this may come as a rather difficult thing to do for some people. I know this because my mother was once depressed too, didn't want to acknowledge that, her depression later turned into schizophrenia and OCD (from which my therapist told me), ultimately culminanting in her suicide. This is why I wanted to tell you that at least from my point of view, keeping an open mind in all of this is very important because a behaviour contrary to that is what makes a tiny snowball turn into an avalanche.
All in all, I hope all of you who read this are well (as much as possible) and are making progress in your life. Just remember, little steps are more important sometimes than bigger ones and have patience with yourself.

48230239.review:
[b][h1]A brief description:[/h1][/b]
[i]Depression Quest[/i] is a text-based story-telling experience about living with depression. As you go through the story, you will make choices for the narrator. Should he call his girlfriend and tell her how he's been feeling, or should he just go to bed? [i]Depression Quest[/i] can be played through in about 30 minutes or less, assuming you read every page in full. 

[b][h1]Why I [b]do[/b] recommend it:[/h1][/b]
Even when you choose all the choices you believe are "right," the game doesn't always give you the best or happiest options the next time you have to make a choice. I love that they do this because it is an accurate representation of depression. Everything is exhausting, everything is hard, and the negative feedback loops are nearly impossible to escape from. I particularly liked one choice I had to make partway through the game, after having chosen all the "best" responses up to now, where the character is clearly still experiencing the full brunt of his depression. He can't sleep one night, and the game asks, "What do you do?"

1. Force yourself to sleep.
2. Go to bed. It shouldn't be that hard.
3. Just close your eyes and let it happen. Why won't your thoughts back off for five seconds?
4. Snap out of it. What is wrong with you? Why can't you stop stressing out for five seconds?
5. You're probably going to go into work tomorrow exhausted and fuck everything up and get fired.
6. Go to your computer. Sleep is clearly not happening no matter how long you lay here. 

Seeing as numbers 1-5 are actually marked out with a red line in the game, you are only given one actual response option you can choose (#6). Options 1-5 show the negative and self-loathing thoughts a depressed person may be experiencing all at one time while trying to come to a decision. I love how authentic the game is in its portrayal of depression (and, in my opinion, a sprinkling of generalized anxiety on top of it all). Depression does not let you make choices easily, or sometimes [i]at all[/i]. The fact that the game occasionally doesn't give you an option to truly make your own choices just adds to its authentic representation of depression.

[b][h1]The Good:[/h1][/b][list]
[*] Excellent representation of depression
[*] You are given the opportunity to actually get help for the main character. I think it would be too sad if I couldn't have some kind of happy ending for him, even if it would fit with the theme of the game.
[*] Short playthrough
[*] Free
[/list]

[b][h1]The Bad:[/h1][/b][list]
[*] It's possibly in danger of portraying depression as an easily solvable puzzle if you just get yourself a pet, therapist, and drugs. While it does a great job of showing the experience of depression, I'm a little concerned what the takeaway might be for players who have never experienced it. 
[/list]

47515466.review:
((TL;DR: [b]have empathy, will travel[/b] - this is not 100% your story, this is this protagonist's perspective)))

This is an excellent depiction of depression for those who have trouble with empathy, as it demonstrates, through a vivid and well written story, how crushing it can be to feel such intense emotions.

I reccomend this game for people who do not suffer from depression, as it assists in explaining new perspectives, and also for those who have also suffered from depression - this helps as a representation of how you are not alone in your struggle, and helps place those convoluted emotions into defined words and set statuses as opposed to a cacophony of diluted introspection.

Everyone has a unique experience with depression, and thus Depression Quest is not going to be a 100% parallel to everyone's own unique expression - this does the best it can to highlight the cornerstones of being in a depressive state, and does it fairly well.

45585946.review:
Some people were just complaining about how this game wasn't fun, was a waste of their time and how this game didn't help their depression etc.

 I really don't get why people like this are even playing this game. You can simply play something much more fun or hang out with your friends instead of wasting your "Important" time on writing a bad review on a game. And for the actual depressed people playing this game, thinking that it will help their depression; Look dude, this not a game for you. It is a game for the people who have empathy, a little free time and some patience in them (By which, I mean people around you that want to help you but don't really know how it feels to be in depression.) and it really isn't a game at all, it is a simulation to raise awareness and make people emphatize when they see someone depressed. I only wasted an hour on this game and did only 1 run and reached the good ending. However, my depressed friend played this (And he is the only reason i played this game) and he got a game over in like 15 minutes (Source: he told me that) just because he played the game like it's actually real life. To get a good ending you need to think like the protagonist, feel like the protagonist and think of the outcomes when you are making decisions. If a depressed person plays this they will get a bad and depressing ending like 80% of the time. My run wasn't the greatest and it certainly wasn't the worst one. Surely, one time I almost lost the game. But i knew that it would be fine if i just moved on. And that is exactly what the game tells us in the end of the good ending:

"Instead of a tidy ending, we want to just provied a series of outlooks to take moving forward. After all, that's all we can really do with depression - just keep moving forward. And at the end of the day it's our outlook, and support from people just like you, that makes all the difference in the world.       Thanks Again"

You are probably asking; "why did this random guy on the internet spent time on a stupid review?"
 That's because I get triggered when I see people criticizing a game unfairly. You can't criticise a game if you don't undertsand it's story,characters and (sometimes) the lesson that the game teaches us. If you criticise a game without having a general understanding of these three. it would not be fair. It's like judging a fish by it's ability to climb a tree! It's just stupid. 

 Also, this game is not perfect. It has flaws just like any other game. And it is also not fun at all, it's mostly reading text and trying to understand the plot to make good decisions.

 To sum up, this wasn't a review of Depression Quest. THIS was a review of the REVIEWS of Depression Quest and if you managed to read all of this without being bored. Instead, trying to undertsand my point then you will probably get the good ending in this game. Anyways thanks for spending time on reading this review. (Edit: grammar)

44925922.review:
It's overall a much narrower view of dealing with depression in your every day life as a whole, the way depression manifests itself is very broad and varies from person to person, but it's enlightening and needed to have something that caters to a niche; those seeking some form of awareness to the issue and those looking for a game that validates their experiences. 

I was the latter when I found this game. Living with depression is messy, makes your whole world seem upside down and you feel as if you don't have the means to make it right side up again. Things just never seem to go right, you feel unfocused and unmotivated, like your life is a broken record always on repeat and there's nothing that will let you skip ahead to the happy ending you wish so dearly for. 

Still, although this is but a taste of the every day life of someone who struggles with depression, it is a good portrayal. It shows the impact, not only on yourself emotionally and physically, but on those around you. Your friends, significant others, family... they all feel the weight of your change, even if you try so desperately to hide it. 

Depression is scary in the sense that sometimes you do get over it... great, it's lovely and uplifiting... but some of us never truly do, it's chronic, ever overshadowing every facet of our lives. Sometimes people understand, sometimes they don't, but it's your journey, and you have to keep moving forward. 

Definitely recommend, just keep in mind it isn't representative of how everyone with depression feels or acts.

43784084.review:
Short version: It's free, it takes an hour to finish, it's well written and very sincere. It's not meant to completely encapsulate depression from every angle or perspective, only to present one side of it and start a conversation from there. Definitely worth trying out.

I'm a little late to the party, but originally it was confounding to me that this, an hour long text adventure, of all games, would cause such an uproar as it did a few years ago. It's such a sincere attempt at communication regarding dealing with depression, an issue that no sane human being would choose to be on the other side of. At the same time, in a weird way, the passionate reactions make sense. There are many ways to approach the scenario in the game. You can see it as an outsider trying to sneak a peak at what some people go through, who can't really relate to the situation but will hopefully come out of it having learned something new about the human condition. You could be someone like me, who is going through depression and finds some close aproximations in the game to experiences of my own, even if they don't line up completely. Or maybe you're someone who's going through a carbon copy of the game's bleak scenario. Either way, if you're willing to fully commit to the hour or so that it takes to play through it, you'll come out with some sort of strong reaction. Some people will appreciate the feeling of vulnerability and exposure the game asks of you, a feeling that's typically a prerequisite to the start of any conversation about a serious topic. Some people will be offended that a videogame dared to try to get them out of their shell and get them to feel. Some will dismiss the game completely. Every emotional reaction is valid. What's inexcusable is taking this reaction and letting it manifest as insults to the game's creators in the forms of sexism, misogyny, or worst of all, violence. Obscene reactions like that are how conversation is stifled, and very real issues, like the fight against depression, go undealt with. This game is a work of art that's meant to start a conversation, and I'd encourage anyone with a passing curiosity to give it a try. It's free, and it takes about an hour or less to finish. If you can't relate to the game, let that be the end of it. If you can relate, then first of all, I'm sorry. Depression is rough, and it certainly takes a toll. Second, if you feel like having a conversation about depression, which was this game's intent, don't be afraid to reach out. You're not alone.

Playing this game showed me that you can talk about stigmatized subjects like mental health without having years of experience developing video games. I’ve always enjoyed writing, and this game motivated me to start making Twine stories about my experience with bipolar disorder. 

If you or someone you know suffers from depression, playing this game might give you a deeper understanding of what goes on in a depressed person’s mind.

With a bit of research you'll soon find that this game has received its fair share of media coverage as well as praise from popular video game blogs and pundits. Such dishonest promotional reviews are there just to show you that they respecc wahmen. 

If anything, the game is far from depicting actual depression. What the MC is going through is what everybody who has a job/goes to college experiences on a daily or weekly basis ([b]STRESS AND ANXIETY[/b]). Also the piano is distracting, loud, unnecessary and out of touch. Am I reading a kid's story about "depression" or is this about the melancholic journey of some gay vampire?

People who think they are depressed (like the main character) are, in reality, afflicted by two prevalent disorders that tend to complicate matters even further:  [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_distortion]cognitive distortion[/url] and  [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factitious_disorder_imposed_on_self]Munchausen syndrome[/url]. Be sure to read  [url=https://psychcentral.com/lib/15-common-cognitive-distortions/]15 Common Cognitive Distortions[/url].

The writing is also shallow and relies heavily on the thesaurus. You'll come across several instances of bad punctuation, too many unnecessary adjectives, and awkward sentence structure. It's obvious that the writer added more words than necessary just to increase the word count; some stupid mentality they still retain from their high school days. 

[h1]Here are some silly sentences I came across that made no sense at all.[/h1]

• You are a mid-twenties human being (huh?)

• You are also dealing with motivation issues that sometimes makes dealing with these things difficult

• Without realizing even what you've been doing

• Feeling at once encroached upon and shielded by being quite literally swallowed by it

• There's a second of silence over your phone, but you can swear you can hear the sound of your partner's face fall

• Since you know it's been a while since she's gone out with friends, but the efforts feels futile since you know that she isn't going to go without you

• Sit in comfortable, almost contented silence watching old shows (???)

• She leans into ask a question 

• You pass by a blue Camero and jump as it beeps at you, causing you to jump in surprise. It takes you a moment for to realize it

• The next morning, you check your email again with blurry eyesand mewing kitten (Written by a 5-year-old.)

• A tall woman in her mid 40's with a disarming demeanor and patient eyes with the start of the slightest smile lines 

• For now you're too foggy to do too much of any sort of thinking 

• While it's certainly not your dream job, you've always just sort of stuck it out out of necessity (I think they meant 'stuck to it')

• You've dragging your feet (forgot 'been'?)

• Your thoughts turned to all of the ways you feel like you're deficient at being a good person (WHAT???)

• Due to your schedules not lining up due to work and school

• You feel like you might be simply being insecure

• It states that [i]"Alex's apartment is a short walk away,"[/i] but as soon as Emo gets there, his girlfriend says: [i]"I'm so happy you came![/i] [b]I wasn't sure if you were going to make it! "[/b] — Well to be honest I had to take a sh*t earlier and the toilet seat greeted me in a similar fashion. Gee, quite the dramatic life, eh? 

[h1]Overuse of adverbs:[/h1]

• That you have been seeing exclusively for the past few months
• Can feel inwardly angry
• It's an unseasonably warm Wednesday evening
• You briefly consider using this serendipitous solitude
• She even drops a few suggestively worded hints
• She begins affectionately following you around
• You tentatively tell her
• It's a glaringly sunny Monday
• It is an utterly nondescript Wednesday afternoon (can you make this a tad more awkward, please?)

[h1]Cases displaying the writer's poor understanding of compound adjectives (include typos):[/h1]

• part time job (part-time*)
• under qualified (underqualified*)
• high paying (high-paying*)
• guilt tripped (guilt-tripped*)
• eying you nervously (eyeing*)
• a tall woman in her mid 40's (mid-40s*)
• videogames (video games*)
• laying across your bed (lying*)
• blind sided (blind-sided*)
• soul crushing (soul-crushing*)
• near weekly (near-weekly*) 

The segment where Emo's mother visits him was surprisingly well written despite a typo and a word missing ("You sigh heavily as you close the door behind her spend the next few hours  laying in bed, staring at the ceiling.") 

Using interactive fiction for educational purposes is a noble idea, but this one completely missed the mark.

43376689.review:
I did a single play through of this game a couple of years ago just as I was emerging from a deep depression and while everyones milage is different, there were distinct parts of the game that very strongly resonated with me. This isn't your run of the mill game for sure.

I would say that if you've not had depression and you can put yourself in someone elses shoes (since some of the options you get will not be things you may do personally) then you might get a feeling of what it's like to have depression and other mental health issues. From the static like audio that can quite quickly illicit a sense of anxiety, up to knowing what you should do, but being incapable of doing it, and the frustration and further emptiness that brings. 

Having had depression my whole life I liked that there were elements that I could see myself in. They feel to me like a reminder that you're not alone.

43054694.review:
Everyone, remember, the Dev may have friends, a good family, a job, and a girlfriend, but everyone has their struggles in life. Each person fights their own battles, and we should never judge anyone "not really having depression" because of their situation in life. You can be a millionaire and have clinical depression, remember that.

Besides all that, this game was amazing! I absolutely loved the game and all that it had, it may not be super long, but it tells the story in depth and is beautifully written. I have depression, and I feel this is a good representation of what the struggle is like. Every struggle is different, but this story is a good representation to the people who can relate in at least a semi-way. All and all, I find this story beautiful and empowering, and would recommend to people who don't have depression but know someone who does, so they can take a peek into their world. 10/10 replay-able.

42808682.review:
Okay, there's two things I want to say about this thing:
I've played it far back, when it was still just on the web. Went through the whole thing two or three times. I downloaded it on steam just so I could write this review:

1. It's a surprisingly good piece of interactive fiction. As a person with some issues of a similar kind, it hit me pretty hard, even made me cry at some point. It really knows what it's talking about, and it's really well done.

2. Which is why it's a huge pity that it's been made by a shit person who deserves no kind of publicity or support whatsoever, out of the sheer fact how colossally shitty the person is.

...and this is coming from someone who usually advocates for (and is able to) divorce a person from their creation(s), when judging.
But in this case, I cannot, in good conscience, to do so.

Yes, this thing is free. Yes, this thing is good.
Yes, I recommend you play it if you're even a bit interested.
But I URGE you to NOT get it on steam. Get it somewhere where your getting it won't add up to its "user/install base" count, to avoid promoting and/or giving any bit of legitimacy to its shitty creator.

42593345.review:
The fact that this is the game that started GamerGate cements it gaming history. Yet, had the controversy not started no one would have known about this game. 
It has a few spelling and gramatical errors, and since this is a "Choose Your Own Adventure" type reading game it shows more prominently. 
It delivers on its intention, to fictionalize a scenario of someone dealing with severe depression in a realistic way. 
It takes about an hour to complete.
Due to its length, no character is memorable or likable. The story is only there to illustrate the effects depression can inflict on an individual.
Background music and sound effects are pleasant and never steals attention away from the prose.
No glitches were found in my playthrough.
I would only recommend this game to those interested in mental illness or like short fiction.
Is it bad? No. Is it good? No. It really is a middle-of-the-road quality game and the ONLY reason anyone knows of it is due to GamerGate.

42338904.review:
Prior to playing this game (via the website), I read through some of the many negative reviews (given the political controversy). Strangely, many of them appeared to be obvious troll posts. Among those rated as the "most helpful reviews of all time," here are some recurring themes I noticed, and my thoughts on them after playing:

"This is an unrealistic and/or insulting portrayal of depression."
I am a doctor. I talk to people about their depressive symptoms. I prescribe anti-depressants and am familiar with their effects. I have also experienced depression first-hand. While no one story can hope to reflect everyone's unique personal experience of depression, this story is a satisfactory portrayal of the experience for many. It was particularly strange how one reviewer claimed to have formal education in depression and then criticised the game for veering into social anxiety rather than depression. As any medical student who showed up to the first lecture about depression should know, depression and anxiety disorders are so intimately linked that they are often inseparable.

"The choices either have no effect, or encourage negative behaviour."
To my surprise, when I played the game, the complete opposite was true. Perhaps the developer overhauled the game between these reviews and my playing, or the reviews are outright fabrications. When I deliberately chose options to lower my mood, certain subsequent options that would require a better mood became unavailable. I did the best I could to chip away at the oppressive weight, within the confines of limited options as a result of reduced mental resources (this is a realistic portrayal of a common experience). As a result of my choices, I was able to engineer drastically (within the bounds of realism) different endings. While some reviewers complained they they were unable to be magically cured by the ending, that's precisely the point; a journey with depression is often a chronic issue, marked by small incremental steps.

"The options to simply snap out of it were crossed out."
Again, this is precisely the point. The idea that one can simply "snap out of it" is a prevalent myth in society, born of ignorance and an ongoing cause of significant harm. To whine about this is to be part of the problem.

"The character's reasons for being depressed were not explained."
Again, precisely the point. The medical condition of depression does not need a reason. While depression can be precipitated by certain events, often there will be no reason apparent. See above point.

TLDR:
- The game does satisfactory job given the limitations of what it is and the enormous complexities of the subject matter tackled.
- A strangely high proportion of the negative criticism seems to range from obvious troll posts to brazen fabrications, possibly politically motivated.

40424295.review:
The same gamers that decry the presence of 'pay-to-win' micro-transaction purchases in their videogames are the same people who decry the presence of social commentary in their games. The implicit idea behind both of these positions is that video games exist as a form of escapism, to not have to contend with these kinds of issues 'for a change'. Wouldn't it be nice if a person from a racial or social minority group could expect to be able to do the same thing within video games? To not be reminded of their under-representation and how their perspectives aren't accounted for when a game is marketed and designed? The white male gamer seems to identify more with the main kind of social stratification they might recognize, which would be economic. A poor-middle class gamer doesn't want to encounter a 'rich' gamer who would be able to effectively bully them out of their fun in virtually every game an 'affluent player demographic' would frequent. No gamer wants any multiplayer game they play to feel like they're up against a boss from Dark Souls (obligatory reference) just because some user with a wingding username dumped a credit card balance into virtual items.  This is relatable to most anyone in the gaming community, regardless of personal background. Multiplayer games for most people are a place where people can unwind from a long day or week; Competitive player bases constituting only a minority of most multiplayer gaming communities. 

The idea that competition in games is required to be completely on level grounds is novel, but it is also untrue. This idea in conjunction with the escapist needs video games satisfy (for many) constitute two points of a line that this group of players draws between the 'real' world and the contrived worlds of video games. They seem to believe that the two worlds can be completely alienated, with the coincidental exception of economic stratification as a social issue in their games. Prominent speakers in the gaming media community have continually come out and spoke in unison against the presence of pay-to-win scenarios in recent major games releases (Such as EA's NBA2K18, Star Wars Battlefront 2 and Bungee's Destiny 2). From within the community, the syllogism for this seems only obvious and practical: 
'If it's not fun, no one's going to want to play it. 
So if you allow a pay-to-win scheme, the game will be less fun for most players and thus turn most of them off the game'. 

This truth is taken for granted, because it decontextualizes the natural realities of video gaming as an interest. There are financial, technological literacy, cultural, and physical barriers to entry in video gaming as a market, pass-time or culture. And gamers to a certain point don't have a problem with that, a large portion of them appreciate the sense of sub-cultural exclusivity and wear it as an indicator of identity.  There has been a crisis of identity in the past handful of years, as an internet culture war plays out into all subcultures of the internet. It wasn't that phenomenon like Gamergate was spontaneous acts of an aggressive subculture to a supposed feminist "agenda" in gaming journalism. The members of the Gamergate community were just haplessly unaware of the social context their movement had been fostered in. To them the "GameJournoPros" Watergate scandal overlooked the revenge content of a post of a scorned ex-partner.
Corruption in the video game industry comes in various forms: Paid reviews (which was the apparent 'larger problem' with Depression Quest being featured in indie game review articles), Advertisement and promotion deals for gaming journalist websites by game developers (Kane & Lynch Scandal covered by Larry Bundy), conflicts of interest between games journalists and game developers, award ceremonies or other business interests, and so on. So while the post detailed that there was indeed collusion between video games journalists and business interests: To the other subcultures of the web who were aware of other games 'scandals' (Drivergate, and so on) for a revenge post of a young man against a woman trying to promote a socially-positive game to be the straw that broke the camel's back, the culture of the movement had chosen a misogynist hill to die on. The corrupt journalists in question didn't need to contrive a false feminist narrative for other media to pick up, that was the honest perception of people who encountered this scandal along with other gaming scandals in the past that hadn't generated such cultural inertia. The profuse debates and conflicts both online and at gaming conventions turned a movement that began as a set of Twitter hashtags  into a set of tags for Twitter bots to silence accounts with. This drove gamers toward digging in their heels and identifying 'feminist agendas' as the problematic element used to encourage or pardon corruption in their industry, and with that came the constant derision of 'social justice' perspectives in video games. Even if the bulk of Gamergate-identifying members had been genuinely only interested in using the movement as a means to eye-poke gaming journalism for being corrupt (Such as TotalBiscuit, who took part while fighting cancer), what brought the revenge post to their attention initially were archives and screenshots of bitter mgtow members on 4chan who felt the need to propagate the post because it had been 'censored' on more reputable forums. Because the revenge post had picked up this kind of traction, people introduced to it as a 'smoking gun' piece of evidence were socially-informed of its supposed significance. The idea that journalists aren't allowed to or don't convene or speak to each other because that would somehow warp their profession is unseemly. Almost as unseemly as the accusations made against Quinn in the post itself, that somehow the allure of men who can potentially promote a free indie game was simply irresistible to her. The cultural backlash against Depression Quest for supposedly being the motive for this barely significant instance of corruption was immediate and long-lasting, and came to symbolize the kind of game corrupt videogame media would endorse as a form of political insulation. And with this gigantic unpacking of context, you have the social context of Depression Quest within the 'gaming' community. Its consistent 1.6/10 Metacritic score, overall negative Steam reception consist primarily of political commentary. This is despite a consistent smattering of recommendations for the game from self-reported depression sufferers on both platforms.  Taking all of this into account, I wanted to understand the approach Zoey took when creating the game at the heart of a vortex which managed to swallow up the likes of Richard Dawkins, Tim Schafer, and get considered a 'hatewatch' issue by the Southern Poverty Law Center. 
The profound irony at the heart of all this is that the social issue Depression Quest seeks to address is politically benign. Depression is a mental illness, and like most major categories of mental illness it does not discriminate along a person's social traits. What would the 'agenda' of producing a game that emulates some of the defining features of depression be? 
Having just completed a third play-through of the game, 
Thoughts: 
- The two things I found it did well; incidentally I questioned the deliberate intent behind. I didn't think the game was intentionally funny. 
- The character is a negative stereotyping of people with depression. An unlikeable socially anxious, self-absorbed and chronically dishonest person with no sense of tact. Even if you've suffered depression, identifying with this character seems to just signal the self-berating tendencies of depression. 
- It's not really a choose-your-own adventure because you rarely ever get presented with a choice. 
- The game ends abruptly with a very poor rationale for not writing the game a proper ending.

40313476.review:
[h1]Spreading Mental Health Awareness[/h1]

As someone dealing with anxiety and depression, this text-based game is spot on. Initially I thought it would be easy to get the guy in therapy and all that to get better, but then this game made me realize and remember how it actually feels like to be severely depressed.

[b]Game play: 5/10[/b]
The game is very text heavy, to the point I wonder why it has been made in a form of a computer game and not an online story, for example. It's not much of a game, to be honest. The mechanics, however, are well executed as is. Apart from this, playing the game really makes you know how depression works. It makes you frustrated. The main character doesn't have energy for everything, sometimes he just can't do something even if you previously chose the "right" thing to do, and that's the beauty; it's how depression works.

[b]Story: 7/10[/b]
The story follows a man with girlfriend, boring job and a loving family. The struggle with depression is real, as you encounter different kind of social encounters, and all that is very exhausting for the main character. The story can go to very different directions depending on how you guide the MC. The story feels real, but so far, all the stories have felt too short. I wish there would have been more. The story could be better, but it delivers the message.

[b]Over-all enjoyment 8/10[/b]
This is not a game to "enjoy" exactly, but it does make you feel sad and frustrated and, well, depressed. Which is the point here. I enjoyed playing this game, I've tried to take different routes for a few times and would still love to open more possible options and endings. I recommend this if you wish to know how depression feels like or are depressed and want to feel you are not struggling alone for a moment.

39143585.review:
This is a loaded game with a sorted history and I do want to say it might exist as a lovely reference point for certain people but I can not recommend it. The fact that it is out for free is admirable due to the very fact that it attempts to provide a perspective on depression. It is also from a non-heternormative and female perspective where most games are still bad about allowing for lens beyond that of a straight white guy. I also don't think it is necessary to say its not a game just because there is no combat or traditional video interface, it still deserves the moniker of a game even if I would call it a choose your own adventure like you may have read in a scary book growing up.

I have been a part of as a writer and a leader several sessions of workshops at the graduate and undergraduate level as well as some outside of a college setting. Something that I have often seen is someone present a work that is deeply personal to them but without the needed self honesty and reflection for it to be anything more than pretentious. What I mean is that they come with a work that they believe is perfectly profound and meaningful in such a way that is rarely seen and it goes over like a wet fart. It's not to say something personal can't be done or done well but this student film style pomp is the sign of something that is not done baking as a creative.

This is a story that was not critically looked at by someone who did not at some level feel it was profound. That or critical reads were not able to break through to either the writer or team. There is fat in the writing that could be cut. It ambles and is passive in such a way that to a degree would be alright and support the tone I think they were going for, but it ultimately does not accomplish this. Instead it feels without direction and character. I think there is nugget of an awesome story and idea in here just that it is entirely head on and literal with the material in such a way to feel like the freshman's poem not fully done baking. This is an example of telling over showing and after having looked at at multiple different paths in game I can say that characters come off as means to do or say something instead of fully fleshed out people. 

In a story beyond first draft you can't just state your story, themes and character. You need to cut and configure. You need to create create subtext and metaphor. The the lives your character s lead and the things they do need to exist for a reason beyond simply being simultaneously heavy-handed and vague reiterations of your points. You need to This mattered a lot to someone and as far as a I can tell all their darlings are alive safe and sound. For that I can not recommend this story but it is a nice sentiment if an early draft of one.

38994213.review:
If you're not terribly depressive, you should play this game. 

It's not very good, tbh, like a VERY short choose your own adventure game, but I see the core of a good game there. I can imagine a Depression Quest II made in RPG maker, or some Rouge-like procedurally generated isometric world, where you struggle to build up your self-worth, energy, while manitaining relationships, physical health, and surviving day to day. 

So, I can imagine a good version of this game concept, but that's not why I recomend it. If that was all it had going for it, I'd give it a thumbs down. But you can't talk about the Depression Quest without grappling with the meta-narrative around it, and if you are in any capacity a gamer (e.g. someone who genuinely enjoys playing lots of games, and possible enjoys the company of other people who do so as well), you kinda need to grapple with it. Part of that process is actually playing it. Is it good? I don't think so. Could it have been? Potentially, sure. Does it merit the hate? It's not like it's some sh*t asset flip, no. Could The Quinnspiracy make a good game in the future? I can't be sure, but I truely believe she has the capacity for it at least.

Anyway, you can't beat the price, and you'll finish it in under an hour probably. Give it a go. Then go play This War of Mine.

According to me, this game does not deliver what ir promises. However, narrative-wise (typos ignored), it is quite good although according to me the way to write what was written could have been different but maybe I am just not reading it properly as the writer intended. It does have a solid depression story though and the general idea is there and correctly depicting situations. However, personally I feel that there are some choices missing and consequences were under-played (maybe because me not being able to read as the writer would have wanted as I just mentioned). I also feel like some greyed out options could have been left open and other scenarios could have been written depending on your chracter's mood. Like for example, right now, depending on the mood you enter a scene, you have options available and I feel like more could have been enabled but with more disastrous consequences if your mood wasn't up for it. In short, I think this game lacks some depth (option and writing), but we are all entitled to our own opinions. I didn't want to write a review for this game at frist but then I thought I should because this game deserves to be played (even if I am not recommending it). Take it as a story, accept that your choices are only there to give you different possible outcomes and not to make you choose how the story develops and then feel good or bad about it later, and then it's enjoyable. This lack of depth and necessary state of mind to go through this is why I said it does not deliver what it promises and why I am not recommending it. It is nevertheless a good story, and I even played it twice to get a different outcome and see how it plays out, so I actually recommend it in a way if you know what you are getting into. This is actually quite short, took me exactly 96 minutes (yes, I get the joke) to get through it twice.

Also, if you want a similar game but way better in delivering what it stands for and with graphics, go check out Actual Sunlight. I played it on mobile a while back and it is way better but not free. And I also want to add that I have nothing to do with Actual Sunlight or anyone related (just your average consumer who played the game).

p.s. There is no save system. You will have to start over if you quit (not much of a problem if you remember your choices).

38103137.review:
Its not the best tool for teaching depression, but at least it helps somewhat. There are times in the VN that I think are just the MC dealing with depressing times than actual depression. And even when depression does hit, it doesn't carry the intensity of an actually depressive episode. Though decent with its idea, the game almost trivializes the weight of some depressive episodes. Like when during a bout of depression, are still given the option to call somebody or go outside, when in reality depression just saps everything from you that from personal experience, I just choose to sleep in.

I can understand the idea of the negative spiral, almost being on the receiving end myself if it weren't for intervention from the people around me and the understanding of some of my professors. Though the emphasis on how it truly feels to be in a depressive state isn't well done, the problems it poses when it comes to human relationships is definitely true. The episode where you just sleep in after work, and wake up to see missed calls, messages and just been unable to reply from exhaustion really is something that does occur. And depending on the individual, can range from a sense of emptiness in knowing that you missed out on some conversation, to the continued depression of feeling that you weren't present in the lives of your friends.

And if your friends do know about your condition, the VN does try to show the problem of being friends with us. We try to be good friends, and we legitimately feel worried if we are burdens because of the unpredictability of our depressive episodes. But we still do crave human relations even if we dont always know how to go about doing so. Most of the time, our depression does get the better of us and we breakdown, being unable to even muster the strength to call somebody or anybody for that matter, because we feel incapable of even expressing ourselves. We even feel like there is no point to self-expression since during such a mental state, we feel like there is nothing we can do.

As for social situations, not everyone that is depressed is so hopelessly useless in making friends. We are capable of having fun and meeting the people close to us, just not when we have depression. Some of us are even good social liars, we can tell people that we are fine, we even look like it, which is why the condition is dangerous. Because sometimes we don't want the people around us to know, or worry, or have to walk on eggshells around us just to accomodate us. We really just want to be treated like your friends, like people. Not some mental crutch you have to "accomodate", which just makes us feel worse.

We aren't that fragile, we aren't so socially hopeless. We just have times where our proverbial shit hits the fan. Yes, severe cases or instances of depression do hit us. We sometimes cry during our sleep, have nightmares about things when we wake up. Depression can cause us to go into anxiety attacks about our inability to do anything. But they aren't always triggered by something. This VN gives off the impression of melancholy and general sad circumstances of depression, that it seems all pervasive but its actually not.

I have a manic-depressive disorder. Under the DSM-5 its considered type II Bipolar Disorder, which I had and was discovered by a professor whom noticed certain trends in my behavior. Despite that, I was not and have not been on medication or treatment for the majority of my life. Yes I was different, but I have had friends, I have had happy moments, but they are at times marred by an overwhelming feeling of worthlessness and emptiness at times. During negative bouts, I try to sleep in though your mind at times becomes overactive. You might second guess yourself and the actions around you, you become hypersensitive to spoken words and think that its all negative comments about you. You can tune out the entire world for even weeks at a time, not going to lecture and dragging your ass to tutorials because you know you have to despite feeling like its utterly pointless. Its not entirely debilitating though I have missed an exam during one extremely emotionally taxing episode of depression which lasted about a week during my second year. But, I have completed my studies with close to a first-class honours. We are not as hopeless as portrayed in this VN, but the condition is not to be trivialized.

We do have suicidal thoughts during really bad times because we feel incapable of handling the complex feelings we have. We sometimes think if we died, would anyone really care at all. Maybe everyone would be happier if I wasn't around. Yes we do think that despite having rational minds. Depression can screw with our logical thinking eventhough some of us even studied formal mathematical logic in our university. Here is the catch, despite being good students, getting good grades, having a good family, having a loving partner, we WILL STILL experience depression. Its an inability to be happy and marred with debilitating melancholy that characterizes depression. It will hit without warning, without triggering, with no sense of timing. My ability to write this is because I am not in a depressive state right now.

Which is why I have to write this review. Its not informed enough as a VN to talk about depression. The danger is not the diagnosis of depression. Its the mismanagement of it. Its when people like us, whom when unfortunate enough to go through severe instances of depressive episodes have NO means to recourse, that things can go really bad. I don't have such an extremely debilitating case of depression that its entirely like the MC, but from personal experience of the worse of my depressive episodes, it can be like it. But the characterization is just wrong, like when given the option to do X or Y during depression, we just dont feel it. Our minds cannot handle the decision in very bad situations, and we shutdown, opting to tune out everything. We forget to eat, we forget to call, do work, play... etc... We just try to pass the day. Almost like a comatose state, which I have personally went through. It goes through tears and unimaginable grief at seemingly pointless things, our brains just think of everything that went wrong, will go wrong, the problems we cause others until the proverbial snap, and we just need to be alone.

Then, it is in those moments of our vulnerability that people recognize as depression. Its something that literally feels like its manipulating our minds, forcing us to do things we wouldn't do when outside of it. We don't ALWAYS have depression, it just hits us like a truck randomly for extended periods of time. Yes it can be hard, but the MC seems to be dealing with a really severe case of Depression, mixed in with social anxiety. But it could equally be from both the sad circumstances and mental condition. Maybe this is the kind of thing that the developer thought could get the message across, but depression is too complex a mental condition to just put into a game. Its something that needs to be handled with waaaay more tact and complexity than just this game. I can understand the good intentions coming from it, but it just doesn't put across the real problems depressives face, and instead puts it from too much of an external perspective to really be trying to bring the experience of depression to the player.

37941689.review:
Depression Quest is a beautiful and wise piece of interactive fiction which main theme is the exploration of clinical depression. We play a 20 years old man who have got a depression, though he isn't self-conscious about it in the start of the journey were we, the player, join him in the opening of the game. This would probably have stroked me as more silly if I had not myself in recent times had a weak depression. An acquaintance of mine pointed out that I was not okay, she might have questioned whether I was depressed - I can't recall, I thought she was silly. Most of all just to spite her I tried to take an online test for gauging depression, it indicated I had a weak depression. I found another it stated I had a weak or moderate depression. Another still that I had a weak depression ... She'd obviously hacked the internet! A while later on I went to see my doctor and their test said I had a weak depression too.      

Anyhow. The psychology portrayed in this "game" is dominated, to put it in a black and white framework, by natural science and social science, with all their strengths and weaknesses. I.e. it's, among things, the personal clueless and naive bitch of the pharmaceutical industry (hyperbole)--O why hello Capitalism dear! My sweet ever-mutating friend, how come you're still only level 9?! Have you no balls? And do stop sulking already about the Chinese outwitting your parents for a while ...--Albeit there's of course also loads of noble and lovely aspects to the discourse that dominates western psychology. It's just gonna have a tough and problematic time when for instance transhumanism hits humanity hard in the near future. Though naturally it won't stand alone, thus the sparkling multifaceted stars that is humanity shines brighter than ever before! But it could get very problematic indeed. "It's the best of times and it is the worst of times." ...      

I've played through one path in the game and I've been afking some, it took around 1.8 hour.

If the narrative was, "I am depressed because of x reason," then there would material for a goal and good opposition to that goal.

35058308.review:
I don’t have moral objections to Depression Quest for its attempts to bring harsh themes of mental illness affecting many of today’s youth into an interactive element. I have moral objections to the carelessness with which it approached its subject.

I find Depression Quest to be harmful for the cause it attempts to defend. Depression Quest is bad not for depressives but for anyone who would wish to inform themselves about depression by playing an educational game based on it.

I did not initially get very far in Depression Quest, I was actively repulsed by it within minutes and I was forced to come back to it a few times. This is not due to its hamhanded, burdened writing, but because Depression Quest stated in its writing and what little gameplay I was subjected to that it is not interested in educating anyone about depression.

In the introductory page of Depression Quest, the game states that “[Depression Quest’s goal is]… to illustrate as clearly as possible what depression is like, so that it may be better understood by people without depression…”  

The player is then introduced by the main character who is represented by “you”. Here is where the game may have needed a deeper examination in the writing stage.

Depression Quest is an interactive fiction, much like a choose-your-own-adventure book. This means that by referring to the character as “you” (which will then be internalized as “me” or “I”), the game necessarily has to be the one telling you how you feel. Consequently, the game saddles itself in the uncomfortable, frustrating space between allowing yourself to feel your own emotions and empathizing with another person’s story. Instead of learning about depression by relating to the experiences of another or by making your own informed decisions based on the situation at hand, “you” are handed thoughts and emotions and forced to make decisions based on what you are told that you feel.

At best, this is merely bad writing and bad game design. To be told that one is depressed without any true sense of context (not that real life depression needs context to exist, but we’ll get back to that) and then limit a player’s options based on said depression is frustrating and unintuitive. The very first choice given to the player has visibly cut off the most positive action that can be taken because of a prescribed emotion that has been saddled on the player. This is maddening because the other three options are extremely negative, depressing options. 

At worst, however, this informs a calloused, offensive view of depression. Where the stated goal is to inform others about what depression feels like, the game is not only tight-lipped but dictatorial about emotions. On the surface, this would seem to be what depression means, but when a player is forced to empathize with nothingness, where emotions are prescribed and positivity is blocked off without the slightest hint of context beyond a tedious, menial job, the player who will, by their nature, be fighting against the boundaries of the game will be filled with one thought…

“Why doesn’t this person just cheer up?”

Anyone who cared enough to read the opening introduction to the game will know why this character cannot cheer up, it’s because they have depression, which is a mental illness that prevents cheering up. But I, the player, do not have depression which is why I am playing this game. I am here to learn about depression, but consequently am given a meaningless scenario without context with which one can only hopelessly fight against. Without the buffer and tenderness that empathy to a fleshed out, acting and feeling character can provide, we are only asked to hop into the body of another person, act in their best interests and then be reprimanded for doing so.

So if Depression Quest doesn’t inform its players about depression or allow them to make choices (again: blocking positive answers such as “shake off your funk and go have a good time with your girlfriend” from usage), what is the substance that takes up Depression Quest’s overly long play time? 

That substance would be vague, unsatisfactory explanations of the general idea of what it is like, not to be depressed, but to be a little sad. Near the start of the game is a sentence that I would like to conclude this little rant by deconstructing. 

Firstly, some context. The main character (again: “you”) are working on a “project” (never explained either, even in its own explanatory page) that is distracting “you” from the tedium and meaninglessness of your nine to five job. It is a freelance project with no backing and is simply a personal creative exercise, possibly made to be monetized at some point. It has no deadline and no collaborators.

When the main character returns home from work hoping to continue their project (Here, unable to “Order some food, grab a drink and hunker down for a night of work.”), a form of vague panic begins to creep up on the “player” and then the game states that “All you can think about is how incredibly far behind you are,[…]” and that the work seems insurmountable.

Let’s take that sentence apart.

“All”, all means entirety. A sum. “You”. Ascribing this entirety to me only after a few pages of contextless description. “Can”, ability to. “think about”. By saying “All you can think about…”, the creator is in fact stating that the player is helpless behind this vague mental blockage (described only as “panic”). The second half of that statement “how incredibly far behind you are” is nonsense. This is clearly not a project with a deadline or true obligation (“You started this project some months ago and have, miraculously, managed to keep at it.”), thus “far behind” is a concept that exists only in the mind of this character who clearly does not represent me.

“All you can think about is how incredibly far behind you are…” is a damning phrase that tellingly states that the player is not only unable to surmount this vague, unnoble emotion that has been forcefully given to them, but also in that submission, they exist only at the behest of complete nonsense that doesn’t exist in the mind of the player or even the main character but rather the creator who believes that simply describing his/her actions and thoughts and not the concepts that inform them is enough to make someone finally understand what it is truly like to be depressed.

Depression is a tough thing. It is not sadness or strife as described by Papers, Please or Spec Ops: The Line. It can come without warning. It can manipulate your life and remove any form of agency from your actions. People who have not suffered depression may not understand what that’s like. It needs to be handled with greater care and understanding than the simple act of describing sadness.

Imagine if I were enacting an emotional exercise with another person. Imagine I told this person that they were depressed, but that taking certain actions may help them become less depressed. This person then tells me that they would like to go out for ice cream to alleviate their depression.

If I told this person that depression simply doesn’t work like that and all they get to do, all they are able to do, without any explanation, is go home and waste away in front of the television, would I not be grossly oversimplifying a state of mental illness?

Would I not be providing a disservice to anyone who suffers clinical depression by trivializing their experiences?

Would that not be a wrongheaded, self-indulgent, callous and hurtful way to describe a serious, harmful psychological state of being?

I am not accusing the creator of being insensitive. I am accusing the creator of being indulgent. Depression, being the bilious virus it is, demands more care than its creator was willing to provide.

That’s not evil or malicious. It’s simply a shame

35025455.review:
Depression Quest is an interactive novel – nothing less, nothing more. It does not have any gameplay nor challenging riddles that will put one's mettle to the test. Moreover, it is not a be-all and end-all guide to depression but it does not claim to be. It is made clear by the authors that the sickness varies from person to person, hence it is an impossible task to describe every type of it. I, for one, believe that the story is universal enough to convey the message well – that no matter how well-off one might be, it can happen to anyone from all walks of life.

The game looks like this: a few photographs at the top of the page, a wall of text in the middle with hyperlinks (additional information in the beginning, going to the next page, and making choices), and three bars at the bottom informing the player about the character's mental state, whether they attend a therapy and supplement it with medication or not. Personally, I am not fond of the bars but they do not get in the way and one can simply ignore them. There's also a monotonous soundtrack with sparse instrumentation and a couple of sounds added depending on the context. The writing is decent for the most part, albeit with minor mistakes here and there, and it is paced rather well. However, I absolutely love one thing they did: many of the options are crossed out, depending on your state. I reckon this is a neat mechanic that illustrates well what depressed people have to go through – they [i]know[/i] what is the right thing to do but they lack the energy and motivation to make it happen.

The game has a number of endings and a few ways to get there so there is no one way to "win" it. My only complaints are that the novel ends rather abruptly and there is a major inconsequence one can possibly encounter when exploring one of the ways. Other than that, it is a decent novel, [strike]absolutely worth the price[/strike]. However, understanding depression is not an easy task so one has to be open-minded in order to get what the novel is really about.

P.S. Please check out my other reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/

My curator page: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FVABot/curation

35010739.review:
Depression Quest is a interactive story where you go through a story of somebody living with depression that you get to make choices in. The game is created by "The Quinnspiracy" and is currently their only game available on Steam.  This game at the current time is free on the steam store. 

First off I would not recommend playing this game if you already are struggling with issues in real life or are going through a hard period. The game's choices are tough and have a genuine impact on the protagonist that affect how the game plays out.  

The music on the game is very typical sad slow music that changes as the game progresses. I actually like the music on this title and believe it to matchs the genre and feel of the game well. The game has multiple endings which are decided by the choices that you make. The game feels in my opinion very well written and nicely paced so it flows well, the game does really give you a look into the life of somebody struggling with depression. 

If you are looking for a game that you can really connect with on an emotional level then this may be the game for you. If you  have a friend that is struggling with depression or having bad thoughts then this game could certainly help you understand it better. 

It is by no means a perfect game and it has its fair share of criticism from a lot of people for a lot of reasons. But tome it is very well-written and really should help you understand depression better.

32194351.review: A "choose your own adventure game" that conveys the experience of depression not only through excellent writing but the central mechanic of prohibiting more positive choices as the character's depression increases. Many of the user reviews are criticising this mechanic and the game as a whole as unrealistic. Firstly, the overall game is NOT unrealistic. It may not represent everyone's experience of depression but it is highly accurate for some people (and the protagonist explicitly has severe motivational issues). Secondly, this is missing the point. The game aims to convey the EXPERIENCE of depression to further understanding among people who've never had to deal with it. People with depression may not be cosmically prevented from cheering up, meeting friends and being productive, but many of them FEEL like they can't. It's the life of a depressed person FROM HIS PERSPECTIVE, not that of an impartial observer.

31980451.review:
1 out of 6 stars.

Imagine a game about domestic abuse that doesn't allow the player to do anything other than stay and endure more and more abuse. Depression Quest does just that, only with regards to depression. 

It teaches people all the wrong lessons. For example:

1. You have no control whatsoever over your life and your decisions once you are depressed
2. Opening up to other people or family members is counterproductive
3. Seeking professional mental health isn't something that helps. (On my 1st playthrough the game openly prevented you from doing that. It was a choice that is crossed out and I was not allowed to pick it. During my second playthrough I was able to pick it and even took medication.  Guess what - it had no visible effect on anything, same ending, same situations etc.
4. The choices you make are in the end meaningless

All this puts the player into a mindset of learned helplessness (it is an actual psychological term, feel free to look it up), which is arguably the worst and least effective posture you can adopt when dealing with depression.

On the technical aspects and plot of the game — the writing wasn't horrible, but nothing to write home about either. Character development was nonexistent and the characters were shallow and stereotypical. The characters were easily the worst parts of the narrative. For example: the author intends to present a girlfriend of the player character as nice and loving, but she inadvertently comes off as pretentious and tacky. Ending the character's relationship with her was the only good decision that the game allowed me to make (obviously wasn't the author's intent).

To make one thing clear: I'm not depressed, but I do have an academic background in psychology. This game has a great premise and and tackles a very important subject and I want to applaud that. 
However, that alone doesn't make a good game. The execution is bad and the underlying psychological assumptions are just wrong. It is not a game that teaches you how to deal with depression, rather it teaches you how to stay depressed forever.

I can't recommend it to people with depression, nor to people who want to learn about it, nor to psychology students. It is a counterproductive, bad game that does not reflect the scientific insights that modern psychology provides when dealing with the serious mental disorder that is depression. 

Big thumbs down.
