31431677.review:
First off: I am very well aware of the drama surrounding this peace of work, I as many other people who participated in #GamerGate think that Zoey Quinn, the devolper of this game, is a despicable person. Never the less a game should be judged on it's own merits, not the personality of it's creators. And thus I recommend this game for a very small niche of gamers.

Disclaimer: This is a highly subjective review, it covers a topic many will find very emotional, including me.

This "game" is surprisingly good. 

It's a text based, slice of life, rpg where you play a not very relatable character.

But as I said in the beginning it is suprisingly good. It's well written and the situations the player's character finds himself are relatable, even if the character's reaction often are not. If you do not struggle with depression yourself this game will not be of much value to you. But for me the game was able to stirr some emotions. That's a feat in and off itself. I made me go from "this guy is whiney b***h" over laughter at situations involving a cat that might not have been that funny, but I laughed anyway, to legitimately making me cry.

As with all games of this genre it's meat and bones are the supporting cast of characters. And this game has some.


Alex, the main character's girlfriend stands out in particular. To me at least. She is a well written, loving girlfriend. Even though she comes of as being an idealised version of one, never the less she hit just the right emotional spot for me.
But that might have to do with me having gone through a rather bad break up a few months ago. 

The older brother Malcolm is another great character. He is the kind of older brother I strive to be, again just the right emotional spot.

I don't use numerical rating systems, and I don't think this piece of work might even be able to fit one. So all I an say is: Feel free to try this game out for youself, it's freeware after all. I don't think you will get the same emotional reaction out of it but you might find something enjoyable in it.

31426872.review: This is not a game. There is extremely limited visual content - just a few pictures per page of text, few choices, and no gameplay. Zero. Also, for a 'game' that is supposed to be woman friendly, the storyline immediately excludes you if you are a heterosexual woman, or a gay man. It is neither fun nor educational as it demonstrates only what it might be like, for some people, to have higher than normal levels of social anxiety, but does not accurately portray living with depression, and it reads at a teen fanfiction level which makes the limited options even more frustrating. For a project that claimed to prove gaming can be gender neutral, nonviolent, AND still be fun this experiment is a complete failure because it narrows down the character to very specific gender and sexual roles in the first two pages, pivots around the idea of emotional abuse and self-loathing, and is simply not at all fun to either read or try to engage. The one positive thing I will say is that if you want to develop depression this is as good a place to start your quest as any.

31333140.review:
(TLDR: It's not a game, it's an experience, and it's amazing. Go on and play.)

First and foremost, I would like to tell those considering downloading Depression Quest this: Depression Quest is not a game. Depression Quest is an experience, aiming to help people understand the trials and tribulations that come with depression. At this, it does an incredible job. In all the stories I've read, all the games I've played, and in all my experiences watching someone try to explain what depression is like, Depression Quest is one of the most realistic representations I've seen.

The music used sets a somber tone, that pulls you into the lethargic, dreary state that the protagonist is in for most of the "game" (depending on how you play.) This only furthers it's ability to connect you to the protagonist. In this, mixed with the simplistic, yet elaborate backstories of nearly all the charcters and the seemingly devastating amount of stress placed on each decision, the creators have made a beautiful piece of art.

Many people, as I have seen in the reviews and online forums, have spoken about it sometimes being "dramatic," or "over-done," but it's really not. Depression is different for everyone. What could seem dramatic in Depression Quest, would be paradise to someone suffering from extreme, heavy-set depression.

So in the end, I implore you to play this. It's an amazing experience, and you will not be disappointed afterward.
You might not by happy. You might even be sad, or upset. Certainly, though, you will not be dissapointed.

31296838.review:
This is an iconic game and, perhaps, not for the right reasons.

Beyond the post gammergate fuss it's worth assessing this game as a stand alone experience, as a game in it's own right not as an exercise in either alt-right baiting or alt-right propagandising.

As such this game stands up as a worthwhile experience.

The game mechanics are simple: you have a list of options available to you each time a decision is made. you begin with most of these unavailable as you fall into depression and then as you are offered options such as speaking to loved ones and seeking professional help more options become available. if you choose not to the options narrow again, if you choose to open up to others and seek help more options become available.

This is a simple but effective game mechanic and is effective in mimicking the path depression may take.

No, the game is not 'fun' but why should games be fun and why are the mainstream games which offer you opportunities to do nothing but kill 'fun?'

This is a game about emotional states and it is a work of art. if this is not what you are after from a game then don't play it and don't review it but don't trash the game the same way i would not trash a FPS.

30335017.review:
An interesting text-based game. While the phrasing can be a little awkward at times ("You are a mid-twenties human being"), it's a good read if you have around half an hour. I'd say give it a go.

Some of the criticism of this game is valid: 
If you don't like reading, this game is not for you. The way depression is portrayed is a little simplistic, and characters seem a little too supportive at times, which is usually not the case in reality. The cross-off mechanic that prevents you from accessing certain options seems restrictive. At least in my experience, depression doesn't really work like that. It might be interesting to try to attempt something unreasonable and be worse off for it. Also, having a depression indicator is a little on-the-nose; players should be able to judge for themselves. The UI could also be a little more interesting in general.

On the other hand:
Despite what I said earlier, the game does an okay of job of portraying the battle with depression. The characters are very supportive and the game encourages looking for professional help and reaching out to those who care, which is good advice. It's not too long, it's free, and provides an interesting insight into depression, if nothing else. 

Also:
Some of the other criticism is very unfair. It really isn't the "worst thing ever" as some seem to be making it out to be. It's not that fun, but neither is dealing with depression. Since it's not too long, I'd suggest playing it before jumping to conclusions.

For me, personally. I ended up putting my feet into the shoes of the main character and ended up making choices on what I would do instead of what i thought was best for him. Some scenarios seem to have a correct answer, but it's important to understand how it would make the character feel.

In short, this "game" captures depression in a fairly accurate light and helps to understand what the daily routine is. The story is stunning and even feels like a crawl. as if everything your doing is pointless as the days keep ticking by.

For those who wish to learn about depression this is a good place to come.  although this can also be fairly trigging to those who do suffer. It can help show you the advantages and disadvantages of anti-depressents and what the health care system can provide. 

In short, a solid 8.8/10 for me. The story did fairly well at not distinquishing the gender of the main character, although they gave the girlfriend a unisex name and would've done far better by avoiding stating her gender. Allowing both male and female readers to better attach themselves to the main character.

I found the technique of certain options being crossed off when your character's depression is too high to be able to undertake them to be an interesting and effective way to convey how like you really can't just decide to not be depressed like that.

26573043.review:
The title of the game says it all : the game isn't about learning what is depression, but instead, what is to live with depression. Of course, depression is experienced in multiple ways, depending of the person affected with it. In Depression Quest, depression is seen in the main protagonist way's - how HE lives through it. The game doesn't teach what is depression whatsoever, but that was never its goal. Its goal is to sensibilize people to what living with depression may look like. In that regard, the game reaches its goal.

On another note, the choices in-game were realistic - as a healthcare professionnal specialized in mental health, through the many interviews and anamnesis conducted, i've heard many stories from my patients on how they lived their depression experience and most of the choices i faced in the game are choices that some of my patients already faced. 

TL;DR: play it, it is free. Plus side, you get to learn some key clinical signs of depression. Who knows? Might help you someday with yourself or someone from your social circle as no one is risk-free of developping a mental disease.

26486554.review:
Una experiencia enriquecedora. No es un juego es una leccíon. Un libro que leyendo pausadamente dura unas 2 horas. Despues de leerlo no tengo claro si genera esperanza o te estampa en la cara la cruda realidad pero desde luego ayuda a identificar algo que le puede estar pasando a cualquiera.Es interesante empatizar con el protagonista y ver su progresión.


Mi interpretación del tema (Sin spoilers simplemente el tema):

Lo alarmante de la depresión es que se retroalimenta, creo que la genera la insatisfacción prolongada/abrupta de situaciones que uno ve como irreversibles y/o pendientes. Te introduce en un bucle que cuanto mas se ejecuta más difícil es salir del mismo porque genera pasividad ante el problema y falta de motivaciones. A su vez te genera ansiedad y te bloquea porque te abrumas cada vez con más facilidad. Además de estar hecho polvo físicamente y disperso por la ansiedad (con tensión cervical) y por el desorden de sueño . Es decir, todo se vuelve mas difícil por el cansancio y se tiende a procrastinar, no te centras en ninguna actividad. Eso a su vez te hace sentir inútil, luego te baja la autoestima. También desencadena ataques de pánico en casos muy elevados de ansiedad... Depresión no es estar simplemente triste, se puede llevar todo: intereses, motivaciones, deseos, coraje, ambiciones, ganas de vivir, voluntad, relaciones. 

Creo que si lo que la genera es solo de origen psicológico uno se puede reeducar a sentir de nuevo con el instinto primario de la supervivencia por el cual se asume todo para seguir adelante... y se que en esa rabia a no conformarse a ser un ser "defectuoso" y querer vivir, ignorando la vergüenza teniendo claro que es un limitador de iniciativa, se genera la motivación para conseguirlo... hay que buscar un equilibrio entre la condescendencia con uno mismo para soportar el handicap de que todo parece mas grande pero exigiéndose un mínimo para no acobardarse y marcar objetivos que aunque no apetezcan hay que hacerlos pues la satisfacción de cumplirlos son lo que curan el alma de esta mierda que te puede acompañar años o décadas como tomes un rol de víctima pasiva avergonzada de uno mismo con pánico a socializar.

26375371.review:
Any game based around depression is obviously going too be somber. It's a topic that is hard to talk about and certainly carries a heavy stigma.

Depression Quest leads you through a series of decisions that influence the life of the character you play as. You are not named or gendered, which allows for any player to project themselves into the role of the main character. You deal with working to make ends meet, maintaining romantic relationships, and maintaining relationships with your family. I've only played through once, but it seems to be a game with many different results based off of your decisions. 

The stated purpose of the game is to let the player have a better understanding of depression, or at least how the developers have faced depression. I think this is done quite well. As someone who has been through a major depressive stint, the game hit close to home. In particular I found the elimination of choices to be one of the most well done aspects of the game. The answer that's usually perceived as the way out or the most healthy choice is crossed out. In this way, you are shown the option, you contemplate it, but ultimately cannot do it. Simply put, it's hard to translate a depressive mindset into a choice based game, but I found it to be done well.

However, as someone who has faced a lot of these issues of depression, it is somewhat difficult to play the game. I'm glad that there was a warning in the beginning telling people that the game is, well, depressing in nature. Particularly, I found it interesting in that now as someone who has been getting help, I see the logical errors in a lot of the depressive cycles and decisions the character makes. It's always saddening to see the options that worked for me crossed off.

In this way, I think the game illustrates its point very well. However, its hard to recommend in a lot of ways. I think its eye opening certainly, but its hard to want people to go through a lot of the sobering decisions. If you don't know much about depression and want to learn more, play it.

26375315.review:
While playing this game, I found my mind constantly wandering. That's not good.

To put this in perspective, a few weeks ago, I had to play a few text based adventures made by my classmates. The developers were (are) not yet professionals, and some of their games were better than others. However, they were all written in a very similar format to Depression Quest. Very rarely did I slip into a daydream, or wish I was doing something else, when playing my peers' games, something I cannot say for Depression Quest.

Self insertion characters, as well as depressed characters, are very hard to write. I should know. I have written characters who have mental illnesses, or have just been down on their luck. I had to rewrite them all several times to keep them likable, realistic, and sympathetic. But the narrative keeps beating me over the head with how depressed the protagonist is. It's pretty much their only character trait. The secret to writing self instertion characters is to give them a backstory and personality of their own. I'm pretty sure Depression Quest Protagonist has a backstory, but a very shallow personality.

I'm not overly fond of the piano either. I don't claim to know much about proper music, so to get an idea of how to compose a better piano score, just play Long Live the Queen. It manages to express a wide range of emotions with just the one instrument. (And that game was also developed by a predominantly female crew. :) )

However, I'm going to give credit where it's due. Even though I'm not diagnosed with depression, I could feel the weight of needing to protect people close to me, including my own mother, even though Depression Quest Protagonist was the one who needed help.

26375306.review:

I felt that any option that could've been selected should not have been displayed, as it was just disappointing and caused more negative feelings towards the gameplay than anything.

I'm fully aware of the fact that this could represent a person who suffers from depression knowing their options but still finding themselves unable to follow through with them. While I appreciate the sentiments and the depth of the thoughts put into this game, I was not a fan of the seeming lack of interactivity where the devs limited player's choices and I felt that some of the writing was longwinded and a bit unnecessary.

26357095.review: Depression Quest is a very well thought out and realistic game. Many, if not all, of the parts of this story are completely relatable. 26357088.review: Depression Quest is extremely realistic. I played through answering questions as if I was actually dealing with those situations. And, as someone who has dealt with depression all her life, I found that my answers reflected how I've actually felt before. As a result, I became profoundly depressed, and that limited what I could choose for answers. That aspect is especially realistic. When you are truly depressed, your mind can go blank and you lose the will to do things. Beautiful, realistic game. If you don't have depression, but want to know what those who do have it are going through, play this game. It's a fantastic example and can really give you an insight you didn't know you needed.

26357085.review: This game was very interesting. I feel like it really captured the feeling of being depressed for someone who had never felt that way before. I like how there were options that could have been the most obvious option but were crossed off because you wouldn't be able to do that if you were depressed.

26357082.review: This game definately accomplishes it's goal. Admittedly I have knowledge about this topic already, so I was able to tell for the most part which choices were "right". The blocked off choices really helped enforce that depression prevents you from doing what you think would be best, or want to do. The choices you make sometimes felt like they would have an effect on things, but didn't have any noticeable consequences down the line. (For example adopting a cat, you essentially never see it again either way to my knowledge.) Whereas other choices have unexpected consequences down the line (medication side effects.) Overall the game really makes the experience of fighting depression a tangible struggle, and even with prior knowledge it was difficult to make choices.

26357070.review:
What really makes this poignant is the disabled options. As someone who's kind of a sucker for fourth-wall muckery, actually having the available options increasingly disabled as you sink deeper and deeper into your own depression is a striking way to impart a feeling of helplessness, in addition to the pointless status indicators at the bottom of the screen-- you KNOW you should probably see a doctor and get medication, but you can't bring yourself to. The whole game, I was almost certain I would reach a point when the only option left would kill me. But I suppose, even if there's no real end, staying alive is a triumph in itself. With a "game" like this, it's easy to end up just being extremely pretentious, but here, you can tell that there's some real understanding behind this. The fact that it presents an atmosphere of emptiness rather than darkness makes it all the more striking as well.

Of course, I'm probably not qualified to speak on this, as I have not had to deal with depression personally. So take my opinion with a grain of salt.

All in all, it's an interesting experience. Not a "game", but an experience.

(Also, I do not care about the drama that transpired after this.)

26357037.review: All I can say is that this game is an accurate depiction of what living with depression is like. It's to the point that I was unable to finish the game because of how real it started to become. This is definitely a game everyone should play to help people understand the line of thinking of a depressed person and the emotional and physical trauma that is endured during depression. This is one of the most real games I have ever played.

26339978.review:
An amazing way to share an experience of depression. I would love if all my friends and family would play this, just to understand me better. Like when people ask "What can I do to help?" I could say "Play Depression Quest."

No, it's not a solution, but it would be a way to make a conversation. A framework for understanding and sharing that could lead to finding ways to help.

If you're struggling with depression ( I am, but feel like I've made a lot of progress and was ready to handle this), this game could be dangerous for you, but I would still recommend getting friends and family to play it. It says so many things we can't always say for ourselves.

26338604.review: The game is just not as interesting or deep as it thinks it's being. It starts off with you waking up in your room on a monday morning and the flavor text berrating you. Some of this text is clickable and brings up even more text than the intial introduction. The first flag is how condescending the narrator is to the people in their life, how everybody "is trying their best but just "doesn't understand the pain." Instead of explaining what "the pain" is or why it's affecting their life so adversly, the narrator just admits that they have a problem but that there really isn't anything anyone can do about it and that it's there to stay. The actual interactivity of the game really shows the blatent "feel sorry for me" attitude with options that are logical and pretty helpful with the situation or further the downward spiral of the character. Instead of having a choice in the matter, however, the "helpful" choices are scratched out in bright red with text at the bottom of the page reinforcing the fact that your life is terrible and nothing is helping you. I don't know if it was the developers intentions to sound condescending and pathetic at the same time but it's frankly not sad but annoying. Just because it feels like there is nowhere to go doesn't really mean it's true and if other people are willing to help you then it isn't going to hurt more just to talk about it. Also it feels like this is just focusing on a very specific type of depression instead of what could actually be a varying type of disorder that people actually have, trivializing the concept of depression. It's a game on a high horse and I'm not impressed.

26338523.review: This review is based on what bit of the game I have played so far. Honestly, I feel that the game does give a an at least semi-accurate portrayal of depression. However, as many other reviews will say, it does not offer a lot of hope with many options being blocked out as the game progresses. It has a broad range of choices that are feel fairly accurate as a list of options and feelings, though most get blocked out leaving a complete feeling of helplessness. I might recommend it for a basic understanding of what depression feels like, I feel that it does not give a complete understanding surrounding the issue. It feels like the game is focusing more on the tunnel than the light at the end of it.

26338513.review: Through what this game sets out to do in terms of goals, I feel that it accomplishes it well enough. It does give away for those who don't have depression to receive a sense of what it is like for those who do. I can say what I have played it has made what it wants to portray clear enough, through its descriptions of situations, relaying what the protagonist is feeling to the player and making the decisions fit with the narrative. In that way, the game is recommended to those who want to know what it's like to have depression, but it offers very little aside from that.

26338493.review:
I honestly found this game to be interesting and didn't really want to stop playing (but had to because time sucks) however I wouldn't really recommend this to most gamers on here. It's a cool text adventure, but I don't think people on Steam are really looking for a text adventure.

Also I think that the fact that there is an assumed gender/sexuality for the player isn't necessarily a good thing. I know this may seem like a nitpick, but not everyone is a straight male, lesbian female, or bisexual person (either gender) and some people actually do get upset about things like this.

Other than that I kind of like that there was an attempt to bring attention to what having depression (and anxiety) is really like.

26338489.review: From what I have played so far, this game has a very imformative and imersive story line to it. As someone who has gone through certain emotions and situations like this, it is a little harder to get through in that respect. Seeing the situation unfold and not haveing every option avaliable to you is frusterating and disheartening, and that makes the game just even more relateable. I'm looking forward to playing through the different and indepth paths that this game has to offer.

26338374.review: I found the game interesting because it is so controversial its popularity (if you would like to call it that) quickly grew and the team behind the game illustrated the game in the only way possible in a text quest. I applaud it for not trying an fps, third-person, 16 bit, or retro style game I enjoy how the game was composed because it was the only good way to illustrate everything.

26338366.review:
From what I've seen so far, Depression Quest seems to represent depression quite accurately--it feels inescapable, hopeless, and almost impossible to communicate to other people without feeling like a burden. It has ups and downs, and no matter how hard you try, there's no way out. 

As far as the writing goes, it goes. It's simple and effective language that says what needs to be said. No poetry or anything like that--none needed.

Choices are (sometimes humorously) limiting based on how a depressed person thinks and feels, which is a good method of teaching players about that kind of lifestyle.

Overall, good depiction of depression, nice writing, nice mechanics. Don't care about the background development or subsequent controversy--this is actually seems like a decent game.

26338351.review: It has branching paths, which do lead to different choices and, possibly, endings, which is a good design choice. I feel like its too bloated, with non-relevant information. In the beginning of the game, some words are highlited in blue, which tell you about various things in the game. But the game shouldn't have to spell out your life through these blue links, but rather, let you experience them when those moments come up in the game. Also, while the different choices are a good touch, sometimes, almost all of my multiple choices are crossed out, so I'm only able to choose one option. This means I can't get any other endings (if there are any.) I don't really reccomend it, because its only an okay-written game, and nothing groundbreaking like articles made it out to be upon its release.

26338346.review: Honestly, I have been dealing with chronic depression for a good amount of my life. The game in and of itself attempted to relate to some and much of the generic issues brought up within a "depressed" person's life and they were quite relatable, but at some points it seems quite unrealistic and blunt. It wasn't a bad experience per say, but it feels as if the game shoe horns you into choosing the generic and or bad choice. It did well locking away the freedoms of choice one would have when experiencing depression and I appreciate that, but at times I was just bored and unimmersed with how it portrays it. Also the generic melancholy music and static felt like it was trying too hard to set the mood in my opinion. I ended up succeeding in game possibly getting a good ending, but i still didn't feel all too satisfied. Not a bad game, nor am I going into the shitty background of it and its developer, but eh it wasn't as heavy as some people would expect it to be. It's worth like 1 playthru at best, do with it what you will.

26263271.review:
I have been writing a game analyses on depression Quest for my interactive media cause and I thought I might try to write a review. I’m an inexperienced programing student and I’m currently studying the concept of game feels and game play aesthetics.
 Depression Quest is an incredible narrative game with a powerful story, this choose you own adventure style game is definitely not for everyone and tell its story through the interactions and choices made by the player, it puts the player into a very dark frame of mind and gives them a taste of what depression is like for some people, this game is not designed to say “this is how depression feels for everyone” these Indi games are excellent examples of how extremely touchy subjects can be explained to people through the power of games. I loved the use of visuals and sounds that set the sense of pressure bearing down on the player, and the amazing way the game forces the player to make very irrational decisions which in turn effects the player more and more as time progresses. This game has been designed to allow the player to step into someone else’s shoes and be immersed in another person’s reality and it can be hard, people generally don’t want to play a game that will make them depressed but I strongly recommend this game, games such as Depression quest and dys4ia can allow a person to gain insight into another life and help you grow and a person. 
Some quotes of the game like- (you are severely depressed. Your moderation levels are nonexistent. You alternate between feeling totally apathetic to panicking about things out of you control. You lack energy to do much more then to sleep the days away yet you constantly feel worthless prevent you from getting any actual rest. You feel like dyeing but ironically are to drain to actually act on these feelings.)  Hits close to home and dills in the fact that this game is not for fun, it’s not for adventure, it is a tool for learning and a treasure trove of emotion, Depression Quest describe how hard it is for family and friends to understand mental illness. This game starts in the middle of the main characters life and allows you to make choices on how to handle everyday situations such as work, social activities, pet companionship and relationships, each and every choice you make can narrow the options and choices you can make later on in the game and inevitably lead you through a panicked stat of mined, there is no real ending to this story, there’s no special combination of choices you can make to gain a happy ending, this is done to show that there is no easy answers and it’s a hard pill to swallow for most people.
If you have read to the end I thank you and thank you to the team who developed an incredible game.

25865144.review:
Not sure why people are criticizing this game, I found it quite enjoyable, almost fun. 
It's called Depression Quest, where you the protagonist seeks ways to get depressed, stop fighting it! 

You start out as a ridiculously happy person, your health is fantastic, you have a sexy girlfriend, hell you're even employed in a steady white collar job! But your goal is to shed these gifts and embrace your true self, so you slowly work your way dropping these unrealistic things until you resemble a normal person. 

Of course there are some ways to break this game, some people have found out you can upgrade to a pet cat, and even take mind altering drugs. But who are they really cheating but themselves? That just ruins the whole point of the game if you try to upgrade yourself to a god-like status, and you get lost in worldly distractions and extraneous socializing. You can't take any real-world lessons from this if you spend all your time running away from your true self. 

Personally I found this game ends far too soon, and I would be interested if the developer added a longer progression of consequences for actions. I was disappointed when I found I could not shed self-hygiene protocols or disassociate with family, and I was quite frankly looking forward to losing my residency. 

tl;dr 
Game is good, stop fighting the dark, give into your corruption. Feed the abyss.

25863284.review:
As someone who has struggled with depression since early adolescence, and witnessed persons with far greater afflictions than myself… this game is borderline offensive. While I applaud the attempt to address mental health, something that is arguably lacking in modern media in general, this is a momentous failure. 

This [i]choose your own adventure-esque[/i] game tries to confront depression through poor storytelling, artificially constricted choice, and lack of understanding of depression. The absence of quality is unbelievable. Mental conditions cannot be [i]simulated[/i] - any attempt to do so is totally misguided. Believing that understanding illness can be imparted through such ridiculously removed circumstances is, in layman's terms, the pinnacle of stupidity. You might as well create a Lower Respiratory Infection Quest, as it would allow the gamer to arrive at no more greater understanding of contracting a potentially lethal disease, than would Depression Quest impart knowledge of undergoing a potentially lethal mental condition. 

[h1]1/10[/h1]

25530999.review:
It's not a fun game, but it's not intended to be. This is a brave attempt to broaden the purpose of games, and to broaden the genre. It's a storytelling game that gives insight into what living with depression can be like. So this can be used to help people who have a depressed friend or loved one understand a little of what they're going through, and maybe give them some talking points to broach difficult subjects.

I suffer from anxiety/depression myself.  I'm 45 years old, but had I played this game earlier in life, I can see how it could have positively influenced me.

My only criticism is that it's a text adventure format.  I think it works for this subject matter, though.  Also, it's important to consider that there was a lot less funding for experimental games when this one was being produced.  Consider it a pioneering game in the indie field.

All in all, I applaud the effort, and hope that people find it helpful. I also hope that we continue experimenting with therapeutic possibilities of games.

25415536.review: This is an accurate depiction of one person’s depression, something that effects everyone differently. This is mostly a visual novel with the visual part taken out. As a person who suffers from depression, it is easy to know the “right” choices to make, but the choices feel like the have little weight to them. The writing is pretty bland. I don’t want to say that we need to make depression more exciting to have a discussion about it in video games, but this was mostly just a story about someone’s life, and instead of reading their blog or article, I had to open a program to read it. Basically, this game was kind of bleh feeling, which I am sure taps into how they were feeling, but there are better ways to bring up depression and more constructive ways to show the downsides and maybe provide the insight to have others help themselves.

I strongly believe in the power of games to help us identify with the problems and challenges of others, but this game really forced me ro reckon with challenges I face myself from a detached perspective that makes me proud of some of my decisions and reconsidering others. It's a powerful tool for reflection, empathy and understanding of those with any type of depression, even as a relatively simple sort of creative effort. 

Give it a try, give it to others. Understand the pain and challenge of others and know that your own isn't the only pain in the world.

25020046.review:
If you are looking for a fun game, stay away. This game, if you want to call it that, is pretty soulcrushing. It really shows the desparation and the helplessness that is to be experienced with depression. You have to commit to those feelings to really immerse in this game, otherwise it's just a waste of time.

If, however, you want to have a taste on what being depressed is like, if you want to understand depression better, this experience might help you. It might not have all the answers you are looking for, but it visualizes the inside of a depressed mind pretty well.

Get used to reading a lot of text; This "game" feels more like an interactive book than a video game. Love it or hate it.

If you can look past the lack of fun as well as the lack of actual gameplay, this game can do a lot to expand your own horizon.

24788978.review:
It should be appreciated that some people want this topic gain more publicity. But I personally don't think that this format of a textadventure fits. The story is just a collection of random events and so no tension is builded. It's also hard to get invested with the protagonist. This said the writing is OK.
I don't know if the options you can choose from are deactivated or activated because of your former actions but it makes the player feeling less control of the actual game. A better solution could have been the possibility of unlikely actions wich then return to the initial point.

All in all it shows how depression could be (actually you can have depression and still make jokes and laugh) but it's hardly a game for entertainment. So I only could recommend this for people who want to make an experience and aren't afraid of much reading.
Everyone else, even lover of textadventures, won't get much out of it.

24757599.review:
It's an interesting experiment but I'm not sure it achieves what it sets out for. In most cases it nicely describes the thoughts and moods of a depressed person but I feel like it's too simple. For someone that struggles with the illness it may seem oversimplified and "too easy" to get out of the severely depressed state in the game... you know what option you need to click (even when the ones naturally available for healthy people are crossed out, which is a nice touch) to possibly better your situation but for someone depressed it's not this clear. Also, although the creators do note this at the beginning, this particular character is in a very good environment (even if their job is not satisfying) because basically everyone supports them eventually and they can affort treatment and medication. 

So I'm not sure the game succeeds in what it tries to do. The idea is not bad and some of the descriptions are on point but the gameplay and the options lack in representing the difficulties and intricacies of the subject... which would be the reason to make a "game" such as this in the first place. I do recommend it if you are interested in the topic but don't expect too much from it.

24725848.review: I had more fun pulling out my teeth. Now I drink through a straw but at least I get more enjoyment from that than this game.

24711232.review:
I'm pretty sure the creator of this game has no realistic perception of depression. The ideas that I came across in this game were fucking pathetic and the decisions you can make (if not forced) are not entirely realistic or wise when you are in that state of mind. I am personally infruriated by this game as it trivialises something as invasive as depression. A path which I, personally, have lost someone to, and something I (almost) lost myself to once. If you want a game with a more legitimate grasp on the subject of depression play something like Neverending Nightmares or Until Dawn.

If you think you are suffering with depression, I implore you to talk to your GP. If they believe you are suffering from depression you will be sent to a hospital for treatment (in my experience). If you are experiencing suicidal thoughts you will most likely stay in hospital for several weeks. Another route is by contacting Healthy Minds, and NHS-run program which has helped me get in touch with some valuable people and continue, to this day, to help me understand my own mental health.

24701619.review:
This game is not for the faint of heart. It goes through the motions of a very real condition that many people face on a daily basis. It was refreshing to know that a game like this exists. I suffer from anxiety and depression, and anything that can help reduce the stigma of mental illness is a plus in my book. 

Having said that, I do wish it had more substance. I finished the entire game in under 20 minutes, and I'm not someone who is particularly gifted at gaming. I think having depression allowed me to finish the game rather quickly. Maybe others wouldn't do so well. I don't know. At any rate, I didn't find it worth the trouble to download onto my computer, especially with the little time I spent on the game itself.

Still, this is a unique way to explain depression to someone, and as someone who understands, I can't say no to that.

24309455.review:
This game gives a short and sweet, albeit powerful, look into the road to recovery from depression. As someone who's been through it and have now (mostly) recovered, I easily beat the game in 15 minutes. 

To those of you saying this game is too short, you should realize that depressed people don't see a "way out." Decisions made with a purpose or goal in mind can be written off as pointless, as the game often shows with the choices that are crossed out. They can easily be trapped in an endless cycle of denial and never really seek therapy, medication, or anything else that can really help them. 

As for not being serious/graphic enough, it's a freaking Steam game. It's not supposed to be that deep. Do you want them to actually depict someone harming themselves or committing suicide? The game isn't called Depression Simulator. It's Depression Quest. Your quest to overcome your mental illness and hope for a better future.

I think you completely and utterly failed to show any of that, and if anything, made me more depressed. The writing was fine, and it wasn't too boring. 24038750.review:
Given the history with this title I will try my absolute best to remain unbiased.

The biggest problem with this game is evident from the very beginning, it states it is a interactive non-fiction experience. 

It isn't, really. There are some very small choices, but they are not impactful and the outcome seems to be the same. There is not even any sort of PSA about how to get help for depression. I am not even sure why this was made. It does not seem to have been created to make awareness about depression, or try to translate the suffering and problems people who have to deal with deep depression have. It just feels like a empty, lifeless and non descript choose your own adventure game, except your choices are limited and the adventure consists of watching netflix and having awkward conversations with relatives and friends. Oh, well I also got a cat, but that really did not do much.

This is a empty, soulless experience, that paints a psychiatric issue over this shell of a "game" with sub par writing and inconclusive storytelling. There is no value gained from this, no new knowledge is found from depression, and no one with depression will gain any help from this.

This is a poor attempt at a interactive novel, and a worse attempt at creating depression awareness.

23694613.review:
I’m a clinical psychologist (CBT, as the one in the game), and also someone who deals with depression for a life time.
Just wanted to say that “if it’s a game or not” should be far from being the question. In life everything is an experience, apart from which lable we put on it. And playing Depression Quest is one of the most beautiful experiences I had in quite a while - the best in Steam, that is for sure.

I recognized myself in pretty much all aspects about the main character. And the way the game evolves is so real (and I can say both personal and professionally) that it often brought me tears. Tears of a mix of feelings; from bad and good memories but, above all, from the accurace of all vivid descriptions. (Which are, by the way, written in a very rich and beautiful manner.)

I have only to thank and congratulate the responsibles for this game to exist. It is of immeasurable help not only for people suffering of depression, but - and I would say above all - to all our close ones to get an understanding upon it. It’s a game to be shown to the families, close friends and beloved ones of any person living with depression. It has an immense elucidative potential.

If I would pick only one single mistake, it would be this game to be offered for free. If it cost 0,99, it would be still accessible to any one interested, but would cut out huge part of bad reviewers, with no personal interest, who only reached for this as it was free.

Thanks again! For the amazing game, for the beautiful (true) story, and for the incredibly helpful tool it can be to so many people who want (or need!) to get a glimpse of what is it depression all about. 
Daniel

23682588.review:
Most people disagree with calling Depression Quest a game. While I personnaly think it is and hope we will broaden our definition of games in the next years, let's put that aside. It's not because it does not qualify as a game that this interractive experience must be bad. 

I already did a review for this game on my blog and may provide a link for it one day, but for now I'll be concise: it shows amazingly how depression MAY be experienced (there are a whole lot of different experiences, this one represents only some of them). I like how it disables some options depending on your mental state, demonstrating the fact that some people experiencing depression lack initiative. I know it's frustrating for the players, but so is it for those people. If you approach Depression Quest as a "fun game", this is a big flaw; if you approach it as a game that tries to convey what it is to be depressed, this is excellent. 

It's full of little details like that that I appreciate, and the writing is good. It might not be award-worthy, but it's easy to read and it puts you in the mood very well without being "emo". 

The player may not have full control over the outcomes, but there are still plenty of branching that will make you see a whole different set of texts from one playthrough to the other. Anyway, even when you "fail", what follow is interesting and will teach you a lot about depression. You have to play this game in a mood of exploration, of "read, make a choice, see what happens, learn", not in a mood of winning, or discovering a fantasy world, etc. That's what we, the players, are used to, and maybe this is why Depression Quest is so hard for us to see as a game, or at least as "well done" (for whatever it is). 

It's strange how I've seen games with similar or more risqué concepts get the same praise as this one without all the hate. Really strange...

Note: I didn't really play 7-8 hours. The game was running on my computer while I was away. It's a good game, but not THAT good.

This game gives a good impression of how depression affects the individual bit by bit, step by step, until we are drowning, confused, and lost in pain we can't figure out.
Serves its purpose very well, putting the gamer through the many emotions and pains depression brings upon us.
It may not be a high-tech 3D game, but it still is useful as means to understand an illness that affects many people around us, loved ones, - who mayt be suffering from depression even without us knowing - so we can be more understanding, and lessen their pain, instead of accidentally enhancing it with a wrong word, attitude, or action.

Once I finish this game, I will be able to add a more thorough Review.

For example this gives a representation of what someone with the illness MIGHT be going through during this time in their life
i'd reccomend this if anyone wants a better understanding of depression this is a good way to find out how a person may be feeling.
The game isn't perfect but it also is'n't an abomination either.

A lot of people give this "game"/ experience crap, read them, I'll wait, then come back. Is the writing that great? not really, but it makes a point of showing you just how fast things can spiral out of control while battling the disease. A lot of them also cite their own experiences with depression, some getting mad with the way they portray depression after suffering from it themselves. I'll say right now I have suffered from everything explored in this, yet I would 100% recomend this to anyone who wants to try to understand depresison more. Bercause thats all you can do, is try to understand it, since it is experienced vastly different between each person. This"game"/ experience was made so that people who have no experience with depression a glimpse into the life of someone who does. This obviosuly means that things will be seen as laziness instead of symptoms of depression because guess what?
THAT'S HOW PEOPLE WITHOUT IT THINK IT IS. THAT'S IT. This is not a ""game"/ experience for those recovering/still suffering from depression, this a game for those with no experience with it, SO STOP TREATING IT THAT WAY. 10/10 would reccomend for anyone who wants to learn about depression and how things can spiral out of control.

This game reminded me what it was like when I was severely depressed. It also reminded me that I, like the protagonist, have come a long way. 

I don't think the protagonist was portrayed as lazy, and I don't think it was cheap that some of the "better" options were not allowed to be picked. I think some of the people writing reviews forget that every person is different, and depression will affect people differently. Not every person will have the inner will power and determination to fight through their depression, especially since for the first third of the game, the protagonist didn't even acknowledge that they had depression. 

Also, it makes no sense to me that people are giving this game a poor review simply because it's a free game. Seriously?

22682956.review:
I know that this isn't intended to be a "game" in the sense that you have fun and find creative strategies to meet your goal. It is a story. A story that addresses a very serious, and often very misunderstood, issue. So I'm not going to judge this based off of the usual aspects I might on any other game in any other genre.

This *experience*, from start to finish, was honestly a bit terrifying and often hit too close to home with me. I have depression and a lot of the scenarios the protagonist experienced felt as though they were ripped from my own life and molded into text. It was relatable. It was honest. It took an issue that so many find difficulty discussing and brought it into light. I actually cried at some points, won't lie. In my experience, things ended on quite the optimistic note. Things seemed to be getting better for the protagonist and, reading through this, it gives me hope that things will get better for me too.

I doubt the creators of this game will ever read this, but if you do, I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart. Depression Quest is an absolute treasure.

22574332.review:
Honestly, I'm not sure what everyone is complaining about. 

Yes, the game is very simple and doesn't offer any real gameplay. It's lightweight and there's not a whole lot going on with it. 

It's also free, as in zero dollars, and you can delete it if you don't enjoy it. At $5 or even $2 I feel like I'd be giving a bad review since there isn't a lot of content here but for zero nothings it's a neat thing. 

The developer makes a clear note at the beginning of the game that this is not supposed to define depression or be exactly like any one person's battle with it, however I did find myself almost eerily relating to it at times. 

I thought a very cool part of the game was how you were not allowed to select the "best" option. For instance, it gives you the choice of "Go to the part reluctantly" and "Stay home" but you cannot select "get over it and go and have a good time" because from this person's persepctive, that's not even a possible option. I relate. 

It is mostly pretty well-written, not amazing. Simple language and vague details I suppose in effort to make it more relatable. 

The music is okay, nothing special, but you can switch it off if it irritates you. 

The game is very short, I played through the story in about 20 minutes and I am not a particularly fast reader. I tried a second arc where I picked all the "worst" options and while much of it was the same it did provide some different results and a different ending. 

I will agree that there's not much to this game, it's short and overly simple. 

However, I found it relatable and at the whopping price tag of free I think it's neat. 

If you're looking for action-packed adventure, this is not even vaguely close. 

If you're looking for a robust and detailed game, again, not for you. 

But if you take a look at the screenshots and read the description of the game and it sounds interesting to you, it probably will be.

22511485.review:
Como historia interactiva y un focus group de consumidor hombre rata, esta de antemano la idea de lo que define un videojuego y si este lo llega a ser o no, más allá de ese “debate” me parece que DQ lográ algo especial  a nivel personal, para quienes han lidiado con una depresión o lidian con ella encontraran probablemente explicación en aquellas lineas  de acción a elegir  -ytambiénlasqueteniegan- a algunos de sus comportamientos.

No solo es un ejercicio de exploración personal sino uno de empatía, es más que necesario pensar la depresión no solo como una causa de deterioro psicológico que encuentra razones e impactos  en la individualidad, sino que las condiciones de las sociedades con ritmos de vida estresantes, niveles altos de competitividad  y fragilidad en las relaciones personales, facilitan que todos vivamos momentos con trastornos en nuestro estado de animo, baja autoestima y una perdida del interés incluso en lo que más deseamos. 

Trabajar y  no sentir ningún tipo de crecimiento personal, tener miedo a emprender nuevos proyectos y que finalmente el miedo los transforme en desinterés, sentir desorientación frente a nuestros caminos de vida, dudar de si mismo, imaginar que nuestra pareja se fija en alguien que no tenga problemas personales tan grandes, considerar que se tiene mucha más confianza con amigos en la Internet que nunca hemos conocido, son situaciones similares y perfiles que logran identificar a una generación desconectada, por eso le doy el sí al DQ ♥.

22382065.review:
Terrible. Just a terrible mess of a game. 
Where do I even begin? From a gameplay standpoint, it's boring. There's nothing visually stimulating (and while I realize that's not the point with choose your own adventure games-but something semi-decent would have been nice, a background to simulate scene changes), and it's all too easy to get the good ending if you have even a sliver of an idea how choose your own adventure games work. The story is bland at best and does nothing to suck the player in and make them care about the character their playing as. Honestly, 3/4 of the way through and I found myself skimming the mammoth-sized paragraphs of crap just to get to my options. Speaking of options, why cross out the ones that would actually help you? I'm speaking from an odd position here, as I have never been diagnosed with depression, but it feels strange that, in an attemtpt to simulate someone being depressed you wouldn't present the helpful option as an option. To the people who played this game who actually have depression, did that feel condescending at all? Plus, the character is completely self-absorbed. There's a point in the game where one of your friends is having some nasty issues in their life and instead of consoling them, you can choose to just ignore him because you feel that you have it worse. Even though this person is a life-long friend you can still opt to turn your back on them. And a trigger warning? Really?

Would not recommend this game if you're looking for something good to play. Would recommend this game if you want to have another reason to dislike Zoe Quinn.

Locking the options was a terrible thing in my opinion, leading the MC to an endless spiral of unworthy feelings, when I actually wanted to help them. Character development wasn’t good either. MC was too plain, I couldn’t feel any sympathy for them, same for the other characters. This could have been a decent/good game (I honestly believe that), but it’s not.

Please don’t treat this subject like a superficial aspect. I know this wasn’t meant to be a “happy game”, but it’s not that simple.

21970294.review:
Just finished the game. Despite the short amount of time it took to complete, it felt like an eternity.

I wanted to give it a fair chance, but there was no game here. The design of the game is just lazy. It's so bland and uninteresting to look at that I really couldn't focus on the story. It's white background, with black text, and a picture on top that pertains to the story.

Whenever I could actually look at what was going on, I was extremely disappointed in the lack of originality of the situation I was in. The story is that I have a girlfriend and family who all love me and are concerned about my depression. WHOOP-DEE-DOO!!! I got excited when someone gave me a kitten. I thought that would make it a good game, but the cat POSSIBLY only shows up one other time. There was no connection with any of the characters really since they're all nothing more than cliches.

The game has a total of ONE TRACK of a short piano piece on a loop. There will be background noises sometimes depending on the area which can make this short track even more annoying than it actually is. I would go insane listening to it as I merely got the gist of what was going on. I can't imagine what would happen if I took the time to go over all the details.

The whole thing about this game is making choices. It doesn't matter how many choices the GAME says there are because in reality there are only two every time. There can be 6 choices the GAME gives you, but there are really only two. It lists some options only to cross them out because you're "TOO DEPRESSED" which is just the most infuriating thing a game about choices can do. I understand my character is depressed, but don't tell me you're restricting my options because of this. Depression doesn't mean incapable of choosing to do enjoyable things. Depression doesn't make some options impossible, but it does make some options more difficult to make because of the emotional weight that just doesn't seem like something to bring around other people. The choices that were presented in this game seemed like they were made to guide the player towards one over the others. I can't choose the crossed out option, but I can choose the option that's the crossed out option with different words. The obvious right option sometimes is actually not always the obvious right option for someone who isn't depressed. The writers basically assume that this is how a normal life should be and anyone who isn't living like this is depressed. I don't have time for parties, internet interaction, and Netflix with a girlfriend when MY JOB is on the line. Depression should have nothing to do with that. Do my choices really matter? Only when it comes down to choosing to see a therapist and taking medicine is when it truly matters. The game is always telling you that you're not doing those things, so obviously the player can deduce that those are the things that must be done in order to win the game. In the real world a therapist and medication does NOT fix all cases of depression. Sometimes these things cause people to become more lost and more depressed.

I do not believe that this game depicts depression exactly. There are many ways people can struggle with depression and I've only seen one very generic and uneducated depiction in Depression Quest. The writing is made to make your character obviously sad when sometimes it's not always so obvious even to those affected by this terrible state of mind. I, along with some of the other reviewers here, have struggled with depression and know how it feels. The game gives a trigger warning to anyone who has been depressed that this game might be too real and may emulate our own lives too well. IT DOES NOT!!! If anything it offends and belittles anyone in this very serious condition. I know it wasn't their intention to do so, but that's how I feel about it.

Depression Quest is a pretentious way of bring attention to this issue. I'm not even happy that some of the money they receive to support this game goes to the Suicide Hotline. It should ALL go to the Suicide Hotline. It's insulting to think how these people have made money off of this. At the very least, it is at the least totally free if we choose it to be that way.

1/10 since it was free. Play it if you want, but your time is better spent elsewhere.

Maybe I experienced the game differently. I definitely thought the protag was whiny and the writing was a bit pretentious, but I didn't get the sense that the game was making them out to be lazy and selfless, more that the depression was crippling their motivation and made it hard to find interest in the things they normally do.

For people saying that all the positive choices were crossed out, yes, the [i]most[/i] helpful ones were, but there were still positive choices (usually the second option - this game has a tendency to list options in order of most-to-least helpful with a few switch-ups thrown in now-and-then, which I find a bit weird but w/e). I installed this game a while ago, reluctant to play it, fearing it would either be too real or make light of depression. This game is one of the most accurate and detailed explanations of how it feels to be depressed. I recommend playing it if at the very least to give you some terminology to use when explaining to others how you feel other than saying "oh man i'm just real sad lately". Even if you aren't depressed you should play this game to better understand that friend of yours who is.

~Edit~
Okay so without getting too personal on the steam reviews, I played this game four years ago when I was in a really bad place and even though it wasn't exactly fun it was sort of reassuring to know that other people had also been there and knew what I was going through. 
  I played it again recently just cause it popped up on my "what to play next" thing and I was really surprised and very happy with the wildly different outcome I ended up with. 
  The first time I played it my depression completely took over my life and ruined everything as I suppose it tends to do, but as I played it the second time I noticed I slowly got my life together and managed to live with my depression. I'm in a much better place these days and though I still have times when I feel depressed I don't feel like it runs my life anymore, and my nihilistic attitude has all but disappeared. 
  I suppose this isn't really a review for the game but when I played it the second time and saw significant improvements to my mental health it was really comforting. It made me feel like even though there are still gonna be rough patches I'm actually starting to get better. So thanks.

21569781.review:
I saw the many negative reviews, read some of them, and knew what was going on.
The fact that there are so many negative reviews is indicative of the very thing that is one major cause of depression. Things like complaining that not all reaction options are available or criticizing an allegedly clichée or cheesy or pretentious writing or how the music is dull and repetitive shows a horrifying lack of empathy, a refusal to see and experience a situation from someone else's viewpoint or to even look at it; upset of not being handed an I-win-button, annoyed by discomfort, by the game tucking at things suppressed in the psyche.

I suspect that at least some of the negative reviewers who claim they have been through depression themselves and this game is no good for portraying that have merely been 'successfully' conditioned into dealing with an uncaring world by becoming more uncaring themselves. Because if you can't stand the pain anymore, you have to become the pain. But everybody just becoming as egotistical as the society that affects them is not a solution, but the very expression of the problem.

The general emotional experience of the player character I can relate to a lot, while many situational elements not, but that doesn't matter. This game is art in that it conveys an experience to the player, so I guess it is only natural that all those who are fueling the problem will not like it. This game is like an enactment, through showing the mirror and making people attack their projection or focus on evasion points.

Its high negative review ratio is like a representative for the emotional distance and uncaring that depressed people might have to deal with every day.

It was easy for me to come to a very positive outcome, just by choosing what I would have chosen in a real situation, not even the supposedly strongest, ideal decisions (if there even is one, because everything has up- and downsides). The player character is relatively lucky. Other people might not have any of the potentially positive influences available to tap into. For them it might be a losing game from the start. Unless we change that.

If the negative critique points mentioned are your grievances, too, then take that as a sign that you are not helping with your current mindset. And maybe I shouldn't even say mindset, because as this game conveys quite well, the mind alone cannot solve problems of the heart. It is caring and the will to make an effort for a better world, to accept inconveniences based on empathy for others, that solves such problems. And that requires a certain amount of courage. Not so much the kind of courage that makes the warrior wield a sword against a foe, but the kind that makes him cut out a parasite from his own body.

https://twitter.com/Dowlphin/status/704736089823645703
All the mind can do is square the circle, but it can never remove the sharp edges that cause injury.

https://twitter.com/Dowlphin/status/701880481181208578
True caring hurts.
That's why it's unpopular.

21311030.review:
I'm another person who suffers from depression, and while the game didn't capture all of that feeling, it did resonate in creating scenes that I certainly recognised from my own life. In that it was successful, although this also led to some trepidation before playing - as a sufferer, I didn't feel the need to revisit what I already experience, especially as it was very likely to remind me of my own difficulties.

I gave it a shot, mostly because I'm at a point where I felt I could explore this theme, and I wanted to see how others have handled expressing it. For me, in my play through, I was pleasantly surprised. I started by making the choices that I knew I would make in real life, and that led downward. But then I started doing what I knew I should do - seeing the therapist, taking medication, confiding in friends - and as you do that, the game rewards you by showing you that those choices can help. It was oversimplified, but close enough to real to be encouraging.

With that said, I'm not sure that this is a game that will help sufferers, but I gather that wasn't its intended role. I remain nervous that choosing the wrong options could lead you to the conclusion that you are stuck with depression, and accordingly I think I'll remain with this one play through for a bit. However, the settings are close enough to real that it might help non-sufferers to understand a tiny bit of what depression can feel like, and maybe help everyone understand that there are ways out. And this seems like a very good thing.

Overall, after months of being wary, I'm glad I finally found the time to play it through. I'd recommand it, but with the proviso that it won't be for everyone.

21267053.review:
Okay so real talk from someone who has had clinical Depression since they were 9.

Depression sucks. Big time. A lot of the thought processes, situations, and dialogue that are used in this 'game' are somewhat relatable to some of my own experiences. The not feeling good enough for your partner, being emotionally exhausted, having to pep yourself up for menial activities...It's a lot more difficult than people realize, and I will give some credit to Depression Quest for trying to shed some light on that, for the small hints of it that are there. 

However, while I understand what this was trying to accomplish, there are better ways of doing so. This is not a game. It is an interactive journal essentially. It is trying to be a new-age look into a 'deep' soul that ends up sounding very pretentious. I just know most people do not want to sit and read walls of text(s) of sad things, which is probably one of the major reasons Depression Quest has been so negatively received. There's also the fact that the story overall really isn't even that engaging. I started skipping over entries after the seventh one and just clicked the most positive options to get to the end. I also can't stand the title. As another reviewer stated, Depression is not a 'quest' where you get a nice little reward for making it to the end. It's draining and exhausting. It's learning how to cope and when you think everything is fine and figured out, the rules change again for no reason. Basically, it's not nearly as straight-forward as this 'groundbreaking game' claims to be.

I read a bit on Zoe Quinn and her desire to create a more straight-forward game because all the ones dealing with Depression are more metaphorical and about symbolism (which I prefer personally). Well, congratulations Zoe. You created your snorefe-masterpiece!

21247977.review:
I have depression, and I've seen a lot of people say they hate it, but.... I think it's spot on. I'm only 23 minutes into working on this story, and I agree with a lot of viewpoints. It's not easy being depressed, the constant anxiety, the feeling that you can't really get up and do anything.... It really feels that way. And when loved ones and parents start saying "You can get through this, just suck it up and do more with your life", it doesn't work that way. Depression doesn't work that way. I really think a lot of people that do have depression would agree with most of it. BUt, that's my belief.... I actually really like it, and it kind of helps to know at least someone knows how it feels and how it seems to effect the world around you. 
That's all I gotta say ^^"

You're given a situation that's depressing. Below are choices to what to do (with the first choice (which is positive) being crossed) and will effect how you do. Overall this game is not to be taken lightly and should only be played when you're certain it won't get to you.

Depression Quest is one of the most skillful games I've played.
It has an interesting mechanic which causes mouse-clicks on the given options to sometimes be completely unresponsive, requiring the player to click repeatedly if they want to achieve a good completion time.
Most gamers don't consider the potential for menu-based games to be good for competitive or challenge-based play, but Depression Quest blazes a trail in this area.

20740421.review:
I've played this before on the interwebs. Might as well toss out a token review.
For a game that causes grown men to go into fits over the dreaded ess-jay-dubyas, this isn't a terrible intersectional game. The main character doesn't have any money concerns, has a steady job, a supportive girlfriend and at least one supportive family member, hits the jackpot on their first time visiting a therapist (it took me about four or five tries to find one that clicked), lives in a location that allows them to keep a cat, and doesn't seem to suffer any ill effects from race, religion, physical disability, age, or gender.
As a long-time sufferer of depression's smaller cousin, dysthymia (if depression is a big black dog sitting on your chest for stretches of time, dysthymia is an overweight cat that lays on your head and never leaves), I recognized a lot of the situations presented in the game, and the options for action described pretty well actions I might have taken. Although I really wish getting help were as easy as clicking a link in a Twine game...
All in all this game doesn't merit the hate it gets. So thusly I give it a recommendation. It's not a Half-Life-esque landmark game... but it deserves to be appreciated for what it is.
I hope that somewhere, somehow, thisgame  makes a grown man-child dudebro cry. I hope it makes him recognize depression in himself or someone he loves. I hope he can become a better person because of it. I hope like hell.

Not that depression is fun but the fact that your choices affected you in different ways. I saw a review that read something like "this is kinda a slap in the face, I have depression" and at first I kinda agreed but there was nothing that really bashed on depression or made light or fun of it. the morale of the story is to fight depression instead of letting it keep you from living. Not many people would go and google "what is depression and why should I be considerate of other people". 20655652.review:
The feeling of having no motivation, getting no enjoyment from anything, and believing that by getting help you're just inconviencing others, are all things that this game tries to portray as well as it can. So while it does fall short in terms of length and actual gameplay, it at least makes a effort to try and emulate the real ways that depression slowly eats away at you like a crippling disease.

The fact is that in the end it actually displays the effects of depression better than most other games, movies, and TV shows. Because depression is a monster in your closet that you can't ever be rid of. No matter how much people say things like "Just go get help" or "Do something to not be depressed", that's just not possible because that beast called depression will always be in the back of your mind chewing on your thoughts and making it seem like every possible choice will just make you a burden on others. Often people suffering from depression will never seek help, and the best help they can receive is by their friends and family noticing the problem and getting them that help (sometimes whether they want it or not).

To sum up:

Gameplay: 3/10 (Pretty much non-existing)

Story: 5/10 (Could be much longer and more compelling)

Experience: 10/10 (For anyone who has actually experienced real depression and been diagnosed, this game may or may not be relatible to your own experiences)

Fun: 0/10 (This game is about depression and doesn't have a happy ending)

Worth it? (Price): 10/10 (It's a free game)

Length: 1/10 (Short and simple)

Overall: 2/10 as a game, but a 8/10 in terms of actual effort and care that was put into it. I wouldn't say that this is a all-time "Must play" kind of experience, but rather on par with playing through a brief educational game.


In the end I will say that it's good attempt at approaching a serious subject, and that It is unfortunately a forgettable experience.

Now, the game is well written, explaining in detail things even when I was depressed I couldn't express, and the choice based system is nice. It is a good interactive novel.
While I had such an unique experience, game could improve upon some aspects, I'd like to say that sometimes there were things which were crossed out, but if I was in the protagonist's shoes I would do just that, which sucks as I could relate better if game allowed me to do the crossed out things. 

I understand everyone's experience with depression is different, I could actually quite relate to many parts of the game. The best part is that this game is free so please give it a try.

20499882.review:
This was an unique game, and an interesting opportunity to connect with how I see  Depression. I myself have been diagnosed and struggle with clinical (or major) depression. I downloaded and played through the game today, read all of the note from the producers in about 1 1/2. My experience, and the choices that I chose throughout the game really helped me connect with the same behaivors, and the impact of my choices in real life. While the game itself may not be for everyone- and may insult or desenitize others with depression or similar diagnosis- I would say it in my mind very similar to what I myself have experienced as a person diagnosed with Depression. 

I would simply like to thank the producers for their involvement in this project, and while I may not ever touch this game again, I would recomend it to some friends- their outcomes, their resolutions may not go well, but maybe they might just be able to grasp how difficult depression can be to handle from day to day. One choice can affect everything, making positive choices- even when you feel empty, guilty, hurt, embarrest- like you are a failure or ugly inside, and don't know how to tell anyone else- That is one of the hardest things to do. No ammount of telling someone to try harder or be a better person will change if they don't trust themselves to feel safe, or to feel loved, beautiful, or capable to live as they want to. The only reason I have this ability is because I made that choice to open up no matter how afraid I was everything I did would fail. 

This might be a game to some people, but for me, it's like reliving a part of my life that I didn't know how to connect to before. So Thank you.

I know some people may not agree with my review, but please respect that this is my opinion, you don't have to agree with it, but please don't bash it.
