20468053.review:
The game makes a very important point at the end: there is not a "true" end to depression, as it is something that just happens and you can't plan it. There is so much stigma and ignorance against mental illness and I find that the game portrayed it very well, as well as the feelings of desperation, self loathing, mind feeling numb and blank all the time, and making those little efforts that although they are absolutely important to someone with a disorder, it feels like we did nothing. I found the game particularly real and it felt like reading the diary of someone that actually feels the way I do. 
The scratched out choices, who were like "the best choices for yourself" were scratched out and that makes a powerful statement: you can't just shake off depression or any other disorder, because it is  a chemical imbalance in the brain, an illness, no different than any other and it consumes you slowly.

I hope Zoe Quinn will still produce beautiful content like this in the future.

20386128.review:
I tried this game expecting a result that would match some of the critics I read, and honestly, I'm baffled. This game is absolutely fine. I have gone through a few playthroughs, and I think it depicts depression (and only depression, not linked to any kind of PTSD or any other mental or emotional disease) with a simple and neat outline. Obviously, it doesn't cover everything it could cover, and as it states at the forenote, it's not recommended for people still struggling with depression.

However, it puts simply the basic functioning of depression, it's limiting capacity and how it works as a neverending cycle if you don't step out of it, which is something most people without depression or closeness to someone with depression can't understand.

So yes, I do recommend this game, because honestly, the basics are great, and it makes some clear statements that, judging from other reviews, not even people with depression know, and everybody should understand them.

[b]Long story short[/b], the makers are skilled with the subject, know how it works, and produced a neat outline to display the basics of how depression feels and works, and also how to keep it on track.

20298002.review: Depression Quest, the game that shattered the gaming community due to alleged journalistic bias going to this game regarding her being in a relationship with the journalists.  While I cannot confirm this nor care enough to, Depression Quest is an interesting experience.  For those who don't know what it's like to have the frustration of clinical depression, this game does do a good job trying to explain it.  You really do feel for the main character who just doesn't know what to do.  I especially like the design choice of X-ing out one of the dialogue options that you or me would choose but  not someone with clinical depression.  Now it is a text based adventure and I did finish the game in under an hour.  There are different routes you can take the story like try to get professional help or keep it all bottled inside.  I did get the best ending where my character is getting help and told his girlfriend about it.  It's not exactly a happy ending, but that's how it is for some people struggling with clinical depression.  I highly recommend playing through this game once.  I am glad that it's free on Steam as even asking for a dollar is kind of a little overpriced for a one-and-done game.   I don't even have this installed in my computer anymore.  But it's free so check it out.  It's not really a game, but more of an experiece.

20215532.review: *TRIGGER WARNING.* No. This is a serious review, I'm pissed and I'm serious. I've been suffering from depression since ten years old and I can't let some game make it look like you'e just "lazy." No fuck you. You're not just "lazy." You're depressed. Depression is not as simple as an emotion. Depression is a location. That location is the end of the road, a gun to your head and screams. When your mother and father get divorced. When your mother beats you so badly child protective services has to get involved. When a ten year old child has to see his own brother accuse his non biological father after his original father killed himself. The man who raised him when he was a six. The one who did all this. And he accuses the ten year old boy's father of beating him when he was young. When it turns out the mother was cheating on the father. When you realize the garage door opening at five in the morning at night was the boy's mother going to the gym to cheat on the father. Depression is watching your whole entire world fall apart. This game just makes it look like you smoked a bit of weed and are lazy and sleepy. This game has nothing special other than depression. I don't believe anyone on that team had ever experienced depression. Because the real thing about depression is. There is no escape. It will follow you around and whenever you're having a happy moment you remember the bad moments, you always do. Even when I had no will to live, when I just wanted to end it all. I still soldiered on, I hated myself. I thought I was shit, like everything was my fault. I soldiered on because people cared about me, people loved me. People talked to me. 19791741.review:
Depression Quest provides what I feel is a very fair representation of some of the thought patterns and attitudes prevalent in those experiencing depression.  Calling it a game however, is a bit of a stretch in my opinion considering depression itself is not a game.  I am seeing lots of reviews that are written by people that seem to think that the "solution" choices being unavailable is ridiculous, but from my experience wtih type 1 bipolar disorder the lack of those options is nothing short of realistic as a representation of the workings of the mind of the severely depressed.  Hell, I would even argue that the options presented *aren't hopeless and dark enough!*  That, however, is just reflective of my personal experiences with very intense and deep depression where hygene and food intake are put completely on hold and every other thought that goes through my head is self deprecating or suicidal.  However, the authors explained the choices and decision options very well in the description when they stated that eveerybody experiences depression differently, and it is quite simply not possible to cover every single possible decision and experience angle.  Besides, if they DID manage to cram in... say 100 different decision options, it would result in the game not being what it is supposed to be - a glimpse into the mind of one "average" depression afflicted individual for the purpose of educating those unfamiliar or curious about what could be on the mind of a depressed person.

Is this title for everyone?  Hell no.  There is no happy ending or real control illustrated in the text... this is EXACTLY how MANY, MANY people with depression feel and see the world and is completely intentional.  The only goal of the seriously depressed is to make it to the next minute of their life.  The princess is NOT in another castle... she bled out in her bathtub last week.  If you expect a sunshine and lollipops style ending with just the right combination of choices, you're in the wrong place.

Does this title reflect poorly on the depressed, making them appear lazy?  Only to the grossly uninformed or those with a deeply misguided view on depression as a weakling's illness that's cured with force.  (Please F*** right off - you only perpetuate or worsen the problem)  The described emotions herein are very true to life and the lack of a real "ending" is truly reflective of the illness.

Should people give this a try for s**** and giggles?  If you are truly looking for giggles or a sense of accomplishment after  completing this, you are looking in the wrong place.  Trust me.  Uncertainty orbits the depressed mind like a moon and often eclipses the soul from the light.  People curious about the depressed or those faced with living with a depressed person absolutely should give this a go.  The reality of the depressed person won't make you smile or laugh, so this game will not either.  Reality's a bitch like that.

Do I reccomend people try this out?  Definitely.  Just know what you are getting into, and that everybodies experience and attitudes are going to be different.  Don't be a jerk - realize what the goal of this project is, and not what you want it to be:  education, not entertainment.

No entiendo el porqué de las malas reseñas en este título, al parecer, algunas personas dicen que no explica bien este desorden y que se mofa (¿?) de las personas que lo padecen; bueno, no sé qué decirles, Depression Quest te avisa de antemano que cada persona vive la enfermedad de distinta manera, su conocimiento o vivencia de esta enfermedad no tiene porqué coincidir con aquella de los desarrolladores (yo, personalmente, lo he encontrado bastante acorde con mi experiencia), y en ningún momento vi nada mínimamente ofensivo hacia este colectivo que merece, sobre todo, entendimiento; algo que creo que es el objetivo principal del juego: alcanzar a la gente que (afortunadamente para ellos) no tengan experiencia o conocimiento de esta enfermedad, y que pienso que logra considerablemente bien.
No, no es un videojuego al uso, pero es gratuito, es decir, que ni siquiera se puede uno quejar de que se la hayan colado. Ya de entrada, quien se moleste en leer, te explican que han intentado retratar lo más fielmente posible la enfermedad y que cada persona la pasa de diferente manera.
Este videojuego no está hecho para pasártelo bien, sino para concienciarte por las personas que padecen esta lamentable patología, muchas veces incomprendida, que, en los casos más extremos, conduce al suicidio. Es, primariamente, un intento de solidarizar a la gente con un problema que muchas veces, tristemente, se pasa por alto o se evita, con consecuencias lamentables.
Dentro ya de lo que es el "juego", te diré que es un text-based (es decir, que es un libro interactivo, y que si no te va leer, ni te molestes), la música ambiental es acorde con las emociones que la historia pretende transmitir y la narrativa está fluídamente escrita.
Personalmente, lo he encontrado fuertemente conmovedor (algo impresionante viniendo de mi, la verdad) y bastante cercano.
Así que sí, sin ninguna duda lo recomiendo encarecidamente, no como un videojuego, sino como una "experiencia de concienciación" que todos deberíamos probar.

19578217.review:
I downloaded this game to see if it would live up to the hype (for better or worse), and I decided to take an objective look. What I noticed first were some typographical errors, which would be negligible if not for this game being almost exclusively text-oriented. Also, since I find it difficult to concentrate on large areas of text for long periods of time, I think having a save state of some sort would have been a nice addition to the game, especially since the developer was generous enough to include a graphic showing how to "play" this game with a controller.

As far as content goes, I think that since the protagonist is supposed to be you (the player), I think that “Alex” (your girlfriend in the game) should have been a neuter character so people of all sexual orientations (not just lesbians) could better relate – there was a huge opportunity to do so, what with “Alex” being a unisex nickname, and since this game is meant to simulate what it feels like to be clinically depressed, I think it would have better immersed the player in that world.

Other than these few minor nitpicks, it does have a semi-interesting story, and as someone who has suffered from clinical depression myself, it does have relatable elements. I didn't finish because it was too long for me to complete in one sitting and I couldn't find a way to bookmark my place to pick it up later (as I stated before, save states would have been useful). I think this game could use more development, but it does have potential, and I can honestly say I got what I paid for from Depression Quest.

19571093.review:
Before talking about the actual game, I want to emphasize the first sentence of this game's description: "Depression Quest is an interactive fiction game where you play as someone living with depression". If you're expecting anything more than a text based game, think depression is just 'people being lazy' or simply don't like reading, this is not a game for you.

I've seen some reviewers complaining the character you control is gloomy, lazy, paranoid, clingy... Well, welcome to the ugly ugly world of depression! I don't think the people complaining about the crossed choices quite get the point of the game. Depression is a downward spiral of negative thoughts and emotions, where even the things you once loved cheer you up. Everything is exhausting, even something as simple as making dinner or talking to someone. You want to ask for help, but instead shut down and distance yourself from others, genuinely believing you don't deserve their attention. Asking why you can't choose the better option is the same as asking why poor people don't buy money.

I think the good and bad endings could have benefited of more differences between them, simply to emphasize the importance of getting help and support during these times. Otherwise it was a good, short, free game. 8/10

19536978.review:
I cannot in good conscious recommend this game for any reason, and I took notes as to why, huzzah! This review will be slightly nit-picky and slightly spoiler-ridden, but no one who reads this is really going to care about that.

Starting off with the very first line of this story we have this: "You are a 20-something human being". Okay, cool. But yet it reads that your significant other is named "Alex", again, not a huge deal until you realize that Alex is a female, meaning the only two demographics of "human being" that the author recognizes are heterosexual men and homosexual women. If you are a heterosexual female or a homosexual man, tough cookies hombre! I mean, why even include this if it's so obvious that this story is about a female and her experience with "depression"? to make people feel included? great job there! you couldn't even include a sexuality slider somewhere? And let's talk about the protagonist here: over the course of the story she is clearly socially awkward with what seems to me to be a rather average case of ADD.

Throughout the pages of the story you will see notifications about her depression level, and the lowest I could get it to was "mildly depressed" However, knowing what clinically describes depression and how depression actually feels like are two wholly different beasts entirely. Honestly in my opinion this person was just fed up with their awful job at kinkos or fedex, or where-ever and simply wasn't cut out for customer service. Hey, I get that some people aren't meant for that sort of job! But I don't care HOW depressed you are, you are NEVER too depressed to order a pizza over the phone, or most likely over the internet. Heck, I'm almost willing to bet that because of a bad mood you might get extra toppings on it, maybe get some sort of dessert, too!

Returning to your depression however, lets take a closer look at what you claimed to have done in order to calm your mind, shall well? Netflix. video games. playing with your cat with a laser pointer, browsing social media.. never at any point while reading through this whatever-it-is did you once make a reference to, or make any attempt to do some sort of physical activity for the purpose of stress-relief. A sedentary lifestyle, which the protagonist seems to have displayed throughout this story leads me to believe that they were not in fact depressed, but simply bored. This lack of physical activity in the protagonist's de-stressing routine may have led to additional stresses, such as an inability to deal with others and making one become quick to anger. (Which really isn't helped by the cliche nosy mother character you seem to have.) It could also explain the complete lack of progress on this "secret project" they keep whispering about. Though maybe this motherly issue is somehow related to the fact that the protagonist very well may have lead a rather sheltered life up until leaving the nest and the mother is simply putting on a harsher front to help toughen her up. In either case the protagonist is overly sensitive to perceived threats and probably needs trigger warnings when watching the news.

If all of this wasn't enough the protagonist is also quite paranoid, not to the point of delusion really, but every single thing is like "oh geez, oh man! what if! aaaarg!"  And ya know what? this protagonist needs a good slap in the back of the head, NCIS style. Not everything is a personal attack, not everything is a slight against you, In fact most people on earth have some of these effects simply due to aging. Yes, even an inability to sleep.

So, is the protagonist in this story depressed at any point? I believe the other reviews will answer that question nicely. See what I did there? you and your awful ending.. feh! this whole thing was just absolutely infuriating.

19431033.review:
Well, that was something.

So first, I won't even bother addressing the developer aspect. There are enough reviews that focus solely on the developers, and you can always read online to learn more about them.

Second, to say that this isn't a game because the only elements are role play and choice, well would it help if there was a targeting reticule and a timer so that you could make the choice quicker? Maybe include some QTEs? If so, then it'd be no different than a Telltale Game (a developer I really like, by the way). In other words, I don't buy into the game/non-game debate. Interactive fiction is interactive fiction, regardless of the level of interaction required.

Okay, so what is this? It's essentially an electronic choose-your-path adventure where the lead is already suffering from undiagnosed depression, but the decisions you make determine whether things spiral uncontrollably, worsen slightly, improve slightly, or even turn around.

If you do not suffer from depression, this game may provide insight as to what people are saddled with on a daily basis. Then again, if you are one of the types who feel people should just stop feeling sad, then Depression Quest likely won't change your mind.

If you do suffer from depression, you may find -- despite the fact that symptoms manifest differently in everyone -- elements of yourself depicted. In some cases, you may feel that every single page is ripped straight from your own life story.

I played this game like I would with any other RPG with player choice: I played the opposite of how I believe myself to be. In other words, I sought help and I opened up to the people around me, much like how I'd flock to the dark side/bathe in evil points or whatever the particular currency happens to be in the title.

In doing so, I... I felt uncomfortable. Like I was lying to myself, not to mention those around me. I felt guilty for leading them along, and pretending like things were okay. I went along with the therapist's advice, and even went out with people, and engaged my family in discussion.

Afterward, I sat for a bit and wondered why I am unable to do these things in real life.

Immediately, I restarted and chose the polar opposite of whatever I selected in my initial playthrough. In other words, how I really felt. It was disastrous. 

I sat for a bit longer. Why did I have a stronger emotional attachment to characters and choices in this piece of software compared to those around me? Around those who have stood by me, and attempted to support me?

This was all a lot to absorb. I will need to dwell on this further.

So, as you can see, not everyone will have the same reaction to Depression Quest. The unfortunate thing is while emotional and psychological variances are bound to occur, the narrative differences regardless of choices are slight. As you can imagine, the polar opposites yield dramatically different results at certain junctures, but it is otherwise the same regardless. I would have preferred to see more variety, and a few more callbacks to earlier choices, rather than copied and pasted pages that happen at preset times. Not only to encourage replays, an act that also could help people on both sides see how the littlest decision can have a profound impact, but also to make the experience more unique for the end user.

Huh. I think I spent more time writing about this free game, a 30-minute text adventure, than for anything else in my library. Food for thought.

19087377.review:
Depression Quest manages to convey a believable sense of what one might experience, living through daily life with depression.  While it won't capture everyone's experience with the illness, it can certainly serve to allow players who haven't experienced depression to imagine what others go through better.

On a mechanical level, Depression Quest is also interesting in the realm of interactive fiction in the way it tracks your character's mental health, and presents choices which may be disallowed because of your character's illness.  An interesting study on the power of the *illusion* of choice (or at least, the frustration of missed opportunity, even if certain options are never allowed to be chosen).

19040395.review:
First of all, Depression Quest is not a game in any meaningful sense of the word at all. It’s an interactive set of multiple choice questions that lead absolutely nowhere.
What the developers rather optimistically refer to as a “playthrough”, I managed to complete in about ten agonising minutes through severely gritted teeth. And no, it wasn’t long enough to get the point across; it would have needed about another thousand or two hours of teeth pulling for that to happen and still there would have been no point.
The developers have classed this as a game and they call themselves game developers; on both counts they are hopelessly mistaken. A video game has atmosphere, a plot, very often a hero, and generally looks nice and is exciting to play. This is none of those things and one of the many things it lacks is guns, so that we could all blow our brains out by page five. 
This is not a game in any sense of the word and it would be more fitting to describe it as cruelty to the depressed and self inflicted punishment. 
Games are fun, this is not, so don’t insult us.
It’s so easy to criticise the work of others and let’s face it, critics are just that; they produce very little or nothing at all. In this case, all the criticism Depression Quest has received is entirely justified for the simple reason that it’s a badly executed and irresponsible piece of  self congratulatory narcissism that should never have seen the light of day.

18962512.review:
So, I decided to play this game and give it a fair shot despite all the gamergate controversy. 

The first thing I want to say, as an aspiring game developer who hopes to one day get a game through greenlight, that if this is the new standard of what constitutes the title "game developer" then 10 year olds everywhere creating their first projects in flash can rejoice with a sense of pride in their new title of professional game developer. What do I mean by this? Well, lets take a look. 

The game itself is essentially a wall of text with a couple of highlighted text that links to more walls of text. This "game" is more or less an interactive story that follows the same format as the "choose your own path" Goosebumps books (if anyone remembers those?) After each page of text you are given a few options of how you want to react to certain situations. Each choice will take you to a new wall of text explaining your actions and following the resulting story. Some choices close off other choices later on (I assume, otherwise the crossed out choices presented to the user are arbitrary) giving the user a sense of control over the outcomes. It follows this format until the writers couldn't think of anything else to write and thus they leave it open-ended. They explain this in the game's epilogue where they conclude that the life of a person with depression does not come to a nice and tidy ending, and thus, the game would not have such a conclusion either. This would have been believable if it were not for the games writing. 

The writing is horrible. Not only is there missing commas and other punctuation that would help the reader actually understand tone and pacing of sentences, but the writing style is written at a 7th grade level. This is not an insult as many great books and stories are written with this level of vocabulary and sophistication to achieve greater audience appeal. The problem with this is that the writing randomly throws in "big" words and pseudo intellectual vernacular to give the reader the illusion that the writers are actually smart educated people. The writing, however, speaks for itself. 

This brings us to the music. I actually quite enjoyed the musical score. As a musician (I think most gamers are to some extent), I can enjoy the mood and atmosphere that the music presented. The music did achieve its goal of gradually gnawing at the player (myself) with a certain sense of beauty and anxiety. Well done!

The layout of the game was very simple. If I want to play a simple game, like cookie clicker for example, I want the user interface to be outstanding. Now, I can appreciate the fact that a game trying to give a non-depressed user a lens to perceive the world through the eyes of those who are depressed, will inevitably be a little bit more bleak and bland. This however, is not the case for Depression Quest. The interface looks like absolutely no thought went into it at all. It looks as though it was designed 100% for utility and no thought went into aesthetics. 

Now, for the "vibe" I got from the game. This game dripped with the privileged and shielded eye of a white middle class female who thinks she understands the plight of people suffering depression. It was highly offensive, as someone who has seen, first hand, the affects of depression on family members, this sort of arrogant sense of superior empathy disgusts me. This game is equivelant to a middle class white person making a game about the social-economic struggles of a black person in poverty. It is a level of arrogance that truly warrants a gamergate.

18901120.review:
There is so much going wrong for this game that it would be far quicker to list the good things than the bad.  However, I find it's often best to do things the hard way.

In the opening screen, you are presented with the statement, "This game uses audio as a part of the play experience.  We encourage you to play with the sound on."  This is not a good idea.  The music is very haunting and fairly immersive, but only for the first few bars.  It quickly devolves into a grating noise that is either looping or just played with annoyingly similar chords, throughout the game.  It does not enhance the experience.  If anything, it hurts it.

The story itself is a major problem.  As the game states, people experience depression differently, and the game can only shed light on so much.  However, the game feels lazily put together.   There aren’t many options, just a few blanket ones.  As you plod through, more types of options are locked or unlocked based on your decisions.  But even with the amount of text displayed on each page, the story was very lacking.

The characters felt like two-dimensional effigies.  You could not get attached to, or even empathize with, any of them, because there simply wasn't enough to them.  It was as if each character was their own dating website profile, with only a few words plugged into each text field.

As the protagonist continues to get worse, (or better, as it's hard to tell since it often feels vague) more options are blocked off, leaving the player stranded on a route based on just a few decisions they made early on.  Though this is somewhat accurate to reality–people living with depression find themselves unable to do even simple things like get out of bed or shower, at times–it seems to railroad the player into one of three possible routes:  The good end, the bad end, and the neutral end.

The truth is, these ends come with some loaded messages.  Productive actions will be rewarded, yet by choosing not to make productive choices you will be heavily punished.  This message is incredibly dangerous to spread to those with depression who are playing the game in an effort to feel understood.  It spreads a message of helplessness and worthlessness.  After all, you are made to feel you’ve lost the game, and downright worthless for having done so, if your choices weren’t the “right” choices.

At the end of the game, in the credits, you are pretentiously thanked for "being willing to play games that are meant to be something other than simply 'fun.'"

Even though I have referred to "Depression Quest" as a game throughout this review, it really is not.  This is a "choose your own adventure" book, or an exercise.  There are no real gameplay elements in this thing, save from being able to make choices that have lasting effects.  And yet, it is making itself out to be something better than "fun" games, despite having almost none of the qualities that make a game, period.

In fact, it's barely even a game book.  In "choose your own adventure books," the story is engaging, and what you do matters in the pursuit of your goal.  "Depression Quest" is not engaging, there are no stakes, and it's hard to tell what effect you're having.

Long story short, "Depression Quest" is, at the most, a meretricious, amateur attempt at creating a "choose your own adventure" game book, loaded with text and grammatical errors, being projected as something above and beyond other video games.  This is ironic, seeing it accomplished none of its goals.

It fails as a video game.  It fails as a game book.  It fails as a teaching or therapeutic tool.  It fails at depicting what living with depression is like (especially if you consider the testimonials I've received from friends, family, and online sources).  It even fails at being an expression of the author's personal pain, as it does nothing to instill any sort of empathy in the player.  It's all so tedious, unimaginative and even narcissistic, that it comes off as a whining teenager's journal, destroying any attempt of connecting with the player, even at a superficial level.

Worse still, the game's history renders it even more unenjoyable.  What really did or didn't happen is irrelevant.  Obviously, it doesn't make any sense that the creator would have fraternized with online game journalists for monetary reasons, seeing that the game was always free.  However, after playing the game and seeing what it's all about, it makes perfect sense that they would for pure publicity.  That is quite possibly the only way that this game would have gotten any form of notoriety.  Otherwise, it would have faded into obscurity in less than a week.  And it worked.  The scandal is the biggest reason that anyone knows about it.  It has given its creator more publicity, voice, and money than their talents could have ever brought.

That doesn't mean that the subject of depression is impossible to put into game form.  "Actual Sunlight" is one that better achieves this.  Although, some may think that it's more of a visual novel than a game, it still has more and better gameplay elements than "Depression Quest."  Better writing with a deeper, more meaningful story, and makes no lofty assertions about what it is.  The stakes in the game are clear, and you can empathize with the characters.  Its creators put thought and care into their game, despite it being simple in the game play aspect.

In closing, "Depression Quest" was one of the most poorly made, pointless things I have ever spent time on.  The creator owes $25 to every person who has ever downloaded it.

18877879.review:
I would only recommend it if you want to get someone's point of view of depression, if you need an eye opener into depression. I would not really recommend this game, after having just played about 10 - 15 minutes of the game.
Depression Quest is a game that will give you a deep insight into what a person is going through a deep depression experiences with daily life and activities. It is a choose your own adventure game that keeps track of your decisions in three ways: how depressed you are (like normal depression or deeply depressed) which affects what choices you can make, if you're seeing a therapist or not (and how much you feel motivated to going to more sessions), and if you're taking medication for your depression. 
This was a dark story in terms of how your character deals with depression because most of the choices that were crossed out were choices that had a definite yes or no answer. The choices that were crossed out becomes more frequent, the more depressed you are. You mostly had choices where you would second guess yourself and everything about people's opinion of you. 
I never reached the end of the game but it is a game that I would like to finish to see how it ends. The game does achieve its goal of making you depressed and trying to give you the same experience as your character. So it's not a terrible game but if you play it, be prepared to come out of this game with a negative feeling.

18877833.review:
Although the game creates a frame through which the player can easily see the impact depression has on its protagonist, I found the delivery to be dull and its theme too pushy. The game lacks narrative drive. Although I understand the game wanting to be authentic to how depression affects people in their day-to-day lives, the struggles of waking up, following routine, etc were boring. Maybe in that sense, the game works. I was too disinterested and disconnected with the character to care about pushing through. 
I do think the theme is important, but I do not feel like this game is a strong example for how games can capture an experience. I would like to see the theme handled with greater mastery of the medium and narrative.

18877824.review: In "Depression Quest", the game's objective is to have the player experience a situation where depression is present and to help the player realize how depression is a serious illness. The game does exactly that, as it puts you in a 20 year old man's shoes who has the ongoing feeling that he is exhausted all the time and feels down on himself. With the help of the noticable music in the background and the somewhat interesting storyline, it definitely makes you feel that presence of depression. After playing the first few minutes of the game, I was actually fairly impressed with how the developers were able to portray the image of depression through a video game such as this one. "Depression Quest" definitely achieves it's goal and takes you on one heck of a ride.

18877760.review:
It's a text adventure game, so there's a lot of reading, which is fine. I'm not entirely sure from where I got in the story before I checked out that the characteristics of your reclusiveness are even depression -- it's more of introversion. I find myself identifying with most of what the character describes feeling, despite being a relatively happy person, so it's hard for me to say that the game does a very good job of actually conveying depression.

Now, every once in a while there are options for paths that are crossed out. I'm not quite sure what's going on there, there are clearly some things happening behind the scenes to determine what you can and can't select, but it doesn't give much agency to the player if they can't really tell, at the very least, if and why their decisions have led to fewer choices. If this formula were visible perhaps there'd be a greater connection that would convey the point more.

Moreover, the effect would perhaps be more dramatic if the very first choice you made didn't involve a crossed-off option, increasing the contrast when you fall deeper into depression. To be fair, the first few choices crossed off were definitely things I myself wouldn't do, and again, I'm a relatively happy person, so there's still the question of if this aided in the conveyence. If a player were able to make these decisions, establishing a character that would normally want to, then removing that option might be more powerful, but removing that option in the first place forces the establishment of a character that doesn't really help one way or the other.

18860399.review:
This game's purpose was to raise awareness on what depression felt like to those who didn't suffer from it; which it did, but all too well. I personally did not think I was depressed, but after playing this game I had slight hesitations in my head: "Am I actually depressed?"

It delivered it's purpose all too much, with the very detailed information and sound. It felt too real, and really made me think in the character's perspective. At the same time, I was disappointed every time when I couldn't click on the crossed out option, which is obviously the option for those who aren't depressed. It seemed as though although I wanted to take the more cheery option, it was out of my reach and ended up having to take another option which I felt wasn't my first option.

18860307.review:
This game accomplishes what the goal is supposed to be: highlighting and explaining depression in a realistic way. Thus, it isn't enjoyable or fun in any sense, but it IS interesting. The music choices and visuals offer great atmosphere for the depressing content. Most of all, I like that there are choices listed that someone that isn't depressed would usually make. "Be honest," "Enjoy your night," "get the therapist without prompting," etc. However, for you, being depressed, it is impossible to make those choices. Including them, but making them inaccessible, was an important choice. 
I would only recommend playing this game if you understand that not all games are meant to be fun, but can be a social/emotional commentary.

18841666.review:
This game feels inaccurate in its portrayal of depression. None of the friends save for Amanda seem to be helpful individuals. I would hope that if I had the behavior of our protagonist, someone would try and talk to me or do something. Depression is a legitimate struggle to get out of, but this game makes it feel like a game. By trying to simulate someone’s very personal experience, you make someone with a legitimate medical issue seem whiney. You can’t really relate to the protagonist if you haven’t had depression, and from people who have had depression, it would seem inaccurate. My brother has Bipolar disorder, and has intense periods of depression. He acts completely different from the protagonist in these periods. No one supports the protagonist unlike the girlfriends and family of the real world. While some people don’t get the support they need, I feel someone would at least notice early on. If you wanted to make an impact, make the game from the point of view of someone only slightly depressed, and have game options that can make it better or worse. Starting from the bottom makes it hard for the “typical” person to get into the mindset of the depressed individual. 
	Aside from the faults in its portrayal of depression, the game feels boring. The red crossed out text is just frustrating in the early game where they are not even a conceivable option. They would be better off when they are something a player could access. The static-text is aesthetically unpleasing as it stands out from the rest of the games aesthetic. The photos on the top often feel like its going for an artsy feel, but overall they feel pointless. This game feels like it’s trying to be artsy, being important. It wants to be profound and interesting, but it comes across is trying too hard to be sad and not capturing what it set out to do. The game only got the attention it had due to scandal, and it shows. The gameplay is boring and the commentary is weak. I would not recommend the game to anyone who wants to understand depression. You are better off with an old textbook or internet entries. The only saving grace is that this game was free, so at least I didn’t lose anything other than a few minutes of time.

18628047.review:
Depression Quest is absolute gobshite. Honestly, as a person who has struggled with depression in the past, I wasn’t expecting much, but this train wreck went far and beyond my expectations. From the outset, it’s obvious the maker has never struggled with depression. The player character has the perfect friends, family and girlfriend. Additionally, the ways in which  this guy gets over his depression are the most by-the-book I’ve ever seen. Get a cat, go to therapy, take medication, talk to someone. Rinse, repeat, rinse, repeat. There were absolutely no creative liberties taken with the story at all. Quinn’s writing was also little more than a dreck slog. There were walls of mind-numbing blather you had to crawl through to get to the next boring text tree, with 4 blocked-off options because you were TOO DEPRESSED. There wasn’t really much to the gameplay, either. You got to select randomly from a bunch of random text lines, and it was outstandingly obvious which ones you were supposed to take. The sole points where the game chucks you a fastball is when Boring McCaricature is moping about a party, and if you choose wrong between going into your girlfriend’s room and nursing a Bud Lite, the game shoves a massive branding iron down your throat, shakes you about and screams “THIS IS DEPRESSION” as loud as it can. After that single incident, after which your girlfriend may or may not get pissed at you for asking if she preferred Friends or Parks & Rec, which sends the player into a spiral of depression so awful they can barely drive themselves to get out of bed in the morning. I am being completely serious. In other cases, the game seems to get Difficulty Whiplash. There are random points at which entire paths are blocked off because your guy is too glum to sit at a desk for a few hours. At other points, the obviously correct answers are right there, displaying none of the difficulty of telling someone about your depression or going to therapy. You just click a button and WHAM, everything’s shiny, cap’n, not to fret. 
	One of the most common arguments I hear for the validity of the game is that “It’s not supposed to be fun! It’s supposed to send a message!” Yes, but there have been tons of other games that have not been meant to be fun. Thomas Was Alone and the Beginner’s Guide both come to mind. Then what’s the difference between the two games? Both Thomas Was Alone and the Beginner’s Guide were engaging. They had interesting, human characters that players came to care about. Depression Quest had none of that. It was a boring, detached recounting of how depression survivors wish things had gone starring the flattest, least sympathetic characters ever created. Don’t waste your time on this shitshow. Go do something more interesting, like licking a horse’s stomach or staring at a wall.

18576700.review:
This is essentially a choose your path story. Ok, so not really a game... but a piece of interactive fiction. There is a lot of text to read, at least the first play through. You are presented with a variety of options, but choosing some may cause later actions to be crossed off. This is interesting, but it sucks a lot of interactivity out. 
I also don't like the medicate moral that I think this story is pushing. I also think that it provides an incredibly narrow portrait of depression. I respect that, because it doesn't need to. It's the portrait of a single static character rather than a dynamic one that morphs around the player.  I think that using a more dynamic character scheme would have increased replayability, however, I'm not going to count that against the game. 
The problem lies in the way it quickly degrades into cynically clicking the remaining available options. After the first 2-4 reads, you realize that very little changes with each play through except the ending. The ending only changes depending on choices. There is nothing to encourage a player to see all the endings or to try new combinations. Maybe there isn't supposed to be. I don't know.
There are some spelling and grammar issues, but having been an avid interactive fiction player I've noticed that that isn't uncommon. I note this because a lot of reviewers bring it up. Sure, they could update it with better spelling and grammar. Or they could move on to another project. Most choose that latter and it's not a bad choice. Most interactive fiction isn't professional, but made free to play by hobbyists for hobbyists. 
Does the game achieve the goal of creating the atmosphere or portraying a singular portrait of depression? I'd say yes. Others might and do disagree. I wouldn't say it is the best at portraying depression. Calunio's Depression is probably the best representation I've seen. A major difference is perhaps that this game gives us a character that is incredibly human. We see her as human and as another individual entity, but we achieve only the closeness of an onlooker. Calunio's Depression works by giving us a shell of character and starts with conception. In black and white, the player must slowly and painfully grind to walk a short jaunt to the boss. You win, but he curses you so that with every new screen you arrive, you lose experience. Every new scene causes an exponentially greater experience loss. Meanwhile, you are questioned on the nature of happiness, and no matter how hard you attempt to level, you are never the strongest. Before you lies a tower that seems impossible to climb, a final challenge. Can you reach the end before your curse overwhelms you? Depression Quest may portray a story of a depressed lady, but Calunio's Depression gives out a depressing atmosphere drags you into it (for good or ill.) The powerlessness felt between these to games are incredibly different in both nature and magnitude. 

At the end, I'd merely say Depression Quest is heavily flawed. I wouldn't recommend it to most people I know. It is free though, so maybe try it sometime. Choose for yourself.

Well, as it turns out, this game was a true eye opener for me.

After playing this eighth graders rendition of depression through fanfiction style writing, I now understand how hard it is for people who are self-diagnossed depressed to cope with their every day life. 

Thanks to this game, I now know why they can't make logical choices in their everyday life- they're crossed out and made unable to select! Just like in this game!

I noticed that there's full controller support, which I thought was totally needed, as this 'Read n' Click' was made a thousand times easier by being able to press a button on my controller instead of having to scroll and click. 
Thanks Zoe Quinn!

Overall, this was a great depression simulator, giving me the best experience of living the first-world life in a state of constant sadness any game could offer!

9/10~ Would self diagnose again!

18175885.review:
The writing style is bland, the presentation is completely unengaging, the music is grating, and despite all its attempts to present itself as a game about depression, one gets the sense that while the writers may have read about depression once and maybe even had it at some point, they have no idea how to communicate this fact outside of simple description of symptoms, and have an even weaker understanding of the concept of a "game". 

A far better approach, if you really want to understand what depression is like, is to read Allie Brosh's now-famous account of her own struggles with it, or if you prefer to do so in the form of a video game, try playing Winter Voices. For all the bugs and interface problems Winter Voices struggles with, it does a far better and more engaging job of portraying depression and grief, by taking advantage of the fact that it is a video game in order to represent things more abstractly and truly draw in the player, trying to make them actually engage with the subject matter.

Depression Quest is like reading the most boring and linear Choose Your Own Adventure book ever printed, one where all paths lead in roughly the same direction to roughly the same ending and the serious subject matter is treated so blandly that there's just no reason to give a ****. They say real art makes you think, and this game does make you think, but it makes you think "wow, I'm bored".

It's bug-free, playable, and costs $0, therefore it's already got several legs up on Aliens: Colonial Marines, but otherwise just not worth anyone's time, even as a curiosity.

I don't need the sad music to try to tug at my heartstrings. Depression is horrible but it's also mundane. I guess the issue comes down to that because everyone experiences depression differently, you can't really nail it down with one interperetation, and I feel that the biggest flaw of the game is that it seems to introduce itself like it is THE interperetation. 

Overal, tenuous recommendation if you know people with depression, but not recommended if you already suffer, because you likely won't take anything helpful away from it.

17905116.review:
I'm recommending this game because it is the best (only?) example of its genre, which makes it worth playing.  But believe me, there are things which would make it a considerably better game as well as a considerably better educational experience.

My overriding impression is that this game would have benefitted a great deal from having a depression specialist on board as a consultant, preferably one with clinical experience.

For example, the protagonist seems to have serious social anxiety issues.  While legitimate, this is not the same as depression, as any expert (or well-informed amateur) can tell you.  It seems a disservice to those trying to learn about depression to conflate the two.  Though depressives often appear to be antisocial to their friends, in many the phenomenon stems from issues which have nothing to do with anxiety.

Furthermore, it seems to me this role-playing game (in the truest sense of the word) would have more impact if it allowed more limited healthy options, especially early in the game.  For example, cognitive-behavioral therapy explores the differences between low expectations of enjoyment of activities and the actual enjoyment unmotivated depressives sometimes ultimately derive.  It is about experimenting and taking risks.  Without any options for experimentation, the game provides an effectively pessimistic prognosis for mental illness but hardly a realistic one.  The game represents depression as a problem that PRECLUDES any therapy at one point in the game--quite literally, "Call the therapist's number" is crossed out in the game, blocking you from choosing it.  Because depressives never see therapists, right?  Facepalm.  So many negative reviews of this game deal with this frustration: The game is presented as a role-playing game but does not offer sufficient choices to meet that implied promise, with choices too limited even for--and this is important--people with depression who are role-playing the game.  Depression has legitimate challenges even for people who DO seek therapy or other healthy options, but the game glosses over that fact by forbidding you even to choose those options at certain points in the game.  I get it: the game wants to limit your choices based on how healthy you are, which is in turn determined by earlier decisions in the game.  But this sense of being railroaded into a particularly unhealthy path happens right at the beginning of the game, which probably is what created the intensely negative reviews.

I am impressed with a few of the details, many of which may be unknown to those without experience with the illness.   For example, describing your condition as "feeling ill" or "not feeling well" when you have to cancel a social engagement, because people don't understand "I am depressed."

There are a few English problems here and there, which always annoys me.  Since when is your friend Amanda a "they" or a "them?"  And a number of others.  The game could use with some editorial polish, for sure.  By the way, it's "lying in bed," not "laying in bed."  Unless you are a chicken.  This game is chock-full of this particular mistake ("lie" vs. "lay").  And a few other content (not grammar or punctuation) mistakes that won't be caught by a spell-check.  Also, "it's" = "it is" and "its" is the possessive form.  Copy-edit your damn game!

Playing the game a second time, and playing around with different options has made me notice little pedantic jabs at your choices that make this seem even less like a legitimate choice-driven game.

The biggest challenge for a game like this, in my opinion, is making the experience accessible and coherent to individuals who have never struggled with depression.  In this area, I think the game sadly fails, and I think all the negative reviews are a direct reflection of this fact.  Limited choices are fine, but limitations need to be comprehensible to those who are playing the game, and that's where the game needs work.  It's definitely trying for that, but doesn't quite hit the mark.

I'd love to see a remake that focuses more on this kind of accessibility.

P.S. Valve, please allow us to post full reviews.  Having to post a one-word review and editing it afterwards is a really crappy workaround.  Get on the ball already; this is a really basic thing to ask for.

17682149.review:
A short, original video-game-inspired experience. It's free, and your only commitment is time -- an hour or so. I would generally recommend it.

It will give you a view into "depression," but only in an extremely narrow sense. Though the important introduction page explains the premise, it does not do so well enough. It is sure to alienate many people who feel that this story has nothing to do with them or their lives.

Actually, I think this game is valuable exactly because of that.

It's an ethnographic glimpse at the life of an [b]extremely[/b] specific cohort of people: middle-class millennial Americans, most likely white. The issues won't speak to many of us: being invited to college parties, working a 9-to-5 job, trolling Craigslist for new jobs, owning a car, living away from one's parents in one's own apartment, having a girlfriend, watching Netflix, being able to afford and have access to therapy, etc. It's not just an issue of "privilege," as the introduction points out. Some of these culturally specific aspects would actually seem like [b]punishments[/b], rather than privileges, to many people in the world. Living alone, away from a supportive family? Who would [b]choose[/b] that? It's amazing that this entire cohort of people doesn't suffer from depression.

But that's where this game seems valuable to me: it's a window into the lives of this strange generation of people, who manifest in their personal, interpersonal, emotional worlds the brunt of capitalist America's crushing isolation.

We all live with capitalism, even if we're not self-centered millennials. We all can sympathize with aspects of the protagonist's life, even when it's unfamiliar (and annoying) to us. It's good to think with.

I do wish the developers put a bit more effort into the presentation: the design is drab, and though the music is fitting, it would have been nice to have some variation. I didn't expect to be entertained, but a sleeker experience could have made this effort more palatable.

A personal message to Zoe Quinn: stay strong and keep doing what you're doing, because even if it's not everybody's cup of tea, it touches many of us and adds something good and useful to the world. "Gamergate" is an embarrassment to any decent human.

Finally, I would like to thank the developers for supporting Linux!

17666777.review:
I think the most important thing you have to remember is that this game doesn't have "right" or "wrong" answers. This isn't something that you have to try and win, because that's entirely not the point. Some people might hesitate to call this a game, but I think "interactive experience" is a bit less catchy. Nonetheless, it can offer you a bit of insight into depression that simply talking or reading about it won't achieve. Things like being unable to bring yourself to act upon options that seem so obvious or effortless to "regular" people, and how frustrating that is. Being fatigued by repeated interactions with well meaning but oblivious people that offer no solution or resolution. Finding occasional comfort in unexpected places.

For those complaining that this game isn't an accurate representation of depression, I'm not sure if you've actually played it or are able to read, or understand humanity at all, because if you did, you'd have seen on the very first page that it doesn't pretend to represent ALL cases of depression, nor is that even possible since, besides the innumerable different types of mental illnesses out there, everyone with even basic depression experiences it differently, and live with it under unique circumstances. What I got out of it was a familiar retrospection of how my life and experiences had been several years ago, and occasionally (but fortunately rarely) still relapse into every now and then. But it wasn't exactly the same obviously, as I'm not actually dense enough to expect a 30 minute free game to somehow perfectly mirror my whole life experience.

Depression Quest is very honest about merely being an attempt to provide people who know and care about someone who has depression a bit of potential insight into their otherwise private and closed off lives and consider what sort of reactions from loved ones help and what actually makes it worse, despite the best intentions.

If this does not apply to you but you're just curious, it's free! 

But for those to whom the events described in the game are familiar, but genuinely struggle to explain what they are going through to loved ones, this could potentially be something valuable.

For me, it illustrated the concept of "I understand what you're going through/went through" so much better than a vague verbal reassurance that, when you're in that situation, often feels ingenuine or meaningless anyways. Just remembering the familiarity of that creeping hopelessness reminds me why the vapid suggestion that people should "just get over it" is so uselessly dismissive, and that dismissiveness comes from the lack of empathy, due to a lack of perspective. If this game can offer people a bit of perspective, that's value.

I'll admit I wasn't overly fond of the music, it was a bit more distracting than probably intended. Here and there were also a few obvious writing mistakes, but other than that, I'd certainly recommend this to people with an attention span.

17656784.review:
NOTE: This game is Free To Play, meaning this review and many others do not count. I cannot stress enough that you play it for yourself with an open mind to get an undilluted opinion and ignore this review and any others.

So... I know what Depression is. I've been diagnosed with it for the last 15 years alongside High Anxiety for all that time. 
You want to know what Depression is like? Let me tell you instead of you playing this game.
Imagine sadness. Imagine extreme self-disappointment. Imagine self-loathing to as high of a degree as it'll go. It's not always the same, but to my knowledge... Mix them into one emotion and you get Depression.
It is literally the worst emotion on the planet. Mostly all suicides are caused by feelings of Depression. I have no study, no way to prove that, other than just plain logic and understanding.

This game does not convey the feelings of Depression.

It is sad, yes, but Sadness is not Depression. On it's own that is. You need a slew of other different, but similar emotions but also the faint hope that it can get better and mental habits of being pessimistic about your life, you and everything around you.

I've played and read all lines of both endings and choice options. there's multiple choices in most cases, but in most cases the options are locked because the dev most likely didn't program that far in a text-based game. I could also say because of [arbitrary/contrived reason].

Let me be perfectly clear. This game is not depressing, it's not saddening. To me... It's insulting how hyped this game is on the store page.
It's got the pacing of a pop-up book, the writing of an overly-emotional stereotype writing about how awful life is and for a game that boasts "multiple endings" I would have imagined that the developer would've coded in a suicide ending, since I literally did every awful option and nothing really different happened.

The game is as engaging as listenning to someone whine about how awful their life is. I know, it's supposed to convey the feelings of being Depressed, but the thing is... Unless you're a wordsmith (which The Quinnspiracy isn't) then it will never work in text form.
The game would have worked better as a more interactive game that isn't text-based or an auto-biography of part of the dev's life.

While I was playing-no... While I was reading this e-book it felt like I was reading what amounted to angsty, emo fanfiction and not even good fanfiction.

Some options of the game aren't labeled too great, sometimes the result being the opposite of what you thought the option would do (so... control problems in a text-based game?) which basically boils down to those options being improperly labeled.

The soundtrack is... well it's actually just a track, one song looping over and over and not even with a clean loop either, at certain times you'll hear crackling or popping in the audio as it loops.

All in all, this game utterly fails at what it tries to do. Not only that, but it makes Depression laughable, comparable to stupid pre-teens who thinks depression is a cool thing, who we all know are a complete joke, and that's the literal opposite of Depression.

I've seen better pacing in books you can read in any library anywhere, the game wasn't at all uncomfortable for me, it wasn't like an unfiltered mental diary, more like a "pity me, I'm sad right?" type of story written by some spoiled kid who got grounded for the first time.

Just like any poorly-made text-based game, you can look at the first sentence/paragraph, the last one aswell and essentially miss nothing story-wise, ignoring everything inbetween, only with this one, you can look at jsut the last sentence or two and know all you need for the next decision.

The Choice-based content is actually true to a degree, but the multiple endings are comparable to Mass Effect 3's "What color will your ship's explosion be" type of ending, each one summing up all you've done, with ONE sentence of difference ignoring all else (summing up your run doesn't really count) which doesn't matter because this game is extremely far from being long, even if you read it all. I stopped reading all but the last sentence and first one halfway through.

Pros:
- Content based on Choice is true to a degree.
- The "art style" of the game works decently.

Cons:
- Completely makes a joke of Depression.
- Fails to give an understanding view of depression to the player.
- Text drones on about the player's awful life and at times feels like empty complaining and whining.
- There isn't really music, just ambience with awful loop crackles. It loops 3 or 4 times in a 15 minute period.
- You can ignore most of the text without loss of story/choice context.
- Some choices are literally always locked no matter what you do.
- There's a choice or two on the first screen that is locked.
- Due to the third point, the game is dull and couldn't be further from being engaging even if it's in 1st person.
- The wording in some pages are poorly done, or done wierdly to confuse the reader.
- The Endings are technically the same save for one or two lines of text that don't change anything.

This game gets a 1/10. It makes a joke out of Depression by coming off as whiny and complaining about how awful life is, saying how awful everything is rather than using words to imply the feelings so the reader can dig and feel them that way.
If that wasn't a thing and it did what it'd do, it would be a 5/10 simply due to everything else just being passable. It's not well-made GameSpy, it's just passable. I've played many text-based games that are more well executed than this, some of them being Zork, Trials in Tainted Space and Unification Wars. Trials is in beta.

To improve it I would suggest a complete redo of the whole game. It needs or be worded better, don't tell us, make us imagine it so we can be THERE, not watching ourselves like a ghost would. Be less preachy or Emo-y (if that's a word).

I would also suggest the ambience loop be cleaned up and have the crackles removed.

Make the endings ALOT more dramatically different. Not a single sentence of difference, I'm talking the difference between a life that will continue to be happy, or literally suicide (say if you choose all the good options and then all the bad ones in another playthrough).

It doesn't even need to be longer.

Will I give it Forbidden status? Well... based on how it's been released a full year, I'm inclined to say yes, but I will hold off on that as per the usual for my statuses.

I live with depression every day. I know how it feels. This game? Not one single moment did I EVER empathize with the character. It fails at it's intended purpose.

17037343.review:
Let me preface this review with one statement:
As far as I know, I've never been depressed. I, like everyone, have had bad days, but nothing severe enough to consider depression.

That said, the mission statement of the game seemed to be that depression is more than just being a downer or being mopey or a whiner.

However, I found that the gameplay doesn't support this mission statement.

Whenever I came to a decision to make, I chose what felt reasonable to me, a non depressed person. Don't feel like going out with your girlfriend to a party? eh, just do it anyway because it will make her happy. Even then, I chose to stalk in the corner and not to talk to anyone, but it didn't seem to matter.

Should I call a therapist? Yes. Should I continue seeing the therapist? yes. Should I tell people that I'm depressed? Yes. Should I stay on my medication, even when I am feeling a little better? yes. Should I move in with my obviously loving and awesome girlfriend? Yes.

And at the end of the game, I was living with my girlfriend, seeing a therapist, on medication, with an adorable kitty and my family was very accepting of my condition. I still didn't really like my job, but I realized it was a small part of my life and just something to get through. I was being more sociable with friends and, for the most part, fighting through my depression very well.

There was never anything that would imply a depressed person is incapable of making these decisions. 

The game is, essentially, implying that depressed people are just being little bitches and intentionally making the wrong decisions.

That said, I enjoyed the narrative and the choices, though intentionally limited, felt like I could control my fate, rather than being told that I'm depressed, so I can't possibly recover.

It's a free game and it only takes and hour, and I found it rather enjoyable.

Despite its failure to meet its mission statement, I did feel like it enhanced my understanding of the thought processes depressed people go to in order to will themselves back to a good state. So I think I would recommend this game, as I have played many many worse games than this.

16827574.review:
Most of the time, we think of video games as "fun". They often have stories, sometimes involved and emotional stories, but in general video games are generally escapism or competition of one form or another. Depression Quest, on the other hand, admits up front that it is *not* "fun". It's an attempt to communicate how depression feels and impacts someone's life, and I believe that it succeeds admirably in that.

The game itself is short -- a little over an hour, depending on your reading speed -- but in that time it puts you in the shoes of someone who is dealing with depression. The story is told in text, with branching dialog trees at various points, similar to "Choose your own adventure" books or other interactive fiction. The clever thing they do at various points is to list various options, but then remove them. In most games that feature branching dialog, the good/bad/snarky options are generally very clear; BioWare is (in)famous for this. In Depression Quest, too, there are clear "right" choices and answers, and the game will show them to you, but they may be crossed out and unavailable based on your mental state. This simple mechanic is brilliant, as it accurately models how depression can feel; you know what the "right" thing to do is, but you just can't seem to do it.

If you want to know more about how depression feels, or if you're trying to understand or help someone who may be dealing with depression, this game is well worth your time.

16815116.review:
This is an interesting one, unlike anything I’ve played recently, and consequently rather difficult to evaluate. It would be misleading to classify it as a video game, or even a visual novel, and should be approached accordingly. The awkwardly titled (yet entirely appropriate?) Depression Quest is a cold, presumably personal take on depression. In the course of my first playthrough, completed in one sitting lasting about an hour, I felt it was more of an opinion piece, a snapshot of depression, wrapped in biographical accounts, situations and perspectives. 

For me, it didn’t work. The quality of writing is average at best, suffering from overwriting, repetition and a jarring form of second person narrative that too often insists on telling the reader how to feel and why. Perhaps this is intentional - one of the aims of Depression Quest, I’m told on the opening page, is to help people who do not suffer from depression to understand those who do. This could work, yet I also find that the plot was fairly generic - we assume the role of a character who is depressed for undisclosed reasons, and as a result, he or she has no energy for hobbies, work, family and friends. I’m not entirely sure what message Depression Quest carries about depression as a whole, other than that it happens. This may sound good on paper, a frank depiction of depression, the sort that doesn't necessarily have an underlying cause or meaning, but it’s akin to filming a man crying continuously for several minutes - there must be more, ultimately, to truly engage the audience, to give them a reason to care and empathise. 

The interactive element of Depression Quest is also questionable, multiple choices provided at the end of every other page of text. As with so many other choice-based titles, this creates an unsatisfactory overall narrative, and the idea that you can go back and change things, achieve the best possible ending, is in stark contrast to the realities of depression. Beyond that, it also creates logic problems - without spoiling anything, in one scenario I achieved a positive outcome, and a mere two pages later things had fallen through, without any real relevance carried in the writing. The music, too, is poorly implemented, the same piano piece, while fitting, looping over and over and in the end serving as little more than a frustrating distraction from the writing. Ambient sounds are introduced in various scenes - coffee shop sounds in a coffee shop, for instance - but this does little to enhance the experience. Nor do the images, small snapshots of images vaguely linked to the current scene, which seem to have various amounts of blur depending on your character’s depression level. This is another thing I don’t understand - depression, in my own experience, does not affect visual or auditory senses. I do not start seeing fuzzy images or hearing static no matter how low my mood is. 

Ultimately, then, I found my experience with Depression Quest underwhelming. Regardless, I recommend the title because it’s free, because a playthrough will not eat up a lot of time, and finally, because it is a personal experience that will invariably resonate with different people in different ways. If you're interested in gaining insight into one of humankind's ugliest emotions, give Depression Quest a go.

Okay, sooo...  I'll preface this by saying that there has been a lot of "controversy" about DQ in gaming spheres.  Most of us that are clued in to the gaming subculture know all about it and I'll only bring it up just this once during the review.  The only thing I will say about it is that this review is [i]utterly detached[/i] from the poopstorm.  I'm here to tell you what I think of DQ as a game in it's own right.

[b]ProTip:[/b] If that already sounds too "SJW" for you, this game is definitely NOT for you.  Don't download it, don't install it, don't worry about it.  Everyone else, read on.


[i]Download this FREE game if you:[/i]

[list]
[*] Are interested in learning a bit more about depression.
[*] Are looking for a very casual narrative experience.
[*] Are interested in what all the "hullabaloo" is about.
[*] Aren't a Burgers & Fries poopstain.
[/list]


[i]Decline this quest if you:[/i]

[list]
[*] Want interesting gameplay, such as puzzles, shootmans, or jumping.  This is not for you.
[*] Do not have an open mind about clinical depression.
[*] Are looking for something that is "fun".  This is a game about DEPRESSION.
[*] Are scurred of scurry SJW skeltins hurtin' your fee fees!
[/list]

[u]The Bottom Line[/u]

As the title suggests, this really isn't a "good" game, or even much of a game at all.  It's a short story exploration and there is no real "win" condition exactly, no highscores, no frag count, and no real "questing" despite the title.

In short, it kinda really sucks as [i]purely[/i] a game.

That isn't why you should play DQ though.  You should play DQ if you think you may suffer from depression and don't know what to do.  You should play DQ if you have "that friend" who seems nice but is always a "loner" and you don't know why.  You should play DQ to learn more about a prevalent mental health issue that suffers from intense stigma.

Is Depression Quest the "answer" to depression?  Hell no.  It is only one facet of the story.  Depression is something that plays out differently for everyone that experiences it, and no one experience is the end-all definition of the condition.  That all said, however, there were a few situations in DQ that hit close to home for me, despite other scenarios not being necessarily so.

The take-away here is that you should absolutely not feel alone and that you should seek SOME sort of help.  From family, from friends, and your other loved ones.  Depression's best ally is isolation.

Don't expect a lot from this game.  It's not a revolution.  It doesn't even say anything new.  It is just another helpful point of view in the overall discussion and nothing more.  Really.  That is it.

It's also free, but you can donate if you wish.  That's really all there is to it.  After all the hyperbole I fully expected to be forcefully neutered by a crack team of dye-color haired SJW cuck-warlords just for playing it.  Nope.  Just a regular ass little text adventure about a condition that affects many people in our societies, regardless of politics.

16368460.review:
Depression Quest is an interactive tale, rather than a game I hasten to add, that sets itself the task of emulating the experience of suffering from depression. For the most part this is achieved successfully, although due to the complex nature of the subject matter, the experience, or 'game' in itself is far from perfect.

The choice of text to respond with can at times be limited, lacking in complexity, often with one answer alluring to a positive ending, while the other choices would all be negative. Despite this, the narrative path that I was guided along had the ability to not only convey great emotion, but was emotive in itself, even reducing me to a tear or two at one point. One issue I did have was being unaware of whether there was any save game feature, fortunately the game is only around an hour long so this wasn't too much of a problem, but I was initially unaware of the length and whether I'd be able to finish it within one sitting.

To some extent my opinion may be biased, as due to my history of depression I can most certainly empathise with the main character of the story. Nevertheless, for those willing to take part in what you could call a 'Depression Simulator', there is a lot be learned from the mental condition here, or if you are like me, along with empathy there is some comfort in finding an iteration of depression other than your own. Above all this, there is a wealth of emotion to be felt from the narrative, although for the most part this is admittedly downbeat rather than happy; just a point to consider.

Either way, if you don't mind taking on a purely text based interactive story, rather than an actual game, I would most definitely recommend this title...I mean apart from anything else it's free isn't it, why not really? 

All the best to all of you by the way, especially to those of you that are suffering in any form, it can get better. :)

15883743.review:
As a sufferer of depression, I generally found this game quite comforting; if awkward and difficult. Whilst this particular story may not mirror everyone's experience of depression, the parallels expressed between this interpretation and my own experience did resonate quite well.

One caveat I will add to this however is that I worry the game may be potentially triggering, particularly for those whose depression either too closely follows the protagonist's narrative, or at the other extreme: bears no resemblance at all. This could lead to vulnerable people feeling either alienated or exposed. Whilst I appreciate the initial trigger warning at the start of the game, the idea that one linear story of depression can be truly representative of a condition so multi-faceted is false. I am certain this is something that the developers know full well, however, and they are to be commended for creating a game whose primary intention is to demonstrate some of the core problems faced by those with depression within a broad(ish) narrative, and help break the taboo surrounding mental illness. Which, despite the good work from groups such as Time to Change et al, remains incredibly pervasive.

As a game mechanic, I thought the crossing out of options based on depression level was an excellently observed way of expressing the powerlessness and apathy generated by depression.

Whilst I cannot (and shall not) speak for all sufferers, this game on a very personal level was a reassuring and truthful depiction of an iteration of depression that I attempt to manage in my life, and I am glad to have happened across it.

6.5/10
