15792317.review:
I recommend this game if you've got some idle time, as it's short, free and it paints a beautiful, sometimes upsetting, sometimes uplifting view on one of the most common mental states in the world. 

It's presented as a visual novel, it's low budget, and it shows. Regardless, if you are patient enough to immerse yourself in the fictional character through the text, I think the experience warrants it. It employs one particularly clever trick - showing you options which you want to pick, but preventing you from picking them. This gives you (the person behind the keyboard) a sense of frustration, and through that, an understanding. Those banned options go through your characters head too but, like in real life depression, they [i]can't[/i] do them any more than you can click the buttons.

It has some story telling issues, the biggest of which was that time was poorly represented. I suspect the events play out over many months, yet this isn't made obvious, and it feels like weeks instead. Also, it's "obvious" which are the better options to pick - at least when you're in a healthy mindset - but I'm not sure how it could be done better. 

If you're suffering right now from depression, this might make you feel terrible, but you might still want to persevere - it's a story of hope, as much as it is a story of depression.

15787079.review:
I've played this a few times few at this point, attempted to compare different endings, but as an interactive fiction/visual novel, the cons outweigh the pros unfortunately.

I appreciate what this game attempts to do for the awareness of depression, but it fails to do so effectively.

At first opening the game, the music tipped me off with the thought, “oh hey, that’s nice. It’s kind of sad. This may help put me in the mood and let me understand what depression is for some.”

I’ve dealt with depression in the past, and no, it’s not fun. It’s tiresome and… depressing (Lol, kind of like this review). But depression is a bit different from one person to another, so knowing how it was like for myself and some other people I’ve been close to, I was curious about how this game would portray it.

First and foremost, the writing is decent. Fortunately for the player, there aren’t any serious flaws that derail the story completely. BUT, there definitely could’ve been more elaboration on the character’s past(s) or relationships with others. There was no real detail about the player’s workplace, or even their boss. Having that relationship explored more could’ve greatly helped the story, even if it was for a short moment. 

Halfway through the game, I just stopped caring about the outcome. Which is weird for me, since I’ve trudged through some pretty boring interactive fictions in the past, including those old school text adventures very few people would ever want to play (unless you’re into that sort of thing like me).

Technically, I found this game irritatingly lazy. There’s no save function. I know this seems trivial, but even with the most homebrew of interactive fictions through platforms like Gargoyle or the InfoCom reader, there’s usually a save function. If you find yourself bored wanting to quit to carry on later… YOU CAN’T. You have no other choice but to start from the beginning.

The “branching” story is misleading in the description above. This game is marketed as an interactive fiction with decent options to change the ending, but in reality, there isn’t. Most people aren’t going to play this more than once to realize this, but there is only one ending. Sure a couple words and things may be switched around or replaced, but it’s a lie. Sure your “stats” may be a little better or worse, but it doesn’t change the context of the game greatly enough to be considered truly interactive.

And yes, I understand the crossed out options are options that would be available if you weren’t depressed, but since you’re given so little options, the variance is negligible. Therefore, replay value is at an all-time low. And even though I didn’t want to, I replayed this sucker more than I wanted to. I even went with the worst options available to me, singling me out to depressing options (no pun intended), to see if I would have a super terrible ending… it never came.

From personal experience with depression, I faced myself at the edge of a bridge considering suicide since I’m a terrible swimmer. The choice of suicide never came in this game.

I know this sounds absolutely terrible and I apologize to anybody that may be offended, but when you think the world is better off without you in it, you only drag the people around you down, that God has either forsaken you or isn’t even there, or if you killed yourself the world wouldn’t skip a beat, then yes… suicide, regardless of the stigma, is a viable option to somebody that is depressed, regardless of how terrible of a choice it may be.

An option for this could’ve been suicide, then showing the aftermath of what it would do to the family and friends of the player.

Unfortunately if this choice was made into the game, you never get acquainted well enough with your family and girlfriend enough to actually care. They overall seemed paper thin in character, and sure this detail may be thrown aside as a viewpoint of somebody that's depressed. I get that. But if you want to really grind at the readers views and heart, you need to connect them to the characters and their feelings, including the supporting characters. This may seem pretty basic, but the supporting characters are just as important as the main. And no matter how crappy this sounds, suicide could’ve opened up another heartbreaker end game scenario in the fact that your new kitten would die of starvation because you killed yourself and nobody knew about it for, I dunno... let's throw out some arbitrary numbers: 4-5 days to a week at most.

So yes, I found this game lazy in mechanic and programming. From the lack of options, lack of ending, and lack of a save function. I felt like it always ended with a sigh with no resolution. Which is funny, since the writers at the end of the game thank you for playing stating, “there’s no real end to depression.” Which may be true, but I just found lazy. For a good story, there could still of been a resolution of what happened, even if it’s, “Oh, nothing happened. You stayed depressed and went into a deeper spiral of darkness. Lost your job, and found yourself homeless.” Or, “Your girlfriend Alex, wanting to help you, excorted you to go see a therapist.” Or, “Your family, admitted you to a psyche ward, because they realized your depression got so bad, you weren’t able to function in day to day tasks.” OR, “Your IM friend Attic, realized you didn’t go see the therapist, attempted to get you help in person. You denied. So he called a Suicide help line.” OR, “ANYTHING beyond the same thing, nearly every time.”

The music was okay at first… then it got annoying. And in the end it seemed to actually add to the boredom I found with this game. It definitely didn’t help the more times I played through it. Luckily there’s a mute function in the menu, or you can always just mute your computer audio.

BUT here are the pros…

I appreciate what the game attempts to do.

The pictures getting fuzzier and turning black and white was a nice touch.

The music getting a little distorted the more you get depressed was kind of a nice touch.

I found no typos (unlike this review)

Final verdict:
This game should be Pong and Forgotten.
3.7/10 – Not worth your time unless you’re really curious. OR, you’re a diehard interactive fiction novel gamer and want a taste of everything at some point, despite whether or not you’d like it or not. Which unfortunately for me, I fell under this category.

P.S. I'll probably make a video review of this on my YouTube Channel. I know this is shameless advertising, but idc. It'll probably get me some views and subs because of the whole gamergate crap. Also, It'll knock off anybody thinking that I plagerized my own material since my Youtube name doesn't have the underscore. lol

15671518.review:
I could have written this review before I even played the game, but I like to be sure. I've been depressed for a few months and when I was reminded about this I thought I could give it a proper shot now. This game is written from the point of view of a person who has depression. I really struggled to write the word 'game' there, it feels more like an intereactive PDF document. I've heard people say that this game 'isnt even about depression' but I think thats obviously incorrect. However, it doesnt mean that it is a good example of depression as a whole either, this is the documentation of one persons experiences with depression. Several of the key point of depression have been missed out entirely and most of the interactions are contrived at best.  

The point of this 'experience' is to give you an idea of what depression feels like. Speaking from a depressed frame of mind I would say that it failed horribly and more demeaned depression that supporting it. Theres far too much focus on what the 'player' experiences than what they are feeling, which is kind of the point of depression. Things are difficult to do when you're depressed because you dont feel like it, not because the choice itself is hard. Striking through half the options doesnt make the choice harder, it makes it easier. When you're depressed every decision brings your life to a hold while you have to sort it out, you dont just click the closest option. 

Not sure if I got my point across at all well but the simple answer is no, this is not a good... Thing.

To get this out of the way, People who are actively depressed and are not seeing a therapist or taking medication should NOT play this game.
That being said, I suffer from depression and was diagnosed with Adjustment Disorder and possibly Bipolar Disorder.

Playing this game was hard, emotionally. I didn't think that I would have a problem with the issues that the game represented, but it sure got me. It made me re-count a lot of the steps that I had to take to aid my depression and anxiety. I believe that this is an accurate representation of a form of depression, not all forms, but a common form of it. This was an emotional game and definitely got to me, I teared up during some of text, started grinding my teeth, and felt multiple anxious 'heart drops' during the course of the game. It may be short, but it covers a lot of subjets and has what I would think is quite a bit of replay value. I felt like going through the story was completely worth my time and would be for those of you who want to understand what depression is like.

I saw a lot of reviews out there about this game, depicting that it's a disgrace or doesn't actually depict depression the right way, they all haven't really played the game or have actually suffered from depression. People have stated that they were diagnosed with 'severe depression' or whatever, 'severe depression' isn't a diagnosis, if you suffered from it, you'd know for sure what you were diagnosed with. Depression is a feeling that people have, everyone has it, it's when it becomes a disorder that is the problem, people get diagnosed with disorders not feelings.

Anyways, I reccommend that you guys try it out if you aren't actively suffering from depression.

15515475.review:
Despite the controversy surrounding this game, I was very interested in trying it out. 

As someone who has had (maybe even still dealing with) depression, I was excited to see its entry into the gaming world. 

Unfortunately, I found I was troubled by the image of depression that this game offers, and I have to wonder if this could do more harm than good. 

It didn't feel as if the person the player is controlling is even a person. I felt like I was wheeling a wooden plank through a series of rooms, so lacking in personality or any distinguishable features that I found myself bored, and struggling to read the text that was telling me how I was 'feeling'. It worries me that the person this game is portraying is dull, boring, robotic. While some ambiguity and vagueness is needed in order for any player to put themselves in the character's shoes, I felt like that vagueness was taken to a point where we can no longer truly care for the character. 

I was also troubled by the lack of options. As someone who has experienced depression, I know that there are times where it feels like options are limited. But people don't express depression in the same way. I have been the person that, despite feeling like death inside, I went out, feigned happiness. I went out and did things, even if I wasn't being honest with people, and that was part of my problem. That was something I had to deal with for years, giving the appearance I was happy and healthy, when I wasn't. I was disappointed to find that so many of the options I'd have chosen, the options that would make sense to not just me, but probably many other people just trying to survive, and maintain the life one has, were just simply crossed out, as if the mere thought of doing such a thing was preposterous. 

I couldn't help but feel just a bit insulted by that. That my experience was an impossibility. 

So no, I would not recommend this game. Not to my friends, not to people who have never experienced depression, 

and most definitely not to others who have gone through what this game tries desperately to depict.

15443115.review:
I understand all the down votes this game gets. This is not so much a game as experiencing someone's journal first hand. There isn't any real progression that is experienced, the images are incredibly tiny, and the musc isn't anything to write home about. In the end, this is not a good game. However, that doesn't mean that it is something to be avoided, ignored, or rejected.
 Mental illness is hard for an outsider to understand. It's even hard for people with a mental illness to understand in someone else, due to a large variety of factors, such as severity of symptoms, what those symptoms are, support network, etc. However, I think this game does a really good job of telling you exactly what it can be like. It doesn't let you experience it the same way you would first hand, but it gives you a foundation of what it can be like.
 I myself suffer from bipolar disorder. This means I go between depressive states, and manic states. I am of the type that my depressive states are the more problematic. I was able to relate directly to the experiences of the character you are to be portraying as I have been there. This game uses the mechanics as a metaphor well to tell you how sometimes an option is not an option just because you cannot get there.
 This is a game everyone can take away something from. I issue anyone reading this a challenge. Playing through this, I want you to stop at each option and ask yourself, "What is the opposite of what I personally would do?" Then I want you to choose that answer.

15230389.review:
I played through this game twice, and I can honestly say that I recommend it. However, there are a few things you should know before you get into it.

It is exactly what it says on the tin: an interactive (non)fiction game. "Interactive fiction" fits better than "visual novel" because it's almost entirely text-based. Sure, there are some accompanying pictures, but the text is the main focus. The "(non)fiction" label fits well because while the scenarios and characters are entirely made up, the underlying premises are very real. The descriptions of how the main character feels and what they're thinking are scarily accurate for someone suffering from depression. You can tell that the people who wrote this have firsthand experience with it.

Playing this made me anxious, not gonna lie. The breezy writing style lets you immerse yourself in the main character's persona, and I had some heart-poundingly anxious moments while playing this. The scene where you talk to Attic about what's going on damn near made me cry, because he said exactly what I needed to hear in that moment.

My only complaint about this game is how easy it is to railroad yourself onto the worst possible path, and end up with the "bad ending." The choices you make at the beginning of the game have much more of an effect on the outcome than your later choices. The degree to which your options are limited in the last half of the game is a tad unrealistic; having been in the depths of this debilitating condition myself, I can say that even at my worst, I could still at least attempt to bring myself to do things that were blocked in the game. I found this unneccesarily restrictive. I understand that it's meant to illustrate the hopelessness that one often feels when deeply depressed, but it still felt unrealistic.

Bottom line: this game is not "fun." It's not meant to be "fun." It's meant to illustrate the struggles that depressed people go through every day of their lives, and I think it gets the point across really well. I enjoyed playing it; the first time through, I answered the way I felt like I would probably answer if it were actually me in these situations, and got completely fucked in the end. The second time, I was actually invested in the characters as third parties rather than actors in my own life, and tried my hardest to make things work within the context of the story, and ended up with a satisfying enough ending.

Give it a try; it's free, you have nothing to lose other than maybe half an hour of your life, and let's be honest, you'd probably squander it by watching something stupid on Youtube anyway, so why not give this a try? Try to ignore for a moment who it was that made this game, and focus on the game itself; you might be a little shaken up, but you won't be disappointed.

15191265.review:
This "game" felt real to me. Depression Quest is very upfront about its intentions and what it is. This collection of choose your own story narratives is the result of a few people and their friends/family who experienced depression using their collective experience to tell a story. It isn't the story of every depressed person at all, no matter how many variations you try to go through, but from what is there, you can get an idea of what it is like for some people.

They clearly say this and I'll repeat it. This is not meant to be fun. This isn't an enjoyable game. If you yourself are or have been depressed then you may not want to play this. It gives you a vague idea of how someone suffering might not be able to act in certain ways, and the resulting feelings they are experiencing when they make a choice.

Going through this, making choices that I would see myself making years ago, I could relate to the narrative that was told as a result. For this reason I think this is an alright way to try to vaguely understand how someone with depression might be feeling.

This is just my advice. I do not recommend choosing the "right" responses based on what you know to be the best course of action. Try choosing options that are maybe a little isolated from people. Avoid what might be considered uncomfortable for an introverted person. Don't try to act like a healthy person if you're playing it to try to understand someone who isn't.

And don't play this for fun. It's hardly a "game". It's an interactive story.

15185621.review:
I think this game does what it aims to do quite well. It makes it clear that, when depressed, there are some things you just can't do, even if it would seem like a logical course of action.

Another thing that really captures the feeling of powerlessness associated with depression is that, since it's presented as a choice-based game, the player instinctively feels like they can make good choices and somehow "win" this game... which, in the end, is just an illusion.

This game is by no means "fun", and it's very likely to be triggering for people with current or past experience with depression, but that's explicitly stated at the beginning. I think it succeeds at being a poignant representation of what depression can be that is easily understandable by those who have no experience with it.

15163175.review:
I don't get all the hate for this game. There are some misspellings and grammar errors but they are fairly minor. It's not particularly fantastic storywriting, but it's not supposed to be. It's supposed to be as accurate of a representation of depression as possible. Depression isn't romantic.

 I also don't feel like it portrays depression as being "whiny" as some people say, however it may seem that way because the person's feelings are unwarranted. This is actually a huge part of the problem of our societies' attitude toward depression - that it has to have a reason, that the person's feelings are invalid if they don't have a reason. This only makes people suffering with it feel worse. 

I feel like despite the fact that this plainly says it is not a "game", people still expect it to be. It's not, it's more like a visual novel. The reason choices are crossed out is to portray the idea that people with depression feel like some choices are IMPOSSIBLE. Whether they are or not, the person feels trapped by their own mind. If you go back and make different choices, you would find that choosing to open up, see a therapist, take antidepressants, etc. opens up more options. 

I DO wish it didn't end so abruptly - In particular, if you choose the options to not get better. This sounds really messed up, but I think the story could make more of an impact if it led to the character's suicide or self harm or something. As it is written, while the indicator at the bottom shows that you are getting worse, the story doesn't really describe it. It should delve deeper into the thoughts and feelings of the character, rather than just describing it as exhaustion, anxiety, etc. It doesn't describe the self-hatred, etc. of someone with severe depression. I think that's part of the reason people think the character seems "whiny". 

Is this game a perfect representation of depression? No. But it IS eye opening and perhaps could help some people relate to a person in their life that may be struggling with it. Depression is something that needs to stop being treated with a stigma, and it needs to be talked about more openly. Hopefully stuff like this can help with that.

Finally, to anyone struggling with depression - You can make it through this. You're not worthless. Even the smallest gestures you do can make an impact to someone else. Don't try to go through it alone, there are people that care and will help.

15162591.review: This game has gotten a lot of controversy, but I think it is a great example of a simple narrative game. It also shows a lot of the thought processes that go through the mind of someone with depression. 15151509.review:
Right away, I liked the way the game gives you information. I like that it gave you the option of getting more exposition/background details or just moving on with the story. After the gray boxes under the options started changing, I felt like I was helping my character and that the options I chose could really influence the story. I like that they show options you can't pick because of stress or exhaustion, which implies that, if you make good decisions, some of those choices may open up, and also shows how depression can make it harder to communicate with people.

I was skeptical when I first opened up this game, since, with the title "Depression Quest," it doesn't sound all that engaging. However, a few minutes into playing, I found that I was really invested in my character and wanted to help them.  I don't have depression, but I can empathise with my character with so many more things than I though I would. I have felt the "end of the week, I don't want to do anything" feeling, I know what it's like when you feel like you can communicate better through writing than speech, and the procrastination is very similar to how I deal with almost all of my work. It felt to me like my character's successes were my successes, and the character's pitfalls were my own. I felt a real sense of accomplishment and happiness when my character felt better and felt sad when they were having a bad day. 

What matters in a game is the experience. It might not be for everyone, especially if you're someone who can't get into text adventures, but this game made me feel for my character. Even though they're just a cluster of words in a simple text-based game, I genuinely wanted them to succeed. I felt accomplished, like I'd done something really good, by the end of it. If that isn't the mark of a good game, I don't know what is.

15134836.review: Boring, slow obvious "game" that feels more like reading the diary of a kid who's parents wouldn't let them shop at Hot Topic than the story of someone with depression.

15132265.review:
I've just recently been exposed to text adventure games (this being one of them) and after playing through the whole thing it was pretty well done! I had a good playthrough with mine so this is all coming from my personal experience. 
(Also anyone who plays this game I highly recommend you do something that cheers you up because it DOES get you down)

This game has hit close to home for me, I sympathize with the main protagonist on some levels. I have suffered from depression before and continue to face obstacles because of it. Before writing this review, I've noticed how people say "this doesn't accurately represent what depression is like." Everyone is different. People go through depression differently be it extreme or mild. Besides this game is only giving us a basic idea of what it's like for someone to experience depression in their daily life. It may not have been how YOU experience it but that doesn't make the game completely inaccurate.  

Now about the game itself, since you have to make choices in this game I actually appreciate having a "back" option to change your decision. Although there's no button on screen, you simply click the backspace button on your keyboard to go to the previous pages. I enjoyed reading the different outcomes and it helped to decide which route I'd rather take. 
Depending on the decisions you make, later in the game some of your choices will be scratched out. Often they are choices that may seem simple and the logical thing to do, but it's not that easy for your character who's having neverending battles with his/herself. More choices will be available to you, the player, when you make the right decisions and help your character fight against the depression. 

I must note that the audio caught my attention. The somber piano music is very mellow and slow. It is played on a loop but it honestly didn't seem repetitive to me. Each page or section in the game has more sound going on depending on the setting. There's a scene where your character is at a party and you can hear jibber jabber and party music all while the piano still plays. I think that's rather clever to keep the piano music. In my opinion it symbolizes the character's depression. The piano music follows the character wherever they go, even in a happy setting, it's always there. 

After completing this game, I actually do recommend it to others. Anyone who can be triggered easily, play with caution. If you're curious to see what it's like have a go at it. Keep in mind the experience with the protagonists' depression may not be 100% accurate, but it does offer an idea to those who want to understand what it may feel like to be suffering from depression. 

Don't forget this game can and will make you feel down, so go play some Katamari Damacy or watch cat videos afterwards. =)

15071024.review:
Surprise! A positive review!

Depression Quest was a very interesting game to play. I do not suffer from depression myself but I do have a few close friends who do. The actions that go on in the game are accurate to what my friends care to share about their situations. I like how the game brought me to the lowest place I could (it made me tear up at points) and I actually felt like what happened to the protagonist was happening to me. So, when a happy or improving moment came up, I felt like I was actually getting better. I know depression cannot be cured or solved, same as was addressed at the beginning and end of the game, but getting better is possible.

The game's physical qualities were also very cool. I really liked the static-looking effect applied to the "status" updates at the bottom of the pages. The sound effects were a really nice touch; they fit the scenes nicely enough where they did not distract me from the game's happenings. They provided good background noise so that each scene was not defeningly silent. I know that's a weird prase to say but, I often find it hrd to concentrate on reading something if there are no other sounds or noises happening and the silence itself is bothersome.

There were one or two spelling/grammar mistakes, but so little to the point where it does not take meaning away from the game's message. I really liked how Attic asked the protagonist for help for his personal issue; I felt good that I had the option to help him fter he helped so much before, I felt like I actually helped someone.

Overall, a really good game. A great experience for someone without depression to get a glimpse of what someone with it experiences everyday. I wish more people could have apprecated it like I did. 

--Drew
   3/27/2015

Do I recommend this as a game? No. I like the sound track but there are very limited choices in which to live your depressed life and you don't get much insight on things. You don't even get a technical/medical aspect of depression. I'd like some customization, a more in-depth game. Turn it from a choose your own adventure to more like Kudos, where you can pick who you are, what you do, what kind of friends you have, and then fight depression by cutting out toxic people, going to a therapist, support group, seeing friends, petting cute animals, meds, or even just forcing yourself to get out there with both good and bad consequences. Perhaps even include different types of depresison or personality disorders. It could show you what its like in a wider scope and show you how to beat it. Now that's a game worth playing! Of course, this game is free and supported on donation. So perhaps that's unreasonable. But I'd pay for Depression Quest 2 if they kick it up to this level.

14849256.review:
This game is far from perfect, but since it's free I'd recommend it to people who have about an hour to kill. BUT. Just in case the name and the description aren't clear enough, I'll say it here: THE CONTENT OF THE GAME MIGHT BE TRIGGERING TO PEOPLE WITH DEPRESSION. Also, I STRONGLY disagree with the reviewers who said that the protagonist is just "sad" and not "really depressed". There isn't just ONE valid way to experience depression and it's really crappy to invalidate other people's experiences just because they don't match your own.

So, anyway, it took me a while to get into it, but once my choices actually started mattering I found the game to be enjoyable. I also liked the way that the static on the pictures changed depending on your current status; it's a minor detail but something that I think really added to the mood. The number of choices you could make were also affected by your status, which I thought was a nice gameplay touch even though I was super frustrated that it kept me from doing some of the things I wanted to do (which, of course, is the point of the game mechanic). While I would have liked more choices that were ambiguous (ie. not clear which the "good" one was), I did like that I was able to make similar choices in-game as I have done with my own life (and that the outcomes mirrored what happened in my situation as well). For me, playing through the game helped remind me of the struggles I've gone through, what I've overcome, and that it's okay that I still struggle with things.

That said, engine wise, I've played better Twine games. I am not sure if the devs were using an old version of Twine or what, but I didn't like how the three statuses (depression, therapy, and medication) were at the bottom of the page since that meant I couldn't just look at them whenever I wanted. I also found the writing to be clunky. In particular there was too much "telling" and not enough "showing", and also in the beginning your "girlfriend" was randomly written as "significant other" and in the middle of the sentence the pronouns would switch from being "she/her" to "they/them". I am pretty sure that it was just something missed in the editing process, but it did highlight for me that the game failed to ask me what my SO's gender and preferred pronouns were, which is something that all Twine games I've played have done.

Anyway, this game is not going to be everyone's cup of tea. And I definitely wouldn't recommend it for someone who thinks they might be triggered by playing as someone who's depressed. But it's free and only 30 mins to an hour of gameplay for one playthrough, so if you're bored and in the right frame of mind why NOT play it?

14809779.review:
I see a lot of reviews talking about how Depression Quest isn't a fun game, and at least one review saying that the game reduces the serious subject of clinical depression to being a whiny bitch.

To be honest, you should play the game. I finished it in 55 minutes, and I see a lot of the reviews played for a lot less time than that - to beat the game that much faster, you'd have to avoid reading which eliminates the point of playing a text-based game or you'd have to flake out part of the way through and write a review without fully understanding the subject of your own review, IE talking out of your ass.

This is not a fun game. If you've ever played Spec Ops: The Line or This War Of Mine, its one of those. This is a game expressly created to address the issue of depression in an interactive format. I'll get the gaming stuff out of the way first.

Fun: 0/10
Reactivity: 10/10
Effort: 1010
Graphics: 1/10
Gameplay: 1/10
Story: 7/10

This is not a fun game. It was never meant to be fun, or feel like a heroic journey against impossible odds. This is a game designed to take the experience of being depressed, of feeling like you're a worthless piece of shit and nothing you do matters, and present that in a format where people who aren't depressed might understand. Since we've established that Depression Quest has little to no value purely as a video game, how does it meet that design goal?

Based on my personal experience with the game, I'd say it does. It presents the feeling of being depressed in the long post-process paragraphs after you make decisions which your character reflects on. I'm not gonna lie - you're going to need to have a basic understanding of human empathy and need to be paying attention to read through the lines and see the emotions rolling around in the character. That said, that'd also be true if you were speaking with a person who is depressed and trying to open up to you.

I can't believe I'm saying this, but somehow a free game about the experience of depression is controversial, as established by this game's history as kicking off the GamerGate lunacy. But as a simple unbiased player, I find this game unfun and a step to the side compared to what I normally go to video games for. However, that's the exact design goal of this game, and I feel it succeeds in what it was trying to do. Even the controversy can be interpreted as success, since more often than not depression in my society (USA) is interpreted as being a whiny bitch who won't take responsibility for themself.

As an experience, I give this game an 8/10, and I would recommend every gamer play this at least once.

14719750.review:
As someone who's still in the beginning stages of trying to treat their depression, this voiced a lot of my worries and concerns over the last few years.  As I read through, I did identify with a lot of the "excuses" the protagonist felt he was giving and the negative feedback loops.

Most of the user reviews for this game have been to Not Recommend it.  Some of the players have, themselves, been struggling with depression and feel this wasn't an accurate representation.  For me, it was.  Maybe just because I'm still at the beginning of trying to figure out what it actually affects in my life and what it doesn't -- what I'm "whining about" versus what's actually a result of the depression -- trying to figure out what and how meds and counselling could/should fit in -- trying to figure out (and fight myself on) what my friends/family "actually" think/do about it (though, I will say, I am lucky to have a lot of support).

It's disappointing to me that so many people felt that this narative was so ... "offensive" (for lack of a better term) or misrepresentative.  I, personally, want to recommend this to the people in MY circles, just to say "Look.  This has been me."  However, I do understand how this may not be everyone's story and how others' struggles show themselves.

I knew i had issues, I felt I was not disabled, or suffering from something out of my control, I did feel depressed, but got damn good at hiding it I guess.  No one who knew me would have guessed I suffered from depression. Even though I entertained the thought at times, I was uncedertain if depression was what I was suffering myself.

I was pretty down one night, and I seen this game on steam, and I thought, well, I will give it a go...

And the circumstances it placed upon your character, were spot on to how I felt.  I cried pretty hard, not necessarily the painful kind of tears, which I have learnt to shut off in my life so well, but I cried I feel for relief, and release...

I felt I finally understood that depression was what I was suffering, and there may be answer for me out there, and most importantly, that I am not alone with this and there are people who understand it, understand it enough to make something which can help identify what it is to a sufferer and help explain what its like to someone who does not suffer from it, help them understand, that the most obvious and sensible option is not always there for someone, someone who suffers from depression.

I thank the creators of this game for their effort and I am certain its helped many down a path of recovery as it had myself, and also helped others who are close to and care about those who suffer depression understand it, and possibly be less wtf, or more understanding about a sufferer of this terrible illness.

Thank you :)

There is a lot of flak for this game and it's creator. I decided to avoid reading reviews and just dive in.

Depression Quest plays like an old choose-your-adventure book. You play as a depressed man and are given different choices each passing day. Some choices can be unpickable based on the mental state of the protagonist.

All in all, there are a few different endings but the game itself is very repetitive. The protagonist is a pathetic whiner who is completely unlikable.

14571523.review:
Depression Quest isn't that bad, really. I think it stands up on its own really well. I've held judgment of it because I never bothered to install it, but taking the leap to click play is one I'm glad I took. 

While the story itself is highly cliche and likes to play into a very simple monologue, it does give you a feeling of uncertainty as to what will happen with the decisions you make and what decision you will have to make next. As someone who suffers from clinical depression, I did find that it was somewhat accurate in the descriptions of how it feels to be depressed, to go to a therapist, and be on various medications to "cure" yourself. 

Regardless of the controversy behind the creator of the game, Depression Quest does a decent job of telling a story about a real life issue. Whether or not one can classify this as a "game" is a completely different topic, but it is a rather interesting way to engage an audience through a different medium than ones that are more commonly used (like speeches, books, etc.). In my mind, there's no difference between Depression Quest and visual novels, because neither is focused on the typical aspects of a video game like graphics, gameplay, or performance. Rather, it wants you to invest your time much like you would with reading a novel. It is only a matter of what medium Quinn uses to convey the story.

Overall, you shouldn't expect much out of this title. It took me exactly 52 minutes to complete the story. However, you shouldn't be expecting a whitewash, cut-and-paste tale about how depression is bad and how it can affect you. If you do choose to install Depression Quest, I would recommend you to not go in expecting a triple A-class story, but you also should not be expecting a narrative that wants you to hold pity for the protagonist. 

I would rate the overall experience of Depression Quest a decent 6 out of 10. The story is flat in some parts, and many other parts seem to be shoehorned in for no apparent reason; however, the writing is eloquent enough for you to hold interest long enough to complete the story. For those reasons, I recommend the product.

14566339.review:
Sadly, the stigma of depression is alive and well and living here in the reviews.  People wonder why so many people die from suicide, and then they mock something designed to help people understand it.  Why?  It makes no sense.

I've battled depression for a long time.  This game didn't make me suicidal as some suggest that it would.  What it does do is make a person appreciate what depression can do to a person.  Often people don't understand why a depressed person does the things they do.  This software can can give you a glimpse into the life of a person with depression.  But also keep in mind that depression is as unique as each individual person it affects. 

If you're looking for a 'fun game', this isn't it.  In fact, I wouldn't call it a game more than I would call it a simulation. Think of it along the lines of The Stanley Parable in that it's not mean to be 'fun', but instead is meant to make you think.  

This title isn't for everyone.  It's for intelligent people with open minds who can appreciate something that can enlighten them.  It's not for people who think it is some kind of joke.  If that's how a person approaches it, then I can guarantee that you will only be wasting your time.

14484000.review:
Game #93										4.3.2020.

[h1] I heard about this game during "Gamer Gate" [/h1]

A couple of years ago, there was this movement called “Gamer Gate”. I wasn’t that much informed about how and why it started but the gist of it was that a few female game developers were getting harassed and they blamed male gamers for it. This, as you could imagine, split the internet in two where one side was saying that all gamers are chauvinistic males who hate all women that have anything to do with games while the other side claimed that female developers were just trying to gain attention and whenever they weren’t given, they would scream how everyone hates them simply for being female. Honestly, I couldn’t care less. I don’t mind girls playing games. I play games with my wife all the time and I’m hoping to get my daughter to play games with us one day too and picking either side seemed wrong.

[h1] I couldn't find a reason to NOT give this game a try [/h1]

One of the people who was deeply involved with “Gamer Gate” was Zoe Quinn, a game developer. I really can’t remember but I think she claimed that some gamers harassed her about her games saying how they are terrible simply because she was a female game developer. One of those games was this one: “Depression Quest”. Obviously, I had no intention of buying a game simply to see what the fuss was about but… the game is free, so there really was nothing stopping me from trying it out.

[h1] Ever wondered how depressed people feel? Now you might get an idea... [/h1]

Depression Quest is a game that’s supposed to help NON-depressed people understand a little better how depressed people feel and, after playing this game, I feel like I understand it a little better.

As much as I’d like to give you a sob story about how I too was depressed when I was young, I don’t want to lie. I don’t think I have ever been depressed, even when my parents got a divorce, I always found a way to keep a smile on (mostly because of video games). 

[h1] A choose-your-own-adventure game where you have choices that you can't make [/h1]

Depression Quest is a choose-your-own-adventure kind of game with a little interesting twist.  You will spend the majority of your time reading about how you live your life each day only to make a choice at the end of each page about what you will do next. You are a person who is suffering from depression. While you seem to be leading a somewhat normal life, there is undeniable sadness, lack of motivation and anxiety in you that is slowly but surely making you more depressed. As you read through the pages and make your choices, you will slowly become less or more depressed. This is where that interesting twist comes into play. Normally you have at least 3-5 options available at the end of each day, however, the top ones, which are the less depressive choices, are crossed out. 

I’m pretty sure that this is something Zoe Quinn wanted us to understand about depression. I 
believe, she wanted people to realize that when a depressed person gets to make a choice, they simply can’t make optimistic, fun or exciting choices because of their condition. 

Even though a depressed person knows that they should be dancing on the dance floor with their loved one, they simply can’t make themselves do it because of their depression so they awkwardly try to avoid as much contact as possible.

[h1] Your goal is to become happier or, at least, less depressed [/h1]

While you don't really get to read about most of the top choices in this game, they are still very visible even though they are crossed out. This is a good motivator to help your character improve. You want your character to feel happy enough to make the top choices. 

As you become happier with yourself, the topper choices start unlocking, but if you don’t try hard to improve and avoid all help, you start becoming more depressed, meaning, you start losing the amount of choices you have (even the ones in the middle and the lower ones). If you don’t do anything to try and get over depression, you will sink so deep that you will have no other choices but to exclusively do the most depressing thing (only the very bottom choice will be available to you).

[h1] Not much to talk about in the graphics department [/h1]

The graphics are non-existent. You will mostly be reading page after page of text with an occasional photo. The more depressed you get the blurrier and messier the text gets and the happier you get, the clearer it all becomes. 

The game is, unsurprisingly, really short. It took me about 30 minutes to get through the game on my first play through and every other one took less. 

[h1] I was pleasantly surprised [/h1]

Despite the length and the minimalistic graphics and gameplay I really enjoyed this little game.  While I certainly don’t understand depression and what depressed people go through every day, I think this game opened my eyes a little about this serious condition. I still don’t want to take sides about “Gamer Gate”, I am thankful to Zoe Quinn for making this free game.
If you have half an hour and are in a mood for a choose-your-own-adventure game with a unique twist, then give “Depression Quest” a go. While what the game tries to inform you about is no laughing matter, this game can be fun.

Next game: Desert Child
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/844050/

[h3]If you liked my review, feel free to follow my curator group. I’m trying to review every single game in my library. Seeing and interacting with fine folks, like you, keeps my motivation up. 
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RevAMG [/h3]

14467337.review:
[h1]ENGLISH and Italian Review[/h1]  [h1]Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA[/h1]
 

[b]English[/b]: 

Don't expect an ordinary game. Actually, i think i could say don't expect a game at all. It's an introspective and interactive reading that will put you in the shoes of a young man suffering from depression and social anxiety, and will put you in front of some choices that will affect the story and the "finale". [i]Depression Quest[/i] has been created from people that lived depression in first person, and is trying to make people that doesen't know it understand what it REALLY is, and help those that are experiencing it. Personally, i think that to live fully this game experience, you should know FOR REAL what are we talking about. A person that is a complete stranger to the concept of REAL depression, might find the game superficial and boring, thinking the you just have to make the "right" or the "healthy" decision to beat it. But it's not exactly like that. Personally, i loved the experience, loved the story, loved some characters. Could it be because i see myself in them, i don't know, but i don't care. I find that it's a good game, and i recommend it to everyone that wants to take a journey to discover this disease, or REdiscover his prospectives about it. The ONLY bad thing about this game, is that there's NOT a SAVE OPTION. It's true that, if you're Flash at reading, the game only lasts 30 minutes or so, but damn, if like me you're a person that takes things slowly and calmly, you will restart the game from the very beginning at least 2 times. So, try to play it all in one take, maybe in a lazy afternoon with nothing to do.

[b]Italiano[/b]: 

[u]Partiamo subito col dire che per giocare a questo gioco bisogna saper leggere BENE l'inglese. La lettura è parte fondamentale di quest'esperienza di gioco, e andare avanti di traduttore e "the cat is on the table" sarebbe frustrante se non impossibile. Questo putroppo rende il gioco non alla portata di tutti, ma le cose stanno così. Speriamo tentino di tradurlo, un giorno.[/u]
Detto questo, non aspettatevi il solito gioco. Si potrebbe addirittura dire "non aspettatevi un gioco" e basta. E' una lettura interattiva che vi metterà nei panni di un ragazzo che soffre di depressione e ansia sociale, mettendovi davanti a delle scelte che andranno ad influenzare il corso degli eventi ed il "finale". [i]Depression Quest[/i] è stato creato da gente che ha vissuto la cosa in prima persona, e tenta di far capire a chi non ci è mai passato cosa si provi, e di aiutare chi invece sta vivendo il problema. Personalmente, credo che per vivere pinamente quest'esperienza di gioco, bisogna conoscere bene di che cosa si sta parlando, e non solo per senito dire. Una persona totalmente digiuna al concetto di depressione VERA, potrebbe trovare il gioco superficiale e noioso, pensando che basti fare sempre la scelta "giusta" o la scelta "sana" per completare bene il gioco. Ma non è esattamente così.
Personalmente, ho amato l'esperienza, adorato la storia, e mi sono affezionato ad alcuni personaggi. Sarà perché mi ci rivedo molto, ma francamente non importa. Lo trovo un bel gioco, e lo consiglio vivamente a chiunque voglia intraprendere un viaggio per scoprire questo disagio, o riscoprire le proprie prospettive a riguardo. L'unica, e intendo UNICA pecca, è la mancanza di un opzione di salvataggio. E' vero che se sei Flash a leggere, il gioco dura a malapena mezz'ora, ma diamine, se come me sei una persona che se la prende molto con calma, ti ritroverai a dover rincominciare tutto daccapo più volte. Dunque cercate di giocarlo tutto in una volta, magari un pomeriggio che non avete nulla da fare.

14387495.review:
As someone who has had a life-long struggle with depression, I was curious about this game (partially due to the controversy surrounding it, which has been written about to death so I won't do it here).  When I stumbled upon it, I decided to try it out.

I'm a fan of visual novels which, for the uninitiated, the bulk of the "game" is reading text.  Visual novels tend to have images of the characters and backgrounds, which is part of its style and appeal.  Suffice it to say that it wasn't a great leap for me to switch over to the "gameplay" in Depression Quest.

This game seems to set out to give the reader a taste of what it's like dealing with depression, although realistically it can't cover every possible life scenario such as class, gender, orientation, race, etc.  It describes the struggles of whether or not to include those close to you in your treatment, to see a therapist, to get on or continue with medication.  Learning about things like the 'feedback loops' that were mentioned can be life savers to folks dealing with depression.  To quote the old GIJoe cartoon, "Knowing is half the battle" and insofar as presenting the information in an interesting, descriptive manner, I think this game does that quite well.  It's a well-crafted game, although I'm not sure how well its replay value would be.

My one gripe is very much with the music.  The piano riff put me in a negative mood before I read word one of the game.  I don't expect hyper anime-style music, but maybe something a little more neutral in tone would have been more suitable.

I will recommend this game as it did resonate with my own personal struggles with depression and presented the information in a straightforward, entertaining manner.

14292572.review:
TL:DR - If TL:DR applies to you, then a game that's 99% reading isn't for you.

Is this a game? Loosely. 
     There is little interaction and your choices don't specifically carry on to influence later options. They do, however, accumulate as a state of mind which impacts the number of options available. You are, in essence, taking on the role of someone who doesn't know they have depression as they fight the downward spiral. That's a deeper characterization than many games I've played.

Should you play it? That depends. 1) Do you have depression? 2) Are you interested in learning more about what people with depression deal with?
     If 1), 2), or both apply to you, then: Yes. It's an informative look into what is still a widely misunderstood illness. And it's more interesting than just reading dry scientific data.
     If neither apply to you, then: No. You won't gain any entertainment value or added perspective from this.

Overall: I like it and intend on replaying it now and then to see how different scenarios play out. Thanks to the developers for doing it well, releasing it for free, and getting it on Steam for a wider audience.

As an avid reader, I was curious to play this "game". However, when I got into it, it wasn't fully what I was expecting.

 It does have a decent amount of replayability, if you want to go back and make different choices, however, one questions if that is something that most people would even really want to do. Most of the choices seemed geared more towards keeping you in that depressive state, and all of the 'good' choices were unavailable to you. At the same time, only one side of depression was expressed, with a lot of things about the disorder being left out. This could have easily been fixed by lengthening the story and adding more to the characters in it. I felt like I wasn't really connected to the characters.

 It did, however, do an excellent job expressing the fact that depression is something that can effect anyone, no matter what you have in life. This is the one really great thing that I hope people will take away from this game. 

The music created a nice ambiance for whatever part you were at in the story as well. Which adds slightly to the mood of the story.

All in all, it wasn't a terrible game, but I do think that there are ways they could have made the experience better.

What annoys me the most is that there are no real choices presented. Any meaningful way to improve your character is vividly struck out in red, to underline that it is hopeless. This is a huge lie-  there are genuine sufferers of depression who do make an effort to and do overcome their condition. They do select the red choices and make things better for themselves.

14121453.review:
The issue I would first like to adress, is the issue of people saying this visual novel does not give an accurate description of what depression is like. I have never seen a single book, visual novel, movie, show, article, website, etc. give a proper understanding of depression. No healthy mind can understand a suffering one. (Well, there are some exceptions to this yet I am speaking of the majority of healthy minds) We simply don't have the ability to understand the extent. It is simply cruel to expect that of a game made by a limited number of people. They did their best to explain the mental suffering to those who have no issue with it. Also, the majority of the public is quite sensitive to issues as suicide and thoughts of suicide. This did a fantastic job at not giving too much visualization for those who are sensitive yet just enough to still show them the severity. 

     The next problem, is that people point out it is not a "game".  This is a visual novel. At no point was it intended to be a game in which you could play and enjoy. It gives you choice as to what you should do yet it does not tell you to "play" it per se. 

     Finally, many people say that it offers little choice and simply tells you a story. Yeah...no shiz. It is a visual "novel". This means that it is supposed to give an experience instead of let you play a lot. The choices you make do affect the outcome but the goal is the same. To speak to you about depression. The choices you make are determined by earlier choices. This shows the "player" that if you stay in one mind-set, things will continue down that path.

Anyways, that is all I have to say. I quite liked this game and don't feel that it is being judged correctly. People become really harsh to games with sensitive topics and I just wanted to give a nice review for this. I don't mean to offend anybody and if I have, I thoroughly apologize. I have little experience at a lot of things and hope that people don't take my words too seriously. This was simply my personal review.

This.
Thiiiiiiis.
Let me start from where I should: It's about a man in his mid-twenties who goes through, well, depression. It's interactive, and presents situations this man goes through while providing 2-5 options to pick your way to continue.
At the very beginning and a few more [pages?] through, it felt as it was shouting "Welcome to Ayudon". Way too me-ish, and I'm sure I'm not the only one who felt like this.
But then as I progressed it felt like.. I don't know, should I say "less charming"? With this I mean, I think I 'lost focus' on actually giving accurate answers on what *I* would do in his place and instead trying to get the best ones for him to achieve a happier mood. Maybe because it showed your mood "status" on each page and I felt like it asked me to increase it, maybe because it had options to make you choose from (still, if it hadn't I suppose it would be even less interesting) instead of being a one-way wall of text (don't get me wrong, a very worth reading wall of text)... or maybe it's just me playing it entirely for the whole night. Although it's quite short, so it's possible.
Enough, back to the point. In sintesi, if there was an "Unsure" option for recommending games, I would leave this one there. It has its ups (such as depicting something I was diagnosed with very accurately), and downs (losing its touch), but then again it might as well be just me...
... Why don't you find out *yourself*? It's a very short road in both playtime and file size, like ~100mbs, so there's that to it as well.
8/10. Might re-review it some day.. I think..

As I played through, I tried my damndest to get my character help, but every attempt to open up to somebody or to pursue help led nowhere. Beyond that, the supposed choices the game offers are a lie. I like the set up of this game and its very cool you have several possible responses to choose from in each event of this person's life your in charge of living. Of course every decision later affects future decisions.The more positive the decision, the more positive the responses usually be. Likewise the opposite can happen as well, when your character becomes more depressed. 

The one ordeal I'm trying to figure out, if its even possible is being able to almost choose the top positive expression. I do feel though that's just there to show what he'd choose if he was mentally capable to at the current moment(most of the time if chosen right it might become available) and not so deeply affected by his depression.

Regardless though playing this game helped me realize(or rememebr more clearly/understand) quite a bit about myself since I used to feel some aspects of depression after some events in my life occurred and I thought I couldn't be happy after them. I did figure out a way to get past them and got rid of habits, some mentioned here such as going to bed at a healthy time and helping others. A lot of this is real life and can happen to any of us. Depression hits you randomly but you gotta be strong enough to break from it. Granted its hard but encouraging yourself and others can do a lot of good to help those feelings melt away.

I would recommend a friend to play this at least a few times if you enjoy real life themed games cause this one is written pretty well for how generic it might seem to be layed out. I like the visual/in game sounds that add to the emotion your reading about. 13936306.review:
To be completely honest, I have (knowingly) lived with depression for over 10 years. I deliberately ignored the warning to see what this "game" had to offer. Long story short, I had a really bad breakdown and then I decided to go to therapy. So there was some benefit to me playing this.

If you have depression, this is nowhere near accurate because, even at my suicidal worst, I was still able to make myself do things. The best ending in the scenario presented isn't necessarily the right one in real life. Medication doesn't work for everybody, there are therapists who are motivated solely by money and, in my case, people aren't always understanding of what you're going through. However, like others have said, you're not alone in the end.

If you don't have depression, the same inaccuracy applies, but I will say that it can offer some insight into what depression is. There are still a lot of people who think it's a choice/lifestyle. I think DQ busted that myth just fine, but it's not always evident when someone is depressed and there is a spectrum of kinds of depression. There isn't always consistency with depression. Believe it or not, we have good days too. 

In the end, Depression Quest was a bit of an eye-opener for me personally. YMMV, but don't expect all the answers to be here.

13690021.review:
A Visual Novel with a minimalistic approach, Depression Quest is an attempt to give its players a chance to walk in the shoes of a "twenty-something human being" with depression. Like many visual novels, your choices are based upon branching paths in the text, but where the key mechanic tying the story to your actions takes place in overt locking of specific choices due to the character's state of mind. Guiding your character's coping with depression is a matter of understanding the character's limits, and reacting accordingly. 

With that said, the game does have a fairly obvious path to success for anyone with any existing sense of what depression is like. It's not therapy, it's a crash-course introduction.

It isn't fun in any traditional sense, and it will only have an effect on someone willing to have some empathy, so it's certainly not a game for everyone. 

Then again, it takes 10 minutes to experience, and it's free, so there's little reason not to at least download it and give it a spin.

WHY ARE YOU READING THE REVIEWS? Seriously, for the most part, they're worse than YouTube comments, they're written by the same kind of people, and with the same amount of careful thought and consideration. So that should tell you something.

I really do think that people who really don't understand what depression is like, but want to change that, will benefit from this.

As one who does understand, I felt for the character (myself?) as I played. I worried. I chose honest answers and got pretty accurate results. I played through it several times. Again, it's not exhaustive. I would honestly have liked to have seen more. But it's free, and it's an attempt to venture into uncharted waters with the medium. It's a discussion starter. It's good.

13374469.review:
Thought I would review this game to get an alternate opinion of it.

Depression Quest is an interactive fiction game and not a modern one. It is in the vein of early computer games that were entirely text-based and derived from narratives. I think that is one of the reasons reviews are mixed on it. It doesn't fit the mold of what a "modern" computer game is. Us old fart garmers will remember this type of gaming experience with fondness.

That being said, I can really only reccommend  the game for people who want to experience or learn about clinical depression or people who want to deal with their clinical depression in a positive way.

It is ingenious in its audacity and for tackling an often overlooked mental disease. It is innovative for its attempt to recreate the experience of a disease at a very realistic level. All the little things are there, such as the thought among many depressives that they don't actually have a disease when they are able to deal with it effectively (yes, that is a real thing) or excusing your tiredness for simply being tired, instead of the effects of a disease. Effects on concentration, focus, seeking diversion (as a result of the disease, not as a way to find enjoyment as it is with many people), social anxiety, interpersonal relationships, and others are all modeled. It takes the form of a choose-your-own-adventure (as interactive fiction generally is) and so there is some replay value to it. I personally played it several times and, since I don't know how the different paths of the game are determined, it's actually kind of fun (yes, in that ruminating depressive sort of way!) to tease out how the choices are rendered.

This is a game that does not have a wide appeal and is a very niche product. It is a game that has a therapeutic effect for suffers and/or is a way for the curious to "play" with the disease and challenge some preconceptions of yours or your preconceptions of those who suffer from the disease. If you are even remotely interested or intrigued, I'd suggest it because it is free. Just realize that the "fun" of the game is derived from  learning about something, not derived from entertainment.

13302182.review:
This is an impartial review of this game.  I'm aware of the Zoe Quinn Scandal and the bad publicity of this game, however, I wanted to try it on my own with as unbiased a few as possible.  

First and foremost, this is certainly not a game by any means and should be treated more as a depression simulation and should be provided to those suffering with depression to share with those around them.  Though the game fails to provide any catalyst to explain the depression or to allow the player to empathize with the character, all of the activities, layouts, choices, and mindsets clearly depict depression as intended.  On this front, the "game" achieves what it intended to do.  Since it is free of charge, this depression sim should be recommended to anyone who knows someone suffering with depression.  Even if you hate Zoe Quinn for the scandal or want to blast this for not being a true game, think of the message of depression and the stigma it can help alleviate to help people.

Pros:
-Accurately depicts depression symptoms, feelings, actions, restrictions etc...
-Will accurately explain depression to someone who hasn't experienced it
-Spreads awareness of what true depression is and helps alleviate stigma of mental illness
-Costs nothing

Cons:
-Just like Coming Home, this isn't a game
-The player will only relate to the character if they are within the range of late teens through twenties, limiting audience
-There is no explanation for the depression, making the character appear to be a whiny privileged person with first world problems
-Anyone unaware that this is essentially a depression sim read-along may be in for disappointment

13130645.review:
Depression Quest is a game that makes me really excited about where the medium of video games is now and direction it's going in the future. Depression Quest is an interactive educational simulation about living with depression. It attempts to use game mechanics to communicate to the player what living with depression feels like. The mechanics are simple and certainly nothing revolutionary. But what makes me excited about this game is that to me it serves as an indicator that the medium of video games is maturing to a point where games can start to cover serious topics like this and tell deeply personal stories.

The game of Depression Quest is basically a text-only roleplaying experience that repeatedly presents you with a scenario and then offers you several choices of how to deal with a the presented scenario. For instance, your in-game girlfriend may call you up and ask you if you'd like to attend a birthday party. You're then given several choices like "attend" or "politely decline" or "say you're not feeling well" or something like that. The catch is that while you can see all of the options, the ones you can actually select are almost always limited based on how depressed you're feeling. There's a few blurbs of text near the bottom of the screen which essentially serve as your "depression meter" and as you get better or worse, more or fewer options are available to you. As far as a simulation of depression goes, it was pretty effective. Sometimes you can see the option you'd really like to choose, but you just can't pick it, which is kind of frustrating.

The game states that its authors have personally struggled with depression before which makes Depression Quest's story feel very authentic. Now I'm not sure if it was the quality of the writing or how personal it felt, but I was alarmed at how many times the writing really struck a chord and resonated with me. There were many times where I was like "Oh wow, I think that to myself all the time". Again, I've never struggled with the serious, deep kind of depression this game is about, but those thoughts I had were a testament to how relatable the writing is even to someone who doesn't know much about the subject matter.

As someone who has never personally dealt with depression before, this game was a very educational tool for me and I'm very glad that this game exists. I hope it helps to raise awareness of what exactly depression is and how the people suffering from it can feel limited in their lives. I also hope that this can influence more developers to make more really personal experiences like this game. It's probably less than an hour long, but it's totally free and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a personal game or anyone who would like to try to roleplay what it's like to live life with depression

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

13083404.review:
The game is simplistic in graphics and gameplay, it's true. After all, it's a visual-novel like game. But the main theme, depression, is portrayed through music, writing and most importantly -lack of- choices. If you are used to playing games where you're supposed to win, this game is not for you. It's really disappointing to shoot an enemy only to find out they are invulnerable. But the point of Depression Quest is exactly this.

I went through depression and I believe it's different for everyone. To me, it was pretty accurate. Though I was single during most of it and one can argue the game is 'easy' because you have a significant other in it. If you're unemployed, single, poor and your family is not supportive; it's the expert mode of the game. I guess if those were true for Depression Quest, it would be much, much longer and many wouldn't bother to play.

I had fun playing it, though my description of fun might be different than yours. I love stories that makes me think, cry, or just makes me feel intensely. I felt saddened at times, chucked at others. If you went through depression, this makes you feel kind of nostalgic, and silly in the hindsight. If you aren't, it's still worth playing. When you're overwhelmed with negative feelings it's hard to see what leads to recovery and what contributes to the negative feedback loop. In its simplistic way it shows the exact way to recovery.

If you know someone who is suffering from depression, this game can make you relate. To outsiders it seems easy, just be happy, right? But some options are in fact crossed out just like how it was in the game. You need to be understanding and patient to help them get through. They can read even the tiniest disappointments and it can be really hard to speak out, because it's damn embarrassing. Try to not take their reluctance personally. It can be hard, but usually you're their only support and it's a big responsibility. Act on it.

This is not a conventional game with clear objectives and straightforward ending. It's closer to real life and it can be considered what's called an art game. Its dull graphics and sad music is contributing to the depression theme and not a minus to me. And please, please consider the fact that it's a free game.

I only got to one ending and even though it was a good one it was still overwhelming. I'll try other branches and endings as well, but I need some time before I do. Oh, by the way, if you clicked on a wrong option, you can go back by pressing backspace. (I found it instinctively.)

In short, it's both and intense and informative game, try it.

12998448.review:
[i]Depression Quest[/i] is not a fun experience. It couldn't be without subverting its own narrative. Depression doesn't have tidy little puzzles to solve, a clear path to victory, or a final boss you can defeat. Like [i]Grave of the Fireflies[/i], it's an unhappy look at an unhappy situation. But I've never seen any art, in any medium, that better conveys what major depressive disorder feels like from the inside.

Probably [i]DQ's[/i] cleverest feature is providing a list of actions, visual-novel-style, and then crossing out the obvious best choices. I found myself nodding as I played: [i]Yes, that's exactly how it feels.[/i] When you choose from the remaining options, you often find nobody understands, and sometimes the situation gets worse despite your best intentions. And every now and then the world seems to relish kicking you while you're down. Yeah, that's how life feels when you're clinically depressed.

The soundtrack deserves mention as well: The restrained, hesitant music is subtle, but sets the mood perfectly without being intrusive.

There's a good chance [i]Depression Quest[/i] will leave you feeling unhappy and unsettled, but given the subject, it [i]should[/i]. If you have friends or loved ones who suffer from depression, consider playing this game -- it may help you understand their illness.

12988063.review:
I played Depression Quest during a time of shortly after having experienced an agonizing break-up. I’m not sure if I was just dealing with grief or if I genuinely was depressed, but I played it hoping I could get an answer. My views are personal as a result.

I found the options for what I could do to be more restricting as the game went on, unnecessarily so to the point where I found it harder to feel immersed in not even being able to try to do some of the things I’d like. Considering I did get medicine and psychiatric help after the devastating end to my long-distance 5 year relationship, I’d have like to know where I would have been for pursuing the same type of help in the game. Some choices in general, particularly the ones that didn’t allow me to talk about my problems, created a greater disconnect between my feelings and the protagonist. In particular, moments where I would simply “choose” not to allow my girlfriend Alex to understand my gnawing feelings that she may to be with someone else--uncannily like my own situation--were extraordinarily frustrating. The fact that the game was becoming linear at the moment I began to actually identify wit the protagonist made this feel like a lost opportunity to me.

Either I’m too wrapped up in my own thoughts to truly empathize with the protagonist, or the developers failed to get a reliably feasible representation of what it means to feel depressed. If it’s the latter, it definitely comes in part from the emphasis on feeling doubtful for anything rather than the actual struggle it takes to pull-through with wanting to save yourself from yourself, which would have made the game give more agency to the player as well as accurately portray how depression is a behemoth of a challenge to feel you can overcome, not a parasite that forces you to make choices you don’t want to.

While the atmosphere left me ready to cry some more, the game wasn’t immersive enough to make the experience feel well-executed. If the game had more focus on allowing choices that are difficult rather than simply disallowing the best options, I would feel completely in the place of this miserable protagonist. In short, the game has potential, but definitely needs refinement before it truly becomes what it sets itself out to be.
