This is not a "fun game": it is potentially triggering, grey, confronting and relentless piece of interactive fiction which uses clever design choices (disallowed options, static, greyness) to convey the main character's level of function. Which is precisely why it succeeds as a powerful work of art, and precisely why I had to stop playing, in the end. It was too emotionally wrenching, and too good at what it does.

Recommended with some reservations, as it is very much not for everyone. It is, however, extraordinary and impressive.

12954117.review:
Well...
It's not exactly easy to give this game a cheerful thumbs up amidst a sea of negative feedback from others, but this is what I believe and this is what I have to say.

Depression Quest is misunderstood. I know that sounds like an excuse, but believe me. I've clocked in one playthrough of it and in that one playthrough, more thoughts crossed my mind than any 12 hours spent on a typical shooter of your choice. In fact, I think it's wrong for me to even bring up the term 'shooter' as though in comparison because shooters are games. That's something many people who criticise this tend to complain most about. That this is a poor excuse for a game. In doing so they miss the biggest and most powerful message that this game does it's ultimate best to send.
Depression is not a game.

I've read plenty of complaints about this game from people who do have depression that found this game insulting or offensive. The last thing I, or Depression Quest, want to do is devalue those people and their experiences. But I can assure you that the opening message of the game openly admits that it's only trying to give a semblance of depression and what it's like, though they can not, in fact they can never, fully encapsulate everything about it. No two experiences of depression are the same, something the multiple choice nature of this story can only reach for. The game is honest about itself, which I think everyone at least can appreciate. It's not the be-all, end-all definition of depression. It's a taste, based on a limited experience set to try and share the pain that is experienced in the real world.

If you have depression, the game warns you beforehand what you're getting into. You may not get along with this game, which is completely okay.
As for me? I do not have depression. Nor do I understand depression. But Depression Quest did for me what it set out to do. It showed me - if only just a little - a little of what it's like. In an ironic use of the word, it's through 'play' that I'm given a bit on insight into how hopeless life can be. This is a game that teaches and shares. It might not be music that resonates with you, but the important thing is that it's heard. And I heard it.
Another complaint I've read is that your 'character' has no personality and is an empty protagonist. Again, something has been missed. This is a game told through written 2nd-person narrative. You are the main character. This is your life that you're playing through and these are your decisions. How restricted you are is how restricted you could be if you had depression. How you're told that you're feeling is how you could be feeling if you had depression. The game is saying through it's presentation of the story and 'main character' that this could be you. This could be your life. And for some people, this is their life.
You're given choices on how to make decisions on what to do, some of which are completely inaccessable. Even though you know that it's there, you can't do it. You're told often how you feel and what your mental state is, so sometimes you'll try to do what seems like the right thing only to realise that your character is only feeling worse. You'll wonder what the right choice was, or even if there ever was a right choice to begin with. Again, not everyone faces the same kind of depression, but to see into the eyes of even one kind is... eye-opening. And regardless of how it ends, you can't simply resolve everything because, once again, this isn't a game. This is life. This is depression. This is no idealised, escapist happy ending for feeling better. This is depression awareness.

In summation, no. This game is not fun. You are not meant to have fun playing it. You are meant to think, to consider, to choose and possibly to feel. If that's not what you want, if this isn't what you're looking for, walk away. But if you're up for it, dive. Dive right in. This is less of a game and more of an experience. An experience with depression for those unenlightened to it. Even if you disagree with it and it's portrayal, that's all the more reason to try it.
I promise. Devote yourself to one playthrough and you'll come away with something meaningful. Positive or negative, this is a game that redefines what games can be and what they can live up to. This is something more games should aspire to try and perfect.

So yes. I recommend it. It's thoughtful, well-written, intricate and with the best of intentions. Above all, it's different. Even if you hate it, you should try it.

12935940.review:
I know this game isn't going to be for everyone, and everyone is entitled to their views (whether it's intelligible or non-intelligible).

That said, for me Depression Quest was a very personal and helpful experience because I invested myself into it. It's not about trying to find the best outcome for your character, or watching them fall into ruin. It's about you and how you would cope. (and if you didn't do so well even after investing yourself into the game maybe it's time to talk to someone. That said I'm not a trained professional, not that you should ignore me)

I'm not sure why I got an ending that made me feel hopeful in just one playthrough. What it has done is given me an impression that this was a well thought out game that, if played right, can be a rewarding experience. Realistic was a word used to describe it. 
However, I can't entirely agree with that description because depression can contain a myriad of situations, and it would be inaccurate to say the scope of this game covers all of those factors.
That is why for the purpose of having an indepth experience the player should try immersing themselves as best they can in the role of the character. Temporarily, it hopefully goes without saying. Just like DnD.

What stops most people from picking it up is one word.
Game.
Despite the vast amount of information out there right at people's fingertips (first-world countries at least)I'm still not sure why some still see things in black and white. Maybe it's just easier. Maybe they are brainwashed. But if I had to keep it short and sweet I'd say this.
Games are fun, but not all games are fun, and not all games are games, but fun is fun.

If you really want to know what that means is:
1. Most people think games are solely made for fun
2. In truth not all games are made for fun
3. This makes people confused about what a game is, if not fun
4. Fun is only one thing that games provide ohhhh snap.

I'd recommend this game. Most of you playing might not get the ending that will make you leap for joy, but them some of you have never had depression, not that having it is the only criteria to enjoying the game. Trying it and being honest won't hurt(you know what I mean).

12927391.review:
I suffer from a mild depression, ignored the trigger warning and played anyway. The game may have a different effect on non-depressed people, but to me it was a frightening, affirmative and strangely relaxing experience all at once. 

It's funny how people complain about the non-activeness and whether this is a game or not. Of course it's a game: you make decisions that have an impact on the ending. The gameplay itself is a direct reflection of depression: the correct answers are right in front of you yet you can't reach them; they're crossed out. Of course meeting your friends and opening up about your feelings is the right way to go, but somehow there's this invisible barrier that prevents you from doing so. There's also no indication of how many days/weeks/months/years have passed in the game. Every day starts out the same and ends with the same nagging daily grind/groundhog day feeling of failure. Many depressed people have a warped sense of time like that.

The writing is fantastic. The protagonist has enough character to make you feel sympathetic towards him, yet at the same time he's enough of a blank slate to project your own experiences on him. I do not have the exact same condition as him, but with every incident that occured this "yes! I can relate"-feeling grew and grew. Maybe the writing failed non-depressed people but to me it was spot-on.

I found two or three typos and the music was a bit distracting at first, but you get used to it quickly. 

I recommend giving the answers you would in real life (if they're available), it gives you an interesting insight into yourself. Throughout the game this exact nagging feeling I described overcame me more that once as I tried to get by with my evasive answers. I didn't get the "good" ending, yet the game left me in a somehow positive, affirmative mood. 
I am not alone in this. That's a quite comforting thought.

At first, it doesn't work, but gradually the multiple choices, and the characterizations of your protagonist and his/her loved ones shines through. 12816854.review:
Okay, let's get this out of the way: no, this game is not perfect. It certainly has its flaws, the main one being that it is basically just a "choose-your-own-adventure" book in digital form. Anyone looking for actual gameplay will be sorely disappointed.
That being said, it does a sterling job of portraying the life and experiences of someone suffering from depression. I was diagnosed with depression/bipolar disorder nearly two years ago and I found myself easily identifying with the situations described in this game, having to face most of these decisions myself at some point or another. 
Granted, things can become a little dramatised at times but in an industry that tends to focus on little more than flashy graphics and genric stories, it's refreshing to see a game come out that at least tries to make a difference (even if it occasionally stumbles). 
Depression Quest is a fantastic example of video-games as a tool for powerful story-telling as well as a great introduction into what it can be like to live with depression. Consider it highly recommended.

Mix the Whiskey, fruit juice and syrup and add to a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake for a few seconds and serve over ice with a cherry to garnish.

12783921.review:
Depression Quest is a well written interactive text game. An unnamed male protagionist, whom you play as, suffers from depression. He finds it hard to muster up the motivation to do anything and hates himself for it. There are many nights where he can't fall asleep because of the insecurities that plauge his mind.

This is also represented very well with the filter that is put on the photography that acompanies the text. There is text at the bottom on most pages that helps monitor how severe the character's state of depression is. The player has multiple opertunities to chose different kinds of treatment or to ignore it all together.

The protagionist has multiple friends and how you choose to socalize with them affect the ending and the character's overall mood. The parts with the protagionist's girlfriend, Alex, got to me the most.

Most of my closest childhood friends suffer from depression and it really hit home for me to play this story out. When people think of depression, they think of sadness. What people really feel is exhaustion and a lack of motivation accompanied by self hatred for this lack of energy. This is one of the points Depression Quest drives home the most.

Even if it doesn't sound interesting, I never felt uninterested. It took me an hour and a half to complete it the first time and even in parts where I thought it was hard to continue, that I wanted to put the game down, it was never in disinterest. This game is beautiful and I would encourage anyone who likes interactive text to give this one a chance. It is, afterall, free.

I just hope this scandle allows this game to reach more people because of it...

12767239.review:
It's difficult to recommend Depression Quest, not just for its controversial nature but also because it tackles a topic that's rarely dealt with in video game or visual novel narratives. To me, Depression Quest is more of an interactive semi-visual novel, which isn't a bad thing perse, but don't expect an orthodox "gaming experience".
At first I was very reluctant to give this story a go, but I went through the darkness and "won". It definitely has some merit to it, so if you don't mind placing yourself in the role of a person struggling with depression or just with shitty conditions that are going on, then give this "game" a go.

12762948.review: It helped me understand a debilitating illness that has affected countless people, including many of my own friends. I don't know what else you could want from a game.

12757971.review: This game is very rude towards people like me who deal with depression. I could only sit through 12 minutes of the game before I just shook my head and turned it off to write this review. This character you play as isn't even depressed. They just have no personality. I mean I understand that the creator wants YOU as the player to experience what it's like to go through life and make every day choices while dealing with depression, but this is far from accurate. Maybe it IS like this for some people in worst case scenarios, but still, even depressed people have a personality of some sort. Also, the music was very boring, slow, annoyingly repetitive, and just made me even less interested in playing more of the game. This also applies to the visuals. If I could, I'd rather continue to read it as a visual novel instead. Maybe it gets better the further you play, but until then, I wouldn't recommend playing this game if you have depression. It'll just make you angry at the creator. Even if you don't have depression the overall game so far is very boring.

12752811.review: No. Nice cause, but terrible execution. It just makes me sad. I don't like that. Reallyreallydont.

12750809.review:
Suffering from depression myself, I found playing this game both a comforting and disturbing experience. So many of the scenarios explored here mirror my own experiences, but approaching them in a game-setting helped me get some distance and put them into perspective. It helps that the writing is thoughtful and beautifully understated throughout. A save feature would have been appreciated, especially seeing as the emotional impact it's likely to have on many people necessitates regular breaks. Be aware that if you do suffer from depression, as is clearly stated in the game's disclaimer at the start, you might encounter a number of triggers. If you have no experience with depression yourself but would like to gain an insight into the mindset of a sufferer, this definitely gives you a solid idea.

On a side note, one can't help but wonder whether the many negative reviews are due to the recent/ongoing character assassination and hate campaign against developer Zoe Quinn. Regardless of what you've heard, the game really deserves a chance.

12740570.review:
This is an incredibly intimate experience. ‘Depression Quest’ is a noticeably basic game, yet managed to convey so much with text and a simple selection of choices. The game demonstrates what it feels like to have depression by stripping a game down to its simplest essence: a selection of choices. Then, it limits those choices. You can only agonise as you see a perfectly logical choice crossed out, then realise that of course with depression there is little logic. You begin falling for the paradoxes: not wanting to hurt those around you, but making them hurt by keeping all this inside yourself. Even when the game gives you the option to open up to others, you yourself don’t want to do it in case it makes things worse. But of course, it’s getting worse anyway. 

As you can see, the game is free. It’s a tiny download, and it’s short. You have nothing to lose here.

Surprisingly important and accurate representation of what it *can* be like to live with depression. My experience with it seems to echo those portrayed in Depression Quest well. Ignore the GamerGaters who are giving this bad reviews for personal/political reasons. 12654609.review: I am bipolar.  This game is a thought-provoking look into both depression and the 'down' swings involved with my own disorder. I plan to encourage those close to me to at least attempt this game, in hopes of better understanding.

12650458.review: So... the point of this game is to enable people to empathize with those who have depression; however, the author fails in that aspect. Honestly, you'll learn more about depression from Wikipedia and mental health organizations.

12645934.review:
Absolutely love this game. It really does a great job of representing depression, something I am unfortunately  very familiar with. The choices are so accurate, and the overall atmosphere so abysmal it really does help the player to see how every day choices for people with depression can be painstakingly difficult. Just getting out of bed has taken me literally hours some days.

As a person who has depression, it did help me feel a bit more like I was part of a largery community working to gain awareness and support for depression. It's an illness and nothing to be ashamed of. I can understand how the game might be triggering for people, but for me it really just felt like something that really understood what I've gone through (although, of course, my experience and everyone's is unique).

12643747.review:
People might not see this as good, but I did. It is sad yes but then you don't expect a game called depression quest to be a land of happy rainbows. A lot of it may feel vague but that is so you can step into the person and think on what to say or do. Yes some are blanked out because thats how it is in life. You might know that the obvious thing is to get over it, be happy and hang out with friends but the very thought is enough to paralyse you for hours. A lot of this game did make me think about myself, I'm undergoing treatment for depression myself and whilst people complain about it and the ending, I found the ending incredibly moving and that it was a lot better than sudden "CURE" and insta-happiness. It was more real.

I would whole heartedly recomend it, especially to friends of people with depression. Might give you an insight into their lives.
